articleText:
SMALLER ISSUES'ÖF"

"MORNING BULLETIN"

Consequent upon the reduc- tion in imports of newsprint,

as a measure towards meet-

ing the dollar crisis, newspap. ers throughout Australia will be reduced in size from today.

The cut imposed on the "Morning Bulletin" will mean the loss of a number of pages each week, thus reducing the space allotted for both news and advertising. Despite these reductions, however, it will he the aim of this paper to main- tain its full coverage of local ¡ and district news, plus essen-

tial news items from national and overseas sources. This will be effected in changed methods of presentation, heading space being reduced to a minimum.
heading: SMALLER ISSUES OF "MORNING BULLETIN"

articleText:
¥*e ¿Boniiiig fBttlletfn

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, JANUARY 21, 1947

IDLE THINGS

The next best thing to destroy- ing or losing a commodity is to put it in a state of enforced idle- ness. The swiftest racehorse in the world becomes a costly lia* bility if he is kept eating his weight in feed every ten weeks or so when he should be racing. Ex- pensive machinery ia economic or not according to the ratio of acti- vity to idleness. Unskilled labour, which really pits itself against the machine, must work full time if it is to escape the bare susten- ance of the dole. All of these things are elementary truths that apply equally if a country is under a dictatorship and its people are mere slaves, or if it is carried on by a much-despised capitalism. There vere mighty few idle fac- tories in Germany before and during the war, and there are mighty few idle industrial plants in Russia today. By whatsoever means they are kept going or I whatever may be the name given

to auch measures so as not to offend delicate western ears makes Tory little difference to the man who would throw a spanner into tho works, for he does not remain for long in a condition to know, what happened to him. That is a Russian institution to which they are entitled if it suits them, "but it is different in'Australia.

The ' last year or so has been one of steady industrial declen- sion, when men in their thousands were thrown out of work that was crying to be done for people who aro desperately in need of all lands of commodities. Ko country can for long afford to feed armies of striking men, and Australia is no exception to the rule. All sta* tisticg are lagging^badly -indus- trial by nine and financial by four months--but all things point to an %3-time record of idle men over Tie past -year. Being on strike is regarded differently statistically from being unemployed, though the cost to the nation differs only on degree. Nor can ' the loss be reckoned solely in days of idleness, for industry cannot be stopped

and started like a clock. Much un- productive dead work has to be done, and such are the ramifica- tions, of industry that in some cases it is montis ere the wheels are again in consonance, while many commodities deteriorate through being held and so are a total lose. These losses are na- tional losses, there being no fairy god mother to drop along and level them off. They come out of the resources-of the State no matter who pays them or who loses them.

But all losses are not of man- power. Millions of pounds worth of ^production plant and machinery of every description, rolling stock and i steaming ships are rendered lifeless when this union or that walks out of its occupation 'instead of; walking into the Arbitration Court. Over the last year it has been a commonplace for fleets of ships to be rendered idle on a frivolous excuse or on none at all. Whole systems of railways and strings of rpad transport have been rendered useless, and vast production systems of every kind of commodity necessary to man's I comfort and well-being have been

rendered inert and useless. Ia countless ways the careful plan- ning of far-seeing men has been I overthrown by the unstable ukase

I based upon a show of hands at a mass meeting where it was as I much as one's safety was worth to

i indicate the least sign- of opposi ' tion to spell-binding mob psycho-

logy.

All of this cost money, the loan of which left the nation poorer. All of it added to the cost of pro- ducing things, and so to the cost of living. Idle men, idle machines, ? idle ships and trains and idle plant ' of every description are a luxury

or madness-that no nation can afford, and none knows that bet I ter than the Communists who arc engineering it alL It all tends tc I a spiralling inflation and a sense lof frustration, it inspires defeat-

ism and confusion, and tends tc j break down confidence in the Aus

I tralian way of life. Clamour foi higher wages without correspond ing increase in production is th« shortest possible cut to uncontrol lable inflation, and in campaigning ¡for "40 hours and more pay" ai I one of the tasks fer 1947 the Com-

munists are trying to stampede the people of Australia along thal thorny path.

The Chifley Government is help ing, too. It has imported int* peace the financial policy of war Jt believes that inflation might b* defeated by throttling industry just as lt was believed-and right ¡ly too-that private industry am private spending must be, subord inated to the needs of war. Tba was sound as long as there was < war, but is doddering imbecility now that there is no war and up wards of three-quarters of a mil lion workers have been returned t* industay on which the hobbles ari being, kept. The idea of holdinj back inflation by subsidising risinj costs ia like trying to extinguisl a fire with oil. It cures nothinj and controls nothing,, though unti people realise that they are pay

ing the subsidy out of their pay envelope it encourages the belief that they are getting something'

for nothing.

The Chîûey Government is add- ing to tiie list of dead things, in that the volume of inert money lying at call in the nine trading banks is increasing daily. Since 1942 it has grown by just on £200 million-, a colossal amount in a country of only seven million pêople and where so much remains to be done. Yet it is lying there as dead as any fleet of strike bound ships, or inert trains, and nobody is the richer for* its exis- tence. Like the ships and trains, the value to humanity of money lies only in its use, and w© ape cursed with a Government that

does not know, or has not the ' moral courage, enough to get it to j work. It was claimed for Labour that all it needed was control of the Commonwealth Bank and also of both Houses of the Federal

Parliament. Well, the Chifley Gov- ernment has both, and where it has not sold out to the Commun-

ists it is trying with flabby hands to prevent industry getting to its

feet.

One hail mark of "progress" is that savings bank deposits dropped by - £4JI million between August and October last, while bank notes in circulation reached a new high

The former was the barometer of' despair, when small' folk dipped into the stocking to meet rising costs and short work; .the latter is the indisputable sign that all goes well on the black market, which means that it goes pretty badly for the rest of the com munitya

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

* ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, JULY 22, 1947.

GETTING DRIER

Should anyone consult the Cons

monwealth Meteorological Depart-j ment rainfall sheet for the year 1947 he will read that the annual average rainfall at Cloncurry is 17.96 inches. The distribution is, of coursa, a matter for the monthly rainfall sheets. It is also possible',

to find that rainfall records for

Cloncurry have . been kept sine» 1885, or for the last 62 years. Con-

siderable importf.nce is ~ rightly ' placed upon the length of time over1 which the average so given ip taken, but none seems to be given to the possibilities of the rainfall increasing or diminishing over that period. Yet in a country of rainv

fall so erratic as" that over the

greater part of Australia it should be apparent to any critical observer .that not only are there such pos- sibilities, but that they are highly important.

In thc case of Cloncurry, which is taken because this analysis had to start somewhere; it is possible to turn to page 216 of ^Rainfall

Observations Made In Queensland,'' j which was published in 1914, there to find that the average annual

rainfall over 29 years to 1912 was ; 19.54 inches, which is 1.58 inches higher than that given 33 years

later. Superficially, it would ap- j pear therefore that Cloncurry fain fall is- diminishing " by slightly under half an inch a year, a mat- ter in itself should cause'interested parties to become inquisitive, but there is much more to it.than that. The rainfall in the 33 years be- tween 1912 and 1946 had, in fact, diminished by an amount sufficient lo depress -the rainfall over the whole 62, years by 8« per cent, and so was overstated in "the .'official sheet by over an. inch. . The aver-; age rainfall during1 that period' .was, in fact/, 16.58 inches or 1,38 inches below the official figure., for 1946, and was- 2.96 inches or 15.2 per cent-below the official figure for 1912, a cumulative average of 0.09 inches, per. year., ., V

This instance-and " there are

tragically many more of them shows how misleading the un- analysed use of cumulative aver- ages can be. Nebo rainfall, the annual average of which fell from 31.90 in. in 1912 to 29.97 in 1946, over 76 years actually fell from 31.90 to 27.48 in., being a drop of 14 per cent' in 33 years, and Brisbane was.only slightly better with a. drop of 13.8 per cent, or nearly half per cent per . annum over the same period. There are dozens of other 'cases, for even on superficial'.comparison 73 per cent of the total 242 Queensland Jain recording stations on the official sheets show. a drop in the «mmil average rainfall in 1946 against

that for 1912.

Incidentally, much the Same thing prevails as far south as Sydney and to the western border, as Jby the sanie, comparison .66 per cent of the combined. New . South Wales and.Queensland rain record- ing stations on the official sheets have a decreasing registration. For the other four States the ups and downs are practically even for the total 755 sheet recorded stations, which should spell the doom of the cycle theory rof rainfall, as we can hardly, have cycles working for. in- creased rain in one part of Aus- tralia and for decreased precipita-

tion in another.

This is hardly a matter that can be dismissed with a shrug of the shoulders to an incoming Parlia- ment or an incoming'tenant. The stock-carrying capacity of land de- pends upon rainfall, Which in turn determines Crown rents and capital values, and on this showing jthers are many millions of acres oi land in Queensland with a much lower capital value than was fan and equitable 33 years ago. Con- sideration of these basic facts should also steady up the insane tendency to sink vast sums of pub- lic money running railways through immense arcas of dimiiriahfog

rainfall. It is less a matter of forecasting what weather to ex- pect in a land of notoriously erratic rainfall than it ie one of drawing

some useful deductions from data based upon observations extending back for upwards of three-quartets of a century. There is less ex- cuse for thc follies of the future if we fail to make intelligent use of the lessons of the past, and many such lessons are to be found in the rebordeo rainfalls.

In 1914 the flow of artesian bores

in Queensland was at its maximum, subsequently to which in 1943 there was an increase of 63 per cent in the number of bores sunk and a decrease of 36 per cent in the aggregate bore flow per 24 hours. Nobody knew in 1914 that from then thë bore flow would diminish, any more than they knew -in 1912 that from then to 1946 there would be a decrease in rain-

fall in the case of just on three quarters of the rainfall stations shown on official sheets. Nor

does anybody know how much lower the aggregate Queensland bore flow will sink, any more than they know how much tonger the rainfall will continue to diminish, and there seems to be little or

nothing that can be done about

either of them.

It is realised, of course, that diminution of 'the bore flow may be due as much to loss of air près sure as to actual depletion of artè sian water supplies, but there seems to be little chance of deter- mining which is which, or does it seem likely that even a Boyai

Commission could assess to what

extent-if 'any-sinking bore heads is due Jo diminution in the rain- fall, because there does not appear to be any well-defined accepted area within which are the intake channels or seepages through which replenishing waters reach the under- ground storage. Not even the fact that Cooper's Creek-which is the mouth of the' Barcoo and Thompson Eivers-hag . not dis- charged into Lake Eyre for up- wards of 40 years is generally ac- cepted as one reason for the «ink-

ing bore-heads; but few people will dispute that diminishing rainfall had much to do with the drying tip of Cooper's Creek.

Jos record impregnation cjf ¿ora'

water with fluorine announced re

eently could be camed either by in- creased quantities of that chemical finding its way into the under- ground storage or in the quanti- ties already there being contained

?n less water, than hitherto, and here, .too, nobody is in a position to say which is right.. The ele- mentary facts as we know them are that the borè-heads are . sinking, rainfall is diminishing, and bore water is impregnated more strong- ly than ever before with fluorine.

It seems as if we can do very

little with any of them, but there is "no possible shadow of doubt whatever" but that we should get to know all that ws maj of all tars* og toan*

ROCKHAMPIOIS

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 15, ( 1947.

ABOUT STANDARDS j

To mention standardisation

polite society these days is imm lately to become suspect of be in league with totalitarian &J cow, or at least to be of that w created fraternity of "Dianne who knew of both time and pl for everything - provided tl could only remember how to i them. By long association of id it has come to mean for m people the apotheosis of all that dull and monotonous with eve thing out of the same mould, m production at its dreariest 1 villas in a row, or the cut and p tern of prison clothes. lots _

experts who should know bet still view standardisation as

freezing of individual effort, ' stultification of ideas -or "rib! development" in the abstract. A how would we like to have sup imposed on the existing Uewild lng restrictions and repressic and shortages, that make of ho: building a nightmare, the stands which was set in 1101 by Henry by declaring that a yard TI henceforward to be the length his arm Î .

Oddly enough few objectors

standardisation ever seem to cc nect it with such fundamenl facts as standard weights a; measures which are the han maidens of commerce, or with t alphabet which is the raw materi used by poets and, common fe to express ideas, or. with arit metic without which eomputatii of tote dividends-among oth things-would degenerate into t] primitive methods of tooth ai daw. Standards, in fact, perfor two important functions: Thi enable us to identify goods ax grades so that we are able to bu with greater likelihood of getth value for our money; and th« enable producers to make moi goods with the same effort and ii ' vestment, thus spreading commod ties over a wider area at prici within the reach of .more peopl Without those two aids, buyir. and selling goods would- soon fa into a state of confusion infinite! worse than that in Alice's Wondei land, and Mad Hatters would 1 even more plentiful than polit

cians. -

A standard is something estai lished by either'authority, custoi or general consent; a unit < measurement against which a actual object or deed may i judged. It is something that, con forming to justice, is right or cor rect. There are stanfords for th nutritive value of food,'the lise .fl drugs, and safety in the packin] of canned. goods. 'Then there ar standard dimensions ior part which must fit together, such a ian electric light bulb and it Bocket. Then there are standard of identity, as for the commoi bolt and nut which* the bewilder ingly beautiful munitions worke

defined as*.

"A bolt ls a thing like à stick, of han metal. ; such as iron, withy* squat lump on one end-and slot of scratch lng' wound" round '..the other. A" nu is similar te .tte bolt, bat Just tb apposite, v£elng a . hefte iç.~ a littl chunk of iron with wrinkles round th

, inside," .

. Imagine 'iryingr^to work tba

into the needs oT a^ disabled wind «lill 'or täte Internal economy o! a disc plough.'. - \ -

Then there is the- standard o:

quality which measures the com modify against a mark or point indicating perfection^ as for in stance when one buyB silverware öu which, is a full-length picture o J Britannia,- one knows that one if getting silver of the period ol

1697-1720 which has ll oz. 10 dwi of flue metal to each 10 dwt oi

I alloy; exactly as there must be 'standard proportions of -fruit and

liquid in a tin. By standardised

dimensions a wonderful technical accuracy, provided by expensive machinery operated hy skilled ! workmen, cuts and grinds and fits

adjustable parts true to the ten thousandth of an inch. Any who doubt the practical value of this searching accuracy should, try rid- ing behind a motor engine that was built before these standards were known. As a last bastion of individualism U.S.A. is neverthe- less a whale on standards. Her vast industrial output is based upon it. and after working their way through every kind of mechanical implement and device her engi- neers ended by standardising woman's dress to a higher degree than in any other country in the world. As these zealots left them among the best dressed women in the world TJ.S.A. ladies have no grouch against , these iconoclasts.

But in this as in other matters difficulties surround the indiscrim- inate .setting up and operating of standards. Even nature makes blunders in carrying standardisa- tion too far. Having ,as it were set the mould or standard, she started to turn out things in vast num- bers as in the case of grasshoppers and rabbits and brigalow suckers.

Each is perfect to its own stan-j dard, but there are far too many of them even for their own well- being.

Freedom of choice and changing styles provide the greatest safe- guards against useful standardisa- tion degenerating into dictatorial regimentation. Standards present facts upon which people can exer- cise judgement, but their judge- ment is moved by their desires. That is the brake upon manufac- turers going too far in standardis- ation. The consumerais not merely a consumer, but a compendium of biology, psychology, economics, many of the follies and some of the arts. Such a make-up does not yield readily to regimentation by whatsoever name it may be known.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, MAY 20, 1947.

CARDINAL GILROY

We welcome among us I Eminence the Most Revere Cardinal Gilroy, the first Av tralian to become a prince of t Catholic Church, and hence eligil to become Papal head of tfa Church. A good general not on sends trusty soldiers to man t outposts. ' He visits them, too,

take counsel among them so th he may learn their local needs ai viewpoints ; but most of all do he go to sustain their faith,

encourage them to fresh vigilan and a higher courage.

These are times of great respo: sibility for custodians of the Chri tian faith. At no time in h tory has human degradation ai despair, twin after-effects of t] scourge of war, plumbed sui abyssmal depths. Never befo have whole continents been ra aged so devastatingly ; or star ing, homeless multitudes roami among the rubble of what we; once great populous cities throng« with well-fed, prosperous peopl The mind reels at contemplati( of the immensity of Inman sorro and stark suffering. Yet thei very conditions are hotbeds of evj forcing-grounds of rebellion again; moral restraint, and if men ? their utter despair are not to ei brace strange gods, to fall victii to doctrines of violence and i tolerance, then must leaders < the Christian faith be vigilant ac purposeful," must translate the faith with strength and vision.

It ie not inappropriate to H Eminence's presence among us * recall that he began his caree after leaving school as a telegrap messenger, and as such he carrie to many thousands of people tid ings of joy and suffering, of pari ing- and reunion, of life and c death. Today he is among v as a hearer of a message from Hi Holiness the Pope to Roma Catholic adherents throughout Cen tral Queensland, to he of goo faith and stout of heart. BJ Eminence is visiting the outpost« is strengthening the bastions a

Mother Church.

Outposts of Catholicism stretcl far beyond the confines of the Aus tralian mainland, and so cam ander the devastating influences o Japanese occupation. Mission worl came to an end, more than hal of the missionaries of New Guinei are dead, the Marist missions in th< North« Solomons were completely destroyed, the. cathedral and mis sions in the South Solomons are t heap of- ruins, the Sacred Heart Mission at Rabaul is in little bet ter case,' the Alexhafen missioi valued at upwards of £1,000,00< was wiped out," and the Societj of the Divine Word suffer- ed bady in both personnel and property. " If we are able to ac< now," said the Right Rev. Mon- signor James H. Hannan, in au appeal after resigning his position as National Director for the Pro- pagation of the Faith, Melbourne] to become a missionary in the Solomon Islands, "the present moment may well prove to be God's hour in the Pacific." Mgr Han- nan reached Bougainville in June last, whence he sent the beckoning message: "The greatest gift that Australia can make tb the people under our care is ike gift of Christian civilisation * He has since been followed by 10 priests¿ one doctor and six laymen.

These are frontline soldiers of Mother Church, and they will be heartened by the proximity to them of their Australian Church leader. So, too, will the eight Franciscan Missionaries of Mary, who in 1945 took over from Sisters of the Order of Our Lady Help their ministrations among the abo- riginal lepers on Fantome Island, near Townsville. The report of His Eminence on those outposts should make a glowing page.

His Eminence will find that 3fother Church is being well servèd by her leaders in this district. On the roll of pioneer achievement he will find the names of many Church adherents, who are also well represented in the commercial and public life of the community. The National Catholic Rural Movement, inaugurated during the stress of war in January, 1941, by His Lordship the- late Right Rev. R. Hayes, DJ)., has carried the rural liturgy into country life, and so has raised the stature of the tiller of the soil.

The visit of His Eminence is welcome as a spiritual inspiration to a considerable section of the community, SB well as a powerful ally against thtrforces of evil that, to the weary and feeble, may appear overwhelming. Christian- ity was never stronger than when it required all the faith and powers of endurance of its adherents lest it be overwhelmed ; and it re- quires no less now than ever be- fore all that faith and all those powers of endurance. We must be no worse led than our enemies, and Cardinal Gilroy's presence here is an earnest of Catholic leader- ship that will inspire confidence beyond the official confines of the

Catholic Church.

articleText:
Gb* Jitarning ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON;

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1947.

YOUTH MOVEMENTS.

¡ Latterly pointed attention ha

been directed to the question o youth movements in Australia. Ii will come as a surprise to a .gre« I many people to learn that th» better known organisations, whicl are constantly before thc publii eye, are doing by no means as wei as they should be, and that othei less publicised groups are doing a whole lot better than might be ex- pected^ in a country such as this

The first disturbing note arose from the visit of Lady Baden Powell, head of the Girl Guides, who revealed that this admirable character-building organisation for girls is on the decline in Austra- lia, a condition in distinct contrast with older countries, . especially those which bore the brunt of the late war. About the same time, at the annual meeting of the Boy Scouts Association of N.S.W., Sir John Northcott had occasion to ex- press regret at the slow growth of Scouting in that State, something that possibly is indicative of a general trend throughout the Commonwealth, though no evidence was offered on the point. The Governor laid stress upon the fact that a total membership of only 21,000 for the whole of N.S.W. meant that the movement was touching only a small percentage of the youth of the State.

If this apparent apathy to- wards our youth movements was all that had to be recorded it would still be a matter for grave concern, but there is a more sinis- ter aspect. Whilst the membership of the Girl Guides declines and the Boy Scouts manage to do little better than hold their ground, %here is a steady growth in Aus- tralia of other youth movements whose objectives, in the words of Sir John Northcott,, "are not so worthy and have not 6iich good in- tentions." "Let us not blind our- selves to the fact that they aw strong and growing," said the chairman of the Scout meeting. "If we cannot be as effective and thorough in building up our own movement we can have only our- selves to blame if the next genera- tion has not been wisely guided. We should not rest until we hava at least half of the youth of the country in the Scouts and Guides

movements."

This is something that bolds : responsibility for others beside those directly concerned in the con duct of youth organisations. It ii all too "true that the future o Australia resides in the hands o the youth of the Commonwealth On the actions and thoughts o: the next and . succeeding genera' tions will depend whether Austia Ma is to be a Democratic, or : Fascist, or a Communist nation, o: whether it is to be a. nation al all. Youth movements founded 01 democratic principles and whosi sole object is to mould the char acter of its members to manliness and true womanliness, and incul cate the principles of good citizen ship, should be encouraged to thc utmost at : this time when thc world is" in process of reshaping Jib plea of preoccupation wit! graver matters should serve as au excuse for neglect of this public duty. _

It might be .worth while to con- duct an examination into possible reasons for the Scout and Guide movements doing little better than mark time at a period when there is so strong a call for their ex- pansion. Certainly it cannot be at- tributed to any lack of appeal in .objective, and there is no question of the earnestness and devotion oi those who have dedicated them- selves as leaderg in the work. Yet it may be that in the competing interests and diversions of an ex- citing scientific age even the Scout and Guide movements will find themselves under the necessity oí inarching with the times and en- suring that their methods are made as modern as possible.

Thc real cause of the slow pro- gress of these movements may be laid at the door of a lack of sym- pathetic interest on the part of the people at large. There is nothing which John Citizen is more prone to leave to the willing few. Hence the responsibility of stimulating our organisations is not only one for Australian youth, but it rests upon parents and the com- munity as a whole. Rockhampton, in view of its maintenance of Scout and Guide organisations, physical fitness groups, the Crippled Children's Society and Bush Children's Health Scheme, might be disposed to be resentful at any hint that it is. not doing everything possible for our youth. Yet it cannot be escaped that s public appeal for £500 to equip a children's playground in the city has been hanging fire for six months, and is still uncompleted..

A first need is a closer public- in- terest in recognised youth move- ments and a closer coordination be- tween organisations having a .com- mon objective. One age group for which most requires to be done is the 15-21 group, especially those who have left school and do not belong to any kind of youth or- ganisation. Often they feel that they belong to no one-not even their homes. At the present time many nations, including our own, are alarmed at the rebirth of the

Comintern, Little stress has been laid upon the fact that the only way to meet the challenge of an unwelcome ideology is to convince ourselves and make it clear that our own system 2s best. There is no better way of doing that than through recognised youth organisa-

tions.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON THURSDAY, OCTOBER 16, 1947. YOUTH MOVEMENTS.

articleText:
Cte ¿ftornmg JMIttiii

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, MARCH 21, 1Ö47.

STILL UNSETTLED

The fresh resort to arms in Java even though it be only a gporadh affair, must occasion grave colleen in the minds of those" who look foi a brighter turn to world affairs when strife and misunderstanding will give way to cooperation and goodwill and the great work of re- construction, now marking time, ii enabled to^go forward. Combined

with sinrnar disturbances else where,, and the by no. means en- couraging spirit prevalent at tnt meeting of the Big Four in Mos- cow, it lays emphasis on a question that has been raised1 more than once-whether the world was ready for peace when it came?

The protracted delay in ratifica- tion by the Netherlands and In- donesian Governments of the agree- ment initialled last October was bound to hold possibilities of a fresh crop of disorders, and the British Government has felt con- strained to urge upon both sides the necessity of a speedy settle- ment of outside issues. Britain has a special interest in wishing to see the October agreement imple- mented, since 8he played a big part in bringing the Dutch and Indo- nesians together, and one of her diplomats presided over the crucial meeting at which the agreement wa» reached. It is a tragedy that, when a mutually accepted formula was found, there should remain so many formidable obstacles, most of them based on national pride and suspicion.

The Dutch are held to be not al- together blameless for the delay in signing the agreement, as they are insisting that there should be at-

tached a memorandum of inter- pretation by the Minister for Over- seas Territories. Thi8 the Indo- nesians will not accept, and argue that the Dutch would not have been prepared to accept the incor- poration of an Indonesian interpre- tation had its inclusion been sought. Neither side has been wil- ling to acknowledge that questions of interpretation are of secondary importance to the ratification of the agreement and can be thrashed out afterwards. Through these* things there is a danger of months of fruitful negotiation having been lost, and the whole Indonesian sit- uation thrown back to where it was. It requires no more than a few incidents of the character re-

ported this week to bring about

such a state of affairs.

The interests of Holland and Indonesia demand that there shall be no more fighting, that the im- passe over the agreement shall be overcome and the earliest possible start made with the building of the United States of Indonesia, in union with the Netherlands, as is provided for in the agreement that awaits ratification. The real cause of the drift is the absence of that cooperative attitude on the crea- tion of which so much time and trouble were expended. The con- tinued absence of a cooperative at- titude will play into the hands of the extremists in Indonesia and the reactionaries in Holland who would, prefer to see the future of Indo- nesia settled not by negotiation but hy force of arms.

The effect of the present situa- tion on a large section of the native population is not the least of the reasons why things should be encouraged to settle down in this greatly disturbed country. As recently as this week Australian Press correspondents in Java de- scribed harrowing scenes of half

starved native men and women and

children seeking Red Cross aid. Nothing that emerged from the Nazi concentration camps of Europe was any worse than the emaciated human beings which are the result of two year's strife in what was formerly known a8 one of the most bountiful lands on the face of tho

earth.

Australia may consider that, having enough troubles of her own, she can remain indifferent to the wranglings of the Dutch and a former subject native race. We will not be the first country who has taken the view that a neigh- bour's quarrel ÍB not their concern, only to find out how gre yiously mistaken wo were. The

disturbances in Indonesia is no business of Australia insofar as we can take any practical measures to hasten a settlement. But it is a matter of concern in other ways. Indonesia is one of the near neigh- bour countries which Australia would wish to see politically tran- j quil and enjoying a peaceful, pros- j perous development, because our j

own development and trade ex- pansion are linked therewith. In addition, there is the tremendously important aspect of a mutual de- fence pact, advantageous to both.

An unsettled neighbour torn .by civil war has no value from either a commercial or defence point of view, but is a potential source of danger in the latter sense. There is little that Australia can do about it except discourage the med- dlesome interference that was in-

troduced into NEI affairs last year by waterfront elements, and to'

join in the hope that now that I pointed attention has been directed to the danger of a relapse to hos- tilities, open or covert, the sane elements of both Dutch and Indo- nesians will get on with the

business of working together. j
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON FRIDAY, MARCH 21, 1947. STILL UNSETTLED
snippet: The fresh resort to arms in Java, even though it be only a sporadic affair, must occasion grave concern in the minds of those who look for

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY. MAY 29, 1947.

METEOROLOGICAL BEGIN-

NINGS

Meteorology in Australia bad small beginnings, which were probably based more upon curiosity than with any intent to build up a foundation of serious weather research. It appears that-not un naturally-«ie first element to

impress'itself upon folk from an j English climate was temperature, for in a despatch to Viscount Castlereagh dated October 31,

1807 Governor Bligh included the, temperatures at Sydney over the previous months. It is not re- corded what His Lordship thought of them, nor does it appear that the series of readings was con-

tinued. , ... i

Then came Governor Brisbane m j 1821, whose scientific leanings were so well known to Lord Bathurst that he received the first recom- mendation of the appointment with a testy: "I want à man to govern the earth, not the heavens." But if Brisbane lacked political or economic perception he came to be described by Herschel as "the founder of Australian science," end it is recorded when he left for London in 1S25 that he had had barometers placed at Bathurst, Newcastle and Sydney. Not much is known of their ultimate use but they appear to have been the first of such important- meteorological instruments to be set up in Aus-

tralia.

The actual beginning of meteor- ological records, with a view to ultimate research into Australian climate, may be said to have been the arrivai at Sydney of a book by Lt-Col W. Eeid. in which was "an attempt . to develop the law of storms by means of facts arranged according to place and time, and hence to point out a cause for the

variable winds." The book was

sent by Lord Glenelg to Governor Gipps under a despatch dated November 29, 1838. His lordship"

then enunciated a fundamental rule for working in the meteoro- logical vineyard:

"In- order to make aa -enquiry- of this nature truly useful, it is essential

that the facts' connected with such phenomenon should be collected and arranged over an eptengçd , surface, and that accurate records of them should be kept by persons whose edu- cation and scientific or professional avocations enable them to estimate the value of such records."

It is well to realise that this

awakening to the need to study this ' important " ehvïrbnfnenjsil factor was 19 years prior to the publication in 1857 by the Dutch meteorologist, Buys. Ballot, -of- his discovery of the laws relating to wind movement. Be that as it may, Lord Glenelg suggested that .the cooperation of port and'lighthouse authorities, "and others whose pro-1

fessional pursuits naturally lead, to the observation of atmospheric phenomena" be placed under

tribute.

Response to this, -move -appears to have been both prompt and widespread^ the first to move being Kingston at Adelaide in 1839. he being followed by Wickham at Brisbane and by Franklin in Ho- bart, in 1840. Bat their observa- tions were confined to rain records, sind in the same year rainfall re cords began at Melbourne, Port Macquarie and Sydney. This was an encouraging beginning, even though it took shape more than half a century after the first es- tablishment of white settlement in Australia, but after all it got no

farther than the measurement of rainfall. The first centre to extend to the systematic recording of barometric pressure, rainfall, tem- perature and wind was Hobart in 1841. Melbourne followed in 1854,

then came Adelaide in 1850 and Sydney in 1858, Brisbane in i860 and Perth in 1875. It therefore oc- cupied an overall period of 87 years from the foundation of the colony ere all the States of Aus- tralia had travelled thus far along the road of meteorological re-

search.

The work to now was a purely State matter, and it is remarkable that such unity of purpose should have followed the Glenelg sugges- tion over so wide an area, and through such a diversity of poli- tical control. A sombre touch was given to the birth struggles of this important department- when Gipps, following literally the in- junction of Colonial Secretary Glenelg to "seek persons whose education and scientific or profes- sional avocations enable them to estimate the value of such records," looked for-and found-them among convicts classed as "spec- ials" or gentlemen wrong-doers. This class was not placed upon as- signment or employed at hard labour, nor could any charge be made for their services other than when employed as clerks of any

government department. Observ- ers of this category were employed at Melbourne, Fort Jackson and Port Macquarie as late as 1847.

But thar« were brighter lights, principal among them being Kings- ton, who traced the course of the Torrens and established meteorol- ogy at Adelaide; Franklin, Lieut Governor of Tasmania and subse questly an heroic figure in Arctic exploration, who did likewise for Hobart. Then there was Ellery,

who trained for medicine but turned his attention to science, helped form the Royal Society in Melbourne, and set up meteorology there; Wickham, who com- manded HMS Beagle when she made important coast surveys along the North-west coast of Australia, became police magis- trate at Brisbane and set up there the State's first meteorological units; and Fraser, who as Sur- veyor-General of Western Aus- tralia completed- the meteorologi- cal link at Perth in 1875.

Adoption of the Constitution of the Commonwealth placed meteor- ology under the Government of the Commonwealth. Effect was given to this by The Meteorological Act of 1906. and Mr H. A. Hunt, first Commonwealth Meteorologist, as- sumed charge of his office on Janu- ary 1, 1907. Among the State

i meteorologists during these de-

velopments was Mr C. L. Wragge, who was appointed to that post in Queensland in 1887 which he held until he resigned in 1902. A colour- ful personality. Wragge left datum marks that, rightly or wrongly, were gospel to people of his gen-

eration and are still a tradition 1 among their descendant«.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON THURSDAY, MAY 29, 1947. METEOROLOGICAL BEGINNINGS
snippet: Meteorology in Australia had small beginnings, which were probably based more upon curiosity than with any intent to build up

articleText:
TR* Jvtanfng IBulletta

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, JANUARY 3, 1047.

RUNNING SHORT

Accounts of Christmas shopping, «nth banner headlines proclaiming "orgies of spending'' and record trading figures, give the impres- sion that Australia is a country whose people have more money than they know what to do with. That

there is far too mach loose cash in

the hands of the people is all too true, as is attested by note issue statistics; but there are indications now that it is getting into fewer hands, causing, a growing per- centage of "the population which recently enjoyed comparative af- fluence to feel th« pinch.

An illuminating sidelight on the financial position of the community has just been revealed in Sydney.

The volume of business handled by metropolitan cash order com- panies established an all-time re- cord towards the close of the year,; and the prospect of much more;

business of the same nature : was

indicated by the demand for shares in these companies, all of which are enjoying a brisk sale at ceiling! levels. People who have not been on the books of the cash order com-! panies for years are now returning! to them to arrange credit. They are not out after luxury items; tiie goods they are anxious to buy are essential-furniture, furnish- ings and general clothing.

This is a many-sided question. There can be little question that the return to cash orders is a

Bymptom that the period of lavish spending is coming .to an end ' and that a good many people find them- selves running short bf cash. It is also a reflex.of the mounting cost of goods. The average work ing person cannot afford. to pay cash and is restoring to the time payment facilities offered by the cash order syBtem. Neither of these factors can be regarded with any degree of satisfaction. .Nor are they offset by the claim put forward by some of those engaged

in the busings that an active cash order trade is a sign of good -times, since people would not undertake purchases- on time payment unless they could see" their' .way clearly io meet their obligations. That contention is hardly borne out by the general experience of time pay- ment purchases, which has some- times gone , rather close to being regarded as an evil. The risk to Australia at this juncture, is that

a cash order boom will créât» another avenue of credit, and thereby threaten the Government's efforts to subdue spending and pre- vent inflation. This danger ia ac- centuated by the shortage of good« and the tendency of prices to in-

crease.

Whatever the causes and 'effects, it is unmistakable- that a consider- able section of the community; is running short of nady cash. That was, perhaps, inevitable, human nature being what it is. But it cannot all be laid at the- door of thriftiessness. The frequent stop- pages in industry that have oe

«rorread «ver -«nee the war ended have resulted in aa enormous loss in wages;, andr have, driven many people back, on to their' savings bank accounts and other liquid as seta. Brokers report a tog volume of coaversions>öf war àâvingB certifi- cates and £10 bonds by female fac- tory employees, another sure sign of the need df ready «ash. Wages lost-through'«trikes cannot be made up. If the necessity of having re- connu to their savings brings home to tbs general body -of workers the stupidity of this line of action lt will have done some good.

Generally, the trend in the na- tion's financial position as indi- cated by the cash order boom, the cashing of war bonds and the de- creasing Savings Bank deposit» tiie latter were down . £2,000,000 in September ano! £3,000,000 in October-is a straw in the wind that cannot ix* ignored by anyone.

articleText:
Cfee jitarning bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, JANUARY, 18, 1947.

ABOUT TRANSLATIONS

Whether it is preferable to have one's book pirated or translated has agitated the mind of many authors throughout the ages, and the most that can be said of the two precesses is that the author ha.* no cptjon in the cac»« of the f-.mier, ana if he consents to tue latter.he must be prepared to put up with the consequences. He asks for them. It has been said that the best way to losei the whole atmosphere and purport of a book

is to have it translated into an-

other language, and if any trace of it remains, to have it re-trans- lated into the original tongue.

After all, this is really not sur- prising. The author strives through the wizardry of his mother tongue to infe>v*et in pron linea of words the spasmodic creations of bis brain, fi« starts with an idea ona ends with platoons of words, where the translator starts with. the platoons of words and ends with something that reads like the wrong side of a Turkish tapestry Even discounting the pitfalls and vagaries of the English language, the translator who tries to create in French the impression he got from an English work should take caution as his guide and arrange for sympathetic stretcher bearers at the end of the road. He would also show consideration for human tribulation-not to mention discretion in his own well-being did he await the decease of the author ere he started his fell work.

Maybe because the wella ox human optimism are never dry, the number of people who believe most ardently in their ability to undef

take tais most exacting work is legion, while the- number who have not been overwhelmed with despair at their abyssmal failure is small indeed. There exists no greater fallacy than, that mere knowledge of & fjrretgn language is aU-suffiei ert for successful translations. The first essential is .to, be able to write one's own language, the next is a thorough grip of either the plot if a novel-br the principie» with which the .work deals, and the next is a peoiliar'quality or detachment

which enables'one to write another mair's book and preserve his style and colour. Many translations fail because they end in the book be- coming more a work of the trans- lator than of its author. It is this element, no doubt, which gave rise to' the Italian phrase that transla- tor is another name for traitor.

It is a tribute to the rising stan- dard of literature in British coun- tries* that' the quality of transla- tions from foreign languages into ? English has improved considerably

during the past half century. It abo demonstrates the soundness of the lille that, with very few ex- ceptions, translations should al- ways be into the mother tongue of the. translator. An instance of the latter was the pretty confusion of the French teacher of English at the University at Tunis who invited guests to lunch with:

"Come and take some erubs.** On

being tactfully reminded that sin- gular or plural made a world of difference in the sense of the slang use of the word, grub: "Ah- Of course," she laughed in intense relief. "Your barbarous English. 1 should have said maggot."

But the reverse process is les« happy, and the very heavy demand in Portugal and Spain for trans- lations oí .RmglfoTh works from thal language vastly exceeds the num- ber and quality .of available trans latón. The result has been no lest astonishing to Portuguese anc Spanish readers than it has beer disconcerting to English writers Por instance, the author wrote: "à girl with a face like that coule get away with murder/' but th« translator mystified. Spanish read era with: "A girl with a face Uk« that had to travel -with a murder er." Another gentle character, de scribed by the author as havinj "the run of the village" is depictec to approving Portuguese reader as "drinking all the village's rum.1 Everybody in a country of lighl wines knows the insatiable passioi of the English for rum. Then i translator of technical works sail of a patient whom the author de scribed as "fit only r for Ugh work," that he was "fit only fo work by artificial light." Inade quately did Voltaife say tha translation not only spoiled th beauties of a work but increase) itg errors.

Casting round for remedies ha produced the usual suggestion tha there be set up some tribunal "t examine and .approve translations. This expresses the childish faith i à majority decision, among men bera of' vastly diverse cultural bi liefs and attainments, upon jus

what a French author means whe it comes to be expressed in En¿ i lish. After all, that is a matt« between author and translator, ac not between rival translators. ]

I also points to yet another form < [ censorship, of which most countrii have more: than enough airead and in any case only a very weec culture exists under any form < literary censorship that is n based upon informed, free pub!

opinion. - '

Another inspired thought wi that translators should be ad quately paid, and their rewa should take precedence over th of the author. This presumes th high reward will ensure high qui lty in this important work, whet as it has been found to attra specious mediocrity, even where

did not result in the work "beii obtained on the repute of o translator and farmed out by hi to lesser lights.

The free interchange of thoug ia maybe one of the greatest sal guards against man-made opprc sion, and this is particularly so the case of lmguistically-divid Europe. Hore than one Europe dictator bemoaned the fact, a rightly, too, as lt proved, that 1 p«njit el Britain and VIA han

common tongue, so that if they fall out it will be over basic prin- ciples and not over a misunder- standing. That, alas, is not the happy state between authors and translators, who seem in the con- fusion arising out of a translation of written thought, to be faied to pass as it ware on th« other side «Ot urfeTftOOd,

articleText:
Cïje /Horning bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY, APRIL 17, 1947.

ELECTION ODDITIES

Wei!, the election field got a\ to a straggling start, one wouU Country Party member leav himself, out of the .race and

Barnesite being thrown oft" that« party's band-wagon. The lal will finish the race on foot,

the Returning Officer says that :

he muet.

With most to lose add am

prospects of losing it, moBt nc is coming from the' Labour sta where spavined crocks, handicap] by the political sins of just or third of a century, .and plodd shatters that, - metaphorically never got their head out of

nose-bag, are being curry-coml and groomed to woo the pul fancy on May 3. But public fai is a fleeting thing prone neitl to thrive on a diet of stemmy ch grown on unredeemed promises the past, nor to be dazzled by ni chum gold used to burnish tb of the future. A promise of a pi and shovel job. now-and the sta has little else ta offer--i« a p( substitute fbr the unredeen promise of factory jobs at a number of past elections. .

The chief trainer (Mr Hank has been and gone, and if he c ried away confidence in ] Central Queensland string filli any but the minor placings he li them with none. Indeed, 1 clumsy evasion of vital poii dimmed most of the hopes they ready had, as when questioned the all-absorbing question Communism, Mr Hanlon said:

"Labour has never had anything

do with other organisations exe

industrial unions and the Austral! Labour Party."

Obviously, he had not profit

from the moral contained in t

age-old conflict between the d and hie fleas, a conflict that

self-respecting dog would limit

barking at bis tormentors. IT his part the flea-like the Co:

munist-reckons that if the d does not know when he has a go tenant he (the flea) knowe wh he has a good host. Meanwhi just as a mass meeting of fie would vote unanimously for a co tinuous and unstinted supply

dog, the Communists - who al know their friends - are abroi trying to drum up support for tl flagging Labour stable.

i Mr Larcombe, leader of the C.1

string of dispirited starters, h developed an unsuspected streak . brittle humour. Extolling at Ye poon the' ardency of Labour's d centralising policy he went to tl dairying industry in the Daws« Valley to draw his parable,

seemed odd to him, apparent!, that dairy cows should be fian in rural surroundings and not i Brisbane which Labour's deed tralisation policy has packed wh 71 out of every 100 of Queensland' increased population between 193 and 1944. The subtlety of Mr Lai combe's humour lies in the fae that the average increase of popi lation in Brisbane was -2.55 pe cent per annum, and that for th rest of Queensland was û-47 pe cent per annum! Nor will the haj less Mr Foley thank his Divisiona Trainer for picking hie electorat -which lies largely in Dawsoi Valley - for a demonstration o Labour's decentralisation, becaus there are 1499 fewer electors oi the roll in Normanby for thi election ( than there were thre years ago. Despite this, however Mr Larcombe showed that dair; production had increased out a sight, though' his sorry follower are wondering, no doubt, why h< selected for illustration of hi theme the industry which require the dairyman's wife and childrei to bear a hand so that betweei

the whole of them they may raak« the basic wage for one. His fol lowers know, as does Mr Larcombe that none of them would survivi the attempt to establish a like principle in the Trades Hall.

A strange medley of colour« in

dicates runners from the Franl Barnes Labour Party stable, and a stranger medley of claims charges, denunciations and proies «ions of faith purports to inform electors whence came this stable

and whither it is going. The "of- ficial platform is based on the real Labour principles of the Hon. King O'Malley, Andrew Fisher and Dave Bowman, etc." though the relation of "etc." to either the principles or the mostly ' deported Labour stalwarts is not clear. Further doubt arises out of the leader of this new star on the political firmament announcing, per policy, "It is recognised that the Federal Parliament has control over bank- ing, credit and currency," and his first disciple in this district (Mr Harding) assuring a "Bulletin" correspondent on the 28th ultimo that "monetary reform can be put into action by a sovereign State like Queensland." Both leader and disciple cannot be right. Either a sovereign State has or has not constitutional power to do a cer- tain thing, and nothing short of a civil war or *a change of the con- stitution can get over that. The civil war is most unlikely, but even it might come more Teadily than would permission of the other five States to allow the Constitution of the Commonwealth to be altered so that Mr-Harding might experi- ment on them with Douglas Credit.

Incidentally, selling the Douglas Credit idea is not what it was.

'and with banks cramniorl with, paper money available to tni'Jions of depositors on demand, ii U "ike trying to sell refrigerator spacp at the South Pole. As thev have given up worrying over yhpther the chicken or the egg comes first, so have people ceased puzzling ever which is the greater villain: the man with no confiden-e in his government, his country and himself and so lets his money lie dead in the bank, or the banker who takes care of it. In the 1929-32 ' "man-made" depressions, millions of depositor« throughout Anitra-,

Ha held at immediate rall in ene bank or another £248,000,000 which they were afraid to spend. Douglas Creditors and Labour led the howl against the Common- wealth Bank for refusing to issue a measly £18,000,000 "to end the depression." At the end of Feb- ruary last depositors throughout Australia held at immediate cali the majestic sum of £1,328,100,000, yet Mr Barnes and his cohorts are racing in the "More Credit Purse." The idea of trying to sell credit to folk who could pay off.half of the national debt, when what they want is houses and the like acces- sories of life is worthy of an Op-

penheim opera. If Mr^ Harding! is able to get credence for his1 more money policy in a money sodden land, then we are resigned to the possibility of Mr Larcombe inducing unsuspecting folk to swal- low his decentralisation bed-time story.

1(A. Dunn and F. Rhodes, Morning

Bulletin, Quay Street.)

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1947.

ST CHRISTOPHER'S

Forty-five years ago a preacher in a little church at Benicia, an arsenal, grain-loading city at tje mouth of the Sacramento River near San Francisco, U.S.A., took for his test the theme from the Book of the Prophet Ezekiel : i.e., the story of the dry bones that were made to live. The back- ground to the preacher and pulpit, the towering masts and yards, carrying a tracery of cordage and spars, of a great ship at the load- ing berth, was suggestive of a waiting force to carry the message over tempestuous waters to the uttermost parts of the earth.

Remote as it may seem, there was a distinct link between that preacher and that ship and the preacher at St Christopher's Chapel on Sunday last, where part of the background was a two- stranded wire which carried to Brisbane the audible part of the service and all its implications, there to be converted by the wizardry of science on to a disc that will be flown to America for broadcasting there. Methods have changed, but not the purpose to spread far and wide a spiritual message. The Divine truth came to Ezekiel in ' "the valley that was-full of bones"; that emanat- ing from St Christopher's sprang from amidst a collection of relics which, to but a few moments pre- viously, had been merely inert matter crumbling under the erod- ing fingers of Time. The sub- stance of dead things was different, but the revivifying force was still the same. Years have sped on, but the gospel enunciated by the Prophet Ezekiel, by the name- less preacher in the little church at Benicia 45 years ago, and by Rev. Stewart Lang in St Chris- topher's Chapel two days ago has

altered not at all.

There may be many interpreta- tions, but no changes in enduring truths on which is based the   Christian faith, nor does it matter   greatly what is the interpretation if the enduring truth lies at the end. But there can be many im-

plications which are brought to   life by the faith and constancy of man. It was Ezekiel's faith     which brought a new and wider   life to men who were dead spiri- tually; it will be the spiritual faith of people of all denomina-

tions that will breathe ' life ' into   the Nerimbera relic. Without that spiritual faith St Chris-  

topher's Chapel will disintegrate and mingle with the forest litter; with that faith it can become a place of mental pilgrimage to many thousands of American people who sent their sons and daughters that we might remain free.  

St . Christopher's Chapel is no relic, of U.SJA. army law or organisation, was no part of offi- cial plans for the preparation of America's -sons for an impending ordeal. But it is maybe the most powerful of all mementoes that might have been left as the American armies marched away to carry defeat -to the homeland of the enemy,: because it is in fact a memento of the voluntary spiri- tual preparation made by free men who came to our rescue. Many of those men were about to give their lives, as our men gave-theirs, in the service of the Christian faith. It is thus in two senses a sacred trust that we hold : one

so that our posterity may know the quality - of American service personnel who fought beside that of Australia to beat hack the on- coming Japanese invader ; and one as an earnest to our English speaking American cousins that we share their memories and are 1 not unmindful of their sacrifices.

A succession of like commemor- ative observances, to that held on i Sunday last, will each build up its

section of spiritual remem- brance, and will go forth as an earnest that we in this district do not forget. Making the most of 'our limitations we may do no I more ; and if we are to face un-

afraid the judgement of history

we dare not. do less. .
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON TUESDAY, AUGUST 12, 1947. ST CHRISTOPHER'S
snippet: Forty-five years ago a preacher in a little church at Benicia, an arsenal, grain-loading city at the mouth of the Sacramento River

articleText:
Cfc Corning ÍBoííttín

EOCKHAMPTON,

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 5,

1947.

POPULATION RETURNS

The * population figures for Queensland's provincial centres as revealed by the recent census and just released are full of interest, apart from providing an authentic instrument for the settlement of

future wagers when riyie pride leads to bar-room debates on the ranking of respective cities ' and towns on a population basis.

Bockhampton retains its status as "second city" of Queensland, bot only just. Townsville presses closely/a few hundreds behind, whilst Toowoomba drops a cog into third place, fewer' than 1000 below Townsville. Indeed so clofee to- gether are the three places that in turf parlance it could be described as "a blanket finish." in no case is the increase of a striking nature, but conforms with the generally disappointing growth throughout Australia during the last census period.

Townsville makes the Dest show- ing with an advance of 8000 in- habitants since 1933. Toowoomba

gained 7000 and Rockhampton slightly over 5000. This would not represent much more ~ than our natural increase, plus the few extra workers involved in such undertakings as the sew bridge and the regional electrification in- stallation. Obviously a much. more vigorous industrial expansion is «ailed for if any appreciable growth in Queensland's provincial population is to be expected. It suggests that the decentralisation of industry policies, receiving BO much lip service from politicians and. others, are overdue for imple- mentation.

If one turns to the Coordinator General's annual report, issued at the same time as the population returns, expecting to find the key to Queensland's future -population growth on an accelerated scale, one is likely to encounter disap- pointment. It is true- that there will he found plans for spending tens of millions of pounds on State development, hut the scnemes" ap- pear to be all based on the expec- tation of a slump, or to use the word that is in greater favour to- day, a "recession." This report states that, in addition to its 1946-7 public works programme esti- mated to coet £24*288,508, a sup- plementary^ programme of work' totalling £30,000,000 has been pre- pared "in case of a , recession."

-How is it\that politicians and bureaucrate cannot get out of their heads that Australia is about to

plunge into another depression T By their -constant reiteration of the matter they are gradually in- fecting the public mind with the same idea. Queensland, with its boundless -opportunities for expan- sion in the production pf things which the world needs, should not hear the word depression, for the next 20 years. Yet -in this report of tits Coordinator General there is

[reference to the supplementary £30,000,000 as "a reserve for use in case of greater unemployment through seasonal Blackness or re- cession." "Seasonal slackness" reads like another expression for depressed primary industries.

This is not the kind of thing to inspire confidence that the next census term will be marked by striking advances in population. If Australia is to build up its inhabi- tants to what are considered by political, military and economic authorities to be safe limits, if it ia even to absorb the flow of immi- grants that are now being re- cruited in overseas countries, it must be hy a bold policy of exploit- ing our resources, widening aven- ues of employment, and increasing tile production of primary wealth and consumer goods.

These things will increase the population of Rockhampton, Townsville and Toowoomba, not by the slow, processes of the past but by leaps end bounds. But such ex- pansion can come about only as a result of tile fullest encouragement to individual and collective enter- prise; Perhaps that will not take place until we have got rid of some of the things that today are stifling enterprise, holding back production and. feeding the minds of everyone with the ~ idea that there is no need to work, but if the worst happens and there is another depression like that of the early thirties the Governments have made complete plans for a relief scheme that will take care of all.

The oath to population increase and a higher, standard of. living lies itt the direction of greater en i terprise and harder work, and it is 1 a pity more emphasis is sot laid upon this aspect instead of drool- : ing dolefully -upon recessions and relief schemes. For the regions af-, feçted it becomes largely a matter of self help. If Rockhampton is to retain its place as Queensland's second city at the end of the next

census term it will need to do much more on its own behalf than it has done in the past. Instead of putting on 5000 people in the next thirteen years we should double the population.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON, WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 5, 1947. POPULATION RETURNS
snippet: The population figures for Queensland's provincial centres as revealed by the recent census and just released are full of interest,

articleText:
Oftt j&ormng bulletin

EOCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, NOVEMBER 22.

1847.

TOY TIME

lt seems odd to speak of bard work and headaches.in connexion with toys until, that is, one comee to realise that veritable mountains of them of every kind Lave to t>e invented, tlieir production planned and then put into operation so that at least half of all toys sold throughout the year will "go off" in the ten or so day» immediately before Christmas Day. That simple fact in itself presents a ¡very dif- ficult merchandising problem for the retail store, for not only hare Stocks to be provided in advance, but ' trained salesfolk have to be mobilised to handle this peak busi- ness. Ordinarily in retail selling there are lulls in which lo catch one's breath and fill up the gaps ta used by bursts of buying; but there are few lulls in the build-up to Christmas, and untrained "salea folk accumulate woes for the man- agement -at. compound, interest.

But even that does not go back to- the beginning, which in fact goes back just on ten years to pre- war days, since when there has been little "time for toy-making. For contrary to all traditions as to the mysterious origin of toys that' find their way into stockings hung precariously but trustingly st the foot of the bed,* there has to be a very good assortment of sound, practical brains directing toy production if there is to be any Christmas worth mentioning for anybody-anybody that counts, that is to say. New seasoDs fashions carry vwith^them a man- date which no adult -may ignore, whereas nobody has yet discovered how to sell to a child a toy that

it did not want. The woman who refuses this year's fashions . may ae well don sackcloth right away, but the child that disapproves of the fare in toy-shops still eau fall back on its rag. dolt.

The beginning of Christmas goes back maybè"wïen .mtaths when

manufacturers assemble . tlip . ideas that have «.orné in 'since last year. There are the old faithfuls, of course, dolls, prams, wigwams, knives and the like, without which there could be no Christmas; but every manufacturer hopes for some breath-arresting toy that will carry joy to countless child-hearts. So each manufacturer-who is-- a

specialist in ^certain type» of -toy decides upon his programme, and then about April all manufacturers combine to hold a Toy ' Fair. Thia is not for goggle-eyed chil- dren, but for astute wholesale, and retail buyers who will aplace orders fqr gooda to be sóíd^-in the main -seven months hence.; This) fair gives' to manufacturers an oppor- tunity to get retail toy buyers* opinions regarding the sales pos- sibilities pf the many kinds of toys- bot . the .opinion of millions of 'unconscious children ig still

mnch^pfr A -gamble that will not. be solved until ¡stockings' are un- packed in eight months. " Immed

iatetffia^^yiag tb^Toy Fair man ufaciurers, siatt W*g«aif 3nt0 mass production, peak being reached abont October, after which streams of toys-artfully cased so a« to giye .no hint of the contentsr-frad their way throughout the countless j arteries of commerce to thousands ,of retail shops, there to await the coming of the Great Day.

, Over a century ;ago Froebel enunciated the.doctrine that the

most important part of man's edu- cation is accomplished in the play hour« of the first seven years, but Bot" many people, believed him any more than they accepted his kin* dergarten the first of which he established in 1837. He experienced to the full the lack of honoui accorded to prophets in their own country until after his death, whe» educationalists ali over the world began to see that there might be , wisdom in Froebel's precept that

children learn best by doing. Theil4 next discovery was that their strongest ally ( in implementing] their new idea /was the toy-maker, who in turn had to be reformed from "fragile novelties," which was then the dictionary definition of toys. When toys .had to be handled with extreme care if they were tc survive many play hours, the spirit of toydom was a colour- less, inert thing, and it is not re- markable ' that evolution of the unbreakable doll and the "build your own" toys carried unqualified satisfaction . among millions of very important people.

Notwithstanding this, however, the transition was not a rapid one, in. the main because educators wanted to cram too much of the class-room into the designs, so that manufacturers were often left; with stacks of impractical toye on their shelves. In their turn manu- facturers became suspicious of things tagged educational, and it

was Borne time ere manufacturers and teachers mastered lessons in

adaptability and realised that they

had much in common. Until the outbreak of war many toy manu- facturers engaged noted education- alists and designers, and "high ups" in child education realise that an^ enlightened progressive toy" factory is their. most powerful ally. Nor iß the statesman blind to the propaganda possibilities . in toys, as witnessed in 1937 when ; the war-clouds were rising over Europe and American dolls wore j replicas of the smartest juvenile fashion^ in contrast to the uni

formed dolls of Europe. Santa Claus was backing Washington's neutrality policy. Where German babes played. games with toys based upon military strategy. Uncle Sam's youngsters cut their,

strategic teeth upon games based on crime solving. ,

There are still too many guns and tanks and aircraft carrier» and fighter planes and battleships shaping up to reach millions of stockings on Christmas Eve; but they all meant BO much to civilisa- tion a short time ago, and will Tie hard to eradicate from the plastic j mind of one generation at least.

But the first requisite'of toy sue-, cess still is that it will provide amusement and diversion, and it

is not the fault of the child if we j

continue this long after the cease- fire to teach war in the nursery even while the councils of the

nations strive for peace. v

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON j

WEDNESDAY, MAY 14, 1947. ¡

PRICE EQUILIBRIUM

On October 31 last tue United States abolished 1642 local price control 'boards, more than 10,000 price-control employees went off the public pay roll/ and less than 40 per

cent of USA manufacturers were

left under any kind of control. On December 5 the head of the prices organisation moved out of the third floor of the Empire Building and an ; lanny atomic bomb group moved in.

Canberra comment on this develop- ment was to the effect that atomic power would be needed to keep pace with ascending prices.

But there is more to curbing in- ' nation than throttling the patient, : which is the Canberra specific for

¡this malady. That is to say, there j ? is much to be said for easing the j j safety valve as against sitting on j it. It brings into play more factors that may tend to spread the trouble and 60 disperse it. Sitting on the safety valve not only is a check upon spending, but it throttles pro- duction and piles up unsatisfied wants. It makes goods scarce and' brings joy to the black marketeer. On the other hand, the greatest

check against rising prices is pleni- tude of goods and the black mar- keteer is starved out of existence.

It is not always quite a6 easy as that in practice, because demand for. a wide range of different goods is not always the same, neither is their cost of production nor the manner and cost of their distribu- tion. But in principle USA followed the policy of easing the safety valve, because very many of these conflicting influences and tendencies when brought into the open can- celled oPt each other where under close restriction they remained open, spreading sores. There was for a time, after lifting price con-

trol, more ontcry against rising prices, but there was a diminishing chorus of complaints against lack of commodities. Canberra on the other hand employs ceilings to prevent runaway prices, but the effect is to create bottle-necks blocking other production. In this effort to avoid deflation and give an incentive to labour this process contributed - and still contributes-to wage-price inflation, and in the effort to cush- ion unemployment Canberra has a firm belief in subsidies on not work- ing.

With the lifting of price controls in USA there was an upward rush of prices, when a great many prophets believed their worst fore- cast would be overwhelmed by the rising tide. But the rush ran into full delivery pipe lines of commodi- ties and eager competition, and the price curve started to flatten out. This was intensified by the fact that when towering prices put-one commodity out of reach there w<as always another at lower price to meet the demand. That is not to say that these powerful inflationary conditions, confronting the free countries of the world, always stopped at precisely the right point where things were corrected with- out hurting someone. The move- ment was too vast for exact blue-

print planning, but the simple fact was that ere the end of the year the economic problems of USA were at least within the scope of USA folk to control them. There was no

runaway inflation, and the increase in wages was well above the price

increase.

A joint House-Senate Committee on the Economic Report hag now announced that it is about to in- quire into the prevailing prices for consumer goods and industrial pro- ducts. It has sent out questionnaires to. folk in every walk in life, but in the meantime is looking over some stabilising factors now that price control operates only over rents, rice and sugar. The first of these is the USA Treasury, which is retiring each week about £66, 000,000 of government securities, and is otherwise taking steps to lower the "public debt. That, inci- dentally, is going on too in Australia, there being a drop of £122,000,000 . in the volume of Treasury Bills held at the end of February last as com- pared with the amount a year earlier. Another USA precaution against unstable buying applies to 15 major durable goods ranging from refrigerators to motor cars. On such goods consumers are compelled at the outset to make a cash pay- ment of one-third of the purchase price, and the balance must be paid

off in 15 months.

An even stronger factor is Presi- dent Truman's recent statement

that, having abandoned price control and limited its action to "moral suasion," the Government is en- titled now to look for manufactur- ers and distributors to make a con- tribution by cutting prices. At the same time he said that care had to be taken to avoid a price war which would bring them into con flict with anti-trust laws. He warned them that the alternative would be goods pouring from Amer- ican factories in so great a flow that they would commence to "back up in clearance sales, inventory pile- ups and occasional factory shut- downs" often because high prices kept goods from moving out into consumption. Truman said it is en- couraging that on a higher level of output and prices a peacetime economy had been largely restored after 1$ years of reconversion. Finally, to sweeten generally the

temper of wage-earners and wage-, payers, of consumers and of pro- ducers there is to be a generous tax cut of over £1,000,000/10.

There are many bewildering un- certainties, of course, in which many economic observers delight to enfold themselves. But the Truman administration is making a bold bid for the loyal assistance of the many units which make up the economic whole, and latest advices are that its prospects are good. Tru- man is putting it up to the people, and not forcing on them a blue- print of the unpredictable. In those vital respects the governments at Canberra and Washington are as diverse as the p"les-the latter dealing with living, reasoning people; the former making the first excursion, into a bursaucrstlo dio» tatonhip,
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON WEDNESDAY, MAY 14, 1947. PRICE EQUILIBRIUM
