articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

fiOOKHAMPTON

MAY 23 1947 ....

ATTRACTING SOUTHERN

VISITORS

In order to make Queensland winter playground for southe

visitors the Premier announc

his intention of calling a cont« ence of representatives of loc authorities and sporting bodi as well as other interested orgai sations in the near future. S Hanlon has noted that numero'

southern people already. winter

Queensland and be is sure th we can organise things in such way that thousands more will 1 induced to come north. Alrea( many followers of racing are a tracted to the winter meetinj and he believes that if otb sporting organisations promo their major events during tl winter Queensland could attra an even larger number of visitor

With the general tenor of th approach to something that grov in importance each year thei will be no cavilling, but it wi be hoped that the Premier has

wider conception of the necessity of the case than is here indicate Queensland unquestionably is s attractive spot at this time of tl year to residents of southei States-, and is in the fortunai position of having the main assi to. this condition of .things supplie by Nature at no cost of produ tion and maintenance. That is on glorious winter sunshine, to sa nothing of additional boufliteov. gifts in endless miles of sal bathing beach, well stocked fis! ing grounds and innumerab]

islands that lend themselves t habitation.

But there requires to be som< thing more than the things s lavishly provided by Nature. Ma does not live by bread alone, an the southern holiday maker wi! not enjoy a winter visit to Queeni land if he finds nothing but sui shine and safe bathing beachei Nor will his cup be filled if th most elaborate sporting fixture are scheduled for his beguilement Only last week there was som very terse criticism of the accom modation arranged for a party o interstate tourists who had to sta; overnight in Brisbane on thei way to one of the northern islam resorts. No hot meal awaited them the bed linen was such that the; preferred to sleep in their owl travelling rugs, and they wer<

told there was no one to call then in time to catch the early morn ing plane to take them to theil

destination. This was no "doss house" into which they had chance< by accident, but was the régulai accommodation recommended by th

Tourist Bureau officer who booker them up. This batch of tourists al all events were more concerne* with clean sheets than with addi tional sport fixtures.

Let the Premier convene his con ference hy all means, but it shoulc be open to the widest representa tion, and not confined to Brisbant interests only, since they are un likely to concern themselves wit! anything that is not of benefit tc

the southern resorts. Central anc

North Queensland are as deeplj interested in bringing southerr visitors to the State, more so per haps than Brisbane since thpj have more to offer.' Their problem involves something more than ad ditional sport fixtures. One of thc first things it involves is the de- velopment of roads, so that motor- ists can travel to their holiday resorts with speed and comfort. In that case the Main Roads Com- mission should be given a front seat at the conference. Â second important consideration is that of accommodation, and the licensing, health and other appropriate auth I orities should be there to advise on minimum requirements. If the southern visitor is catered for in these matters he is not likely to complain of any slight inade- quacies in the sport Urogramme.

One thing the proposed confer- ence should do is to wake up Cen- tral and Northern centres to seeing that their own houses are in order. This applies particularly to Rock- hampton. Almost every week we read of parties of schoolboys and others passing through this city either going to or returning from one of the islands in the north.

They have gone there because of the facilities for travel by launch and of accommodation . Off our own coast are numerous islands

equal to any and superior to most, but lacking accommodation for holiday makers, and accessible only at certain states of the tide due to the absence of landing facilities even on the mainland. From time to time the question of a suitable anchorage and land stage crops up, becomes the subject of a report by a Marine Department officer, and then lapses for a further term.

Last week a seven-day tourist coach service was inaugurated between Brisbane and Bundaberg (via Toowoomba), returning via Maryborough and Gympie. AU the points visited realised the com- mercial value of the enterprise and they accorded the visitors civic re- ceptions and showed them every- thing they had, from peanut pilos to cane crushing. Given the roads a tourist coach itiner- ary could be arranged to Rock- hampton, traversing the inland route one way and the coast road on the return trip. A live local tourist body could be already mapping out an itinerary and en- deavouring to interest one of the tourist travel agencies.

In the meantime the import- ant question of the incorporation of the nearby seaside resorts into a Greater Rockhampton in orfler to ensure the early acquisition of electricity, water supply and sewerage is shelved because it is no one's business to take the in- itiative to have the matter de- cided one way or the other. Whilst Central Queensland adopts this

dilatory attitude we will continue to read of tourist parties going north and of conferences being

convened to make South Queens- i land resorts a winter playground I for southern visitors.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MAY 23 1947.... ATTRACTING SOUTHERN VISITORS

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1947

GLADSTONE'S CENTENARY

This is centenary week at Glad- stone. One hundred years ago on Friday last Colonel Barney landed with his staff on Settlement Point,

Facing Island, from the stranded barque Lord Auckland, the swear-

ing in ceremony which created the colony of North Australia and Barney to be Commandant of it

took place, and a Legislative As-

sembly was formed. The colony

   

of North Australia was to include all land north of the 26th parallel of latitude, which parallel runs through Double Island Point and Theebine railway station.

But Gladstone goes back in Australian history much farther than that. It emerged from the list of unknown lands on August 5, 1802, on which day Flinders discovered and entered the port. He had already named Mt Larcom "in compliment to Captain Larcom of the Navy," and he named his new discovery Port Curtis in honour of Admiral Sir Roger Cur- tis who, at the Cape of Good Hope, "had been so attentive to   our wants." He coined a word with which to christen Gatcombe Head, i.e., gat, an opening or gap; and combe, a valley or hollow be- tween two hills. Anyone who has seen it from seaward will agree that the name so bestowed ad- mirably suited the view. Flinders also named Facing Island "which protects it (the port) from the sea;" Ship Hill and South Trees Point, on the last-named of which there stood for many years a tree marked: "M.F. August 5, 1802."

"Excepting that Flinders entered Port Curtis from Keppel Bay via the Narrows a few days after leaving to "prosecute examination of the coast" the solitude of the new port remained unbroken by white men for 19 years. The next visitor was Oxley, sent by Gover- nor Brisbane to explore Moreton Bay and Port Curtis as likely

sites for a new settlement. He arrived in Port Curtis on Novem- ber 5, 1823 "after a tedious pas- sage" and applied himself at

once to examination of the coun-

try, in the course of which he discovered and named the Boyne River, but does not appear to have bestowed any other names that have survived. After 16

days' examination Oxley decided

that:

". . taking it in an extended sense, the country could not afford sub- stance to or supply the means of profitable labour for a large estab- lishment, and even one on the smallest scale."

That report, and his more favour- able one on Moreton Bay, rang down the curtain on Port Curtis

for another 23 years, even though

there persisted an undercurrent of speculation regarding the source of the Boyne River, presumably as to the possibility of it drain- ing good pastoral country.

In December, 1845, Mr W. E. Gladstone became Secretary of State for the Colonies, and at once applied himself to finding some- where to send convicts, as free   settlement was squeezing out the convict settlement in New South Wales and Tasmania. On avail- able reports he selected Port Cur- tis, and chose Colonel George Barney to be commandant of the

new settlement of North Aus-

tralia. Barney arrived at Sydney on September 15, 1846, and pro- ceeded almost immediately to in- spect his kingdom, while the barque Lord Auckland was char- tered at the rate of £1 per ton per calendar month, the charter to operate from November 15.

Ten days earlier Earl Grey, who   had succeeded Gladstone, wrote to Governor Fitzoy instructing abandonment of the project. There  

being neither cable nor wireless in  

those days, the work of preparing

to establish the new settlement

went forward contemporaneously as instructions for its abolition dawdled their leisurely way from London to Sydney. The Lord Auckland sailed from Sydney with Barney and his staff on January 8, 1847, and there being no such things as admiralty charts or channel markings in those days, she ran on a sand-bank at the entrance to Port Curtis on the 25th idem, and it was from here

that the official party landed for the historic ceremony. The Lord Auckland was floated off on Janu- ary 31, and for many years the logs of the improvised grid on   which she was placed for repair

could be seen on the bank of Auckland Creek. On February 26 the barque Thomas Lowry sailed from Port Jackson for Port Cur- tis, carrying several more families of colonists and 50 soldiers.

Establishment of the new settle-   ment quickened interest in the Boyne River and its source, so Surveyor J. C. Burnett was sent overland from Brisbane on March   1 to try to clear up the matter. He failed in his search, and was sent out again in April with no better result than that he reached   the present Burnett and believed it to be the Boyne. On May19,   1847, the Thomas Lowry sailed from Port Curtis with the per-

sonnel of the short-lived adminis- tration. But several signposts re- main. Through the ship Lord Auckland, George Eden, Baron of Auckland, is remembered in Auck- land Creek, Auckland Hill and Auckland Point; Barney Point commemorates Colonel Barney and Gladstone commemorates the name of its founder.

Two months after abandonment of the settlement Burnett left by sea to try to clear up the Boyne- Burnett riddle. He reached and entered Burnett River on July 11,

and in the words of Govenor

Fitzroy he established that the river which he discovered was "not identical with that to which the name of Boyne was given by Surveyor-General Oxley." And so Gladstone became a name long be- fore it became a settled place of authority, but it was the first

place in Queensland outside of   Brisbane to travel even that far

along the road which leads to municipality and the dignities which such state confers.
heading: The morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON SATURDAY, FEBRUARY 1, 1947  GLADSTONES CENTENARY
snippet: This is centenary week at Gladstone. One hundred years ago on Friday last Colonel Barney landed with his stan" on Settlement Point,

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY. JUNE ll, 1947.

SHORTAGES

From day to day newspaper readers have become accustomed tc encounter a growing tale of short- ages, not infrequently relating to commodities of which there should be an abundance in this country Monday waa a typical day. Amal- gamated Textiles had been com- pelled to close down their mille ai Albury, Orange and Goulburn be cause of. inadequate 'supplies oj wooltops-a strange condition fr a country producing the bulk oi the world's best spinning wool Simultaneously came the announce ment of a 20 per cent cut in coal deliveries ordered by the Joint Coal Board, with a consequential drop in output in the metallurgi- cal industries, glass foundries, brick and tile manufacturera and transport, services. This in turn must affect all dependent activities including building, and so on throughout the nation's entire

economic structure.

What arc the causes of these shortages? In the case of wooltops it is attributed to the fact oj higher prices in America taking materials required hy the Austral- ian mille; but with this exception no attempt is made to disguise thc fact that practically every short- age from which Australia is suf- fering can be attributed to strikes, go-slow méthode or embargoes, all designed to reduce output in one way or another. The "Bulletin's" Brisbane correspondent tells ol scores of houses that cannot be oc- cupied because of inability to com" plete the installation of lighting and cooking facilities and the rea- son these things cannot be sup- plied is because of strikes ol moulders and ironworkers .va Queensland and southern States.

No sooner does one set of key workers return to work than another lot goes ont. These men do not themselves suffer much loss ai ?they are able to take easily ac- quired jobs in other industrie» The system of holding up vital in- dustries is the key by which those fostering it apparently hope to break up the present industrial and social system in Australia and substitute for it one modelled on Russian lines. The Governments are well aware of this but are afraid to make any serious move to eradicate the real cause. In fact, «t present they are busy bringing about something that will aggravate rather "than remedy the situation. That is the introduction of a statutory 40-hour week, re- gardless of the industrial tribunals or of the effect on industry gener* ally.

Australia's chief -remedy for fall- ing production ¿nd prevailing shortages appears to be to pay out more and more wages for work that is still not done. When the greatest need in the nation's ship- ping ' industry is the more expédi- ons handling of cargo and a quicker turnround of ships, the best solu- tion offered ia the introduction of

waiting time whereby thousands of pourtia., are paid out to watersid- er* who are not working. The al- ready serious coal position lies under threat of being made im- measurably worse by a complete stoppage at all mmes unless cer- tain shot-firerfi and deputies are paid for a period when their mine was rendered idle by their own

act.

The history of this disputa is worth stating, to show the flimsy pretexts on which the industries of a nation are endangered. With- out any consultation with the mine management the employees at a NSW colliery decided that the shot-firers and deputies would not erect brattice. As a consequence, the mine waa idle from April 21et to May 6th, whereupon the depu- ties demanded payment for the. period they did not work. This was refused, but the matter went to the Industrial Commission and Mr Justice Webb decided that the at- titude of the mine management did not call for review. Following

their usual line when the decision of a properly constituted author* ity does not go their way, the miners threaten a general stop Cge, which must inevitably mean

mstringing all Australian in- dustry.

By way of adding to the general lunacy in industrial affair^ the Waterside Workers Federation, nb doubt feeling elevated at having successfully harassed three .Gov- ernments with the embargo on Dutch shipping to the Netherlands East 'Indies, is making a second essay in the control of Aus- tralia's external trade. According to a message from Sydney the Federation has under consideration a ban on the export of building materials, whilst shortages in Aus- tralia continue. This action is con- templated because 150 tons of gal- vanised iron for Burns "Philp and other concerns are being loaded on ships in Sydney Harbour.

This is in keeping with the general trend in Australia to meet shortages. Higher pay, shorter, hours, payment for idleness, re- strictions, embargoes, commandeer- ing-anything but more work and greater output. Incidentally, it is at this interesting juncture that 20 new branches of the Common- wealth Bank are being established at places in Queensland where there probably already exist ample banking facilities, and where it is most unlikely there is any expan- sion of industry. Viewed from these angles a recent indictment of our

country does not seem to be wide j of the mark: "Politically, finan- cially, industrially, socially and morally Australia ie wandering from the track; if someone does not come to the rescue soon the country will become lost in a great

desert."
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON WEDNESDAY, JUNE l1, 1947. SHORTAGES

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, JUNE 20, 1947.

LAST PHASE

With but two days to go the sands are rapidly running oat for the 1047 Carnival. The uncertain- ties concerning the weather have been resolved and the week prom- ises to end in a blaze of that glori- ous sunshine of which it ia our wont to boast. To be sure th« somewhat prolonged spell of fine weather has an offset in the dust

created by heavy street traffic. A Bmart overnight shower would do the world of good in this matter, but these things cannot be ordered, and it must bc conceded that the City Council Works Department is doing much to ameliorate the

conditions.

Carnival week has entered its

most vital phase for the body to

whom it means most. That is the

Agricultural Society, whose annual

show must earn the revenue neces-

sary to keep the organisation going until the next one comes

round. Attendances thus far have been satisfactory without threat- ening to make fresh records, but it is today and tomorrow that

will tell the tale at the turnstiles.

On these days the neighbouring towns and rural settlements pour in their thousands, suggesting that the Rockhampton Show is a great- er event in the year of district residents than it is even of city folk. Rural residents who do not come to the city excepting at Christmas time manage to get here for the Show. The experience brings something new to the routine of their ' daily lives and they return home with much to

relate and remember. It will be hoped they will not go back with anything of which to complain.

There is one aspect of the Car- nival which could give cause for uneasiness; that is the catering arrangements for casual callers. Under the rationing system no margin is allowed for the demands created by a large influx of visi- to». Some, caterers are far-seeing enough to endeavour to make the necessary arrangement« for in- creased supplies, but not all will go to that trouble, and they have no qualms about announcing that there is "nothing left." To date no complaint has been made that

the facilities for casual meals are

inadequate, but a different experi- ence could be related today and tomorrow when several thousand more people will look to be fed. For the credit of . Rockhampton and for the sake of future carni- vals it is hoped that the hotels and refreshment rooms will strain every effort to meet the demands for meals from country visitors who are-in for the show.

The Rockhampton show means

different things to different people, ; but to the juvenile populace it, means only one thing-that it is ' the greatest event of the year, always excepting Christmas. It was a happy idea, as well as a

shrewd stroke of business on the

part of the society to have a free day for children, for where thc children go there must go the par- ents, to say nothing of the aunts and possibly the uncles. The result is the tremendous crowd that was to be seen

on tile grounds yesterday. Indeed it is getting- eo that whilst the concluding Saturday is the big day for country visitors, most townspeople select Thursday as their day at the show "on account of the children." Thus is the

aggregate attendance' "staggered* BO that the society is no loser and there is less risk of anyone stopping away because of over- crowding.

The show is capable of engen- dering useful thought on the part of elder people. It should not call for any flight of imagination on the part of the Rockhampton citi- {

zen to bring home a realisation j that upon those sleek cattle in the beef and dairy sections his own prosperity is dependent. How many of those employed at the meat- works, the district's largest gingie

avenue of employment, bother to ' visit the cattle pens? Or, if they do, reflect that it is because of the weather-beaten men to be found there, who labour in the improvement of their properties, who lay out their capital in the betterment of their breeds, and who never strike-over lockers or more vital things-that their own highly paid employment' is there to run smoothly if they wish.

Furthermore, it is possible in this good season to see at the show the results when nature is

kind and when man must rely on his own efforts to produce the fruits of the earth. And viewing and comparing these results it

becomes more manifest that the future of Central Queensland's husbandry must largely reside on the application to the Boil of our

water resources.

The show no doubt has short- comings; one would have liked to see more evidence of an advance

in secondary industry These things may come later, and it must be remembered that the war which

disrupted .so many things, includ- ing agricultural ehows, is not quite

two years ended. It takes time to recover lost ground and to re- sume the momentum that leads to expansion. The present show in- dicates that Rockhampton is get- ting back to normal and it should call for a strong excuse for any- one to admit they have not been there on at least one day this week.

articleText:
The Mornipg Bulletin

E0CKBÁMPTON

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 6, 1947

INCENTIVE PAYMENTS

One of the things which en- dangered last week's Industrial Re lations Conference before it as sembled was the suggested "incen tive payments" as a stimulus t< greater production. Prior to tin conference, certain Victoriai unions met and decided that the] were against any plan of thi nature that might - be brough: before the conference by the em plovers' representatives. To saj the least thîfe was a hasty deci sion, and one that could only havi beeu born of prejudice, since the] could have had little, or no know ledge of what the employers in- tended to propose.

flowerer, the conference seemi to have got over any obstacle thai wag created by the Victorian de- cision. . The employers did offer t scheme of incentive payments t< workers on a daily or weekly basL I for higher production, instead o [annual bonuses. This was not re

jected out of hand, but the uñioi delegates promised that' it woul< be considered by the Australiai Council of Trades Unions. If th»

|ACTU gives the matter carefu and impartial consideration, keep- ing in the forefront the end thal is iii view, if might very easily ac cept it without doing violence t< any fundamental union . principle As a fact the miner, the mosl strong-minded bf" all Australiai unionists, is paid under a contract syBtem according to his produc- tion. ' , .

The_ unionist's objection td in centive payment is doubtless based on a traditional fear that it will result .only in increased profits foi the .employers, a tighter grip bj monopolies and, most objectionable feature of aU>/the ..introduction ol "speeding' up" in factories and workshops. Based on " earlier ex- periences such fears may not b« entirely groundless, bat- there should be ' nb" trouble ïn'f introduc- ing adequate safeguards. One.thing certain is .that these objects do not lie behind the present proposals The real-ground for the incentive payment scheme is to provide goods in short supply by the quickest .and cheapest means pos- sible, arid since orthodox methods have failed there is justification for trying some other way.

Objection to incentive payments,

'as a means of ' increasing output, may not reside solely -'with the unions. It is quite likely that many employers, are not in favour of it; These would prefer to allow events to take their course and wait for the incentive to work harder to come from a fear of un- employment, when there is a growing pool of unemployed to draw*" vupon. Perhaps no eurer tansí-of staving.off such, a condi

( n could be. devised than the ac- ceptance of a scheme that will produce, the- -materials - required-for expanding industry. One ' thing that has not been fully grasped, is tfot*]|he~pEeSen^^^ is of a special'and

character.

In the past the welfare of the worker^ has been imperilled by over production. Today he is ex- posed " to _ greater peril - by the shor^tage of materials required by industry. ,"Diecus6ing this -point a prominent Socialist writer in Brit- ain'asserts that "it would be a political blunder of the first . mag-

nitude for British workers to allow themselves to be 6o obsessed by the danger of a crisis bf the traditional kind (overproduction) in the future that they take no steps to overcome the real- economic crisis of a special kind (under- produc- tion) that- is with them today." "The t,same sentiment stands for Australia in its present condition.

In any «vent there is no-call to adopt the incentive payment plan as a permanency. Since Russia set the fashion, economic plans ' cover- ing varying periods of year» have become the vogue in many coun- tries." Incentive payment could be adopted in . Australia as* part of, a Srèê-year pkn. .If at the end of

at time prevailing shortages have been made up and the people are adequately fed, clothed1 and housed, and the slightest symptom of ' overproduction becomes mani- fest, the employers would not de- sire to keep the syBtem going. In- deed it is conceivable that the unions would be the most reluctant to see it abandoned. However, that ls something * for, the future. For the- present the important thing is to see the scheme given a trial.

For that to be done'one thing is vitally essential, and that rests with "the Government. If the em- ployers are to offer incentive pay- ments and the .workers agree to accept the system, there will have to be concessions in the taxation field to ensure that each is re- warded for tho extra effort in-, volved. If it is to be just another! means of "working for Chifley" then little can be hoped from it. Yet seeing the part which thc Government took in the conference at which the proposition was made it is hardly likely that this side of the question was. not thrashed out and some assurance sought^_

articleText:
I %\yt jttoriting bulletin

I ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, OCTOBER 27, 1947.

THE CENSUS

The reaction to the first releas of census figures can scarcely 1 one of jubilation; in fact there

some ground for pessimism. Thej returns relate to the vital matt of population, and it comes almo: as a shock to learn that since tl

last census was taken 14 years a< Australia's population had ßhow the slowest growth on record, wii one exception. Today the' Gommoi wealth can register no more tha seven and a half million people.

The Government Statistician i releasing the figures announci that at the end of June there wei 7,580,820 persons in Australia con pared with 6,629,839 in 1939. Tl increase during this period wt only 14.34 per cent compared wit an increase of 21.97 per cent du ing the shorter period between tl censuses of 1921 and 1933. Tl increase in the 1947 census wf the loweBt of any excepting tha in 1911. The growth of popuh tion since 1933 has been due ai most entirely to the excees c births over' deaths. The naturi ¿¡.crease was 889,677 compare with a gain of 61,314 from nc migration. The migration figure were, of course, affected by si years of war, and one of th brighter features of the report i the improvement in this spliei noted since the end of hostiÛtie: With the resumption of migratio since the war the annual rat of population increase from thi source has risen to 1.88 compare with an average of 1.52 befor the war. This trend is in th right direction, and it should be come more pronounced as trans port to bring in new immigrant

becomes available.

The census permits of a free! examination of the present stat of what is called "the drift t the cities." Apparently it stil goes on. Since 1933 the growth o population in the metropolita) areas has been much greater thai that of the total population, th respective increases being 23.7 for the metropolitan areas com pared with 14.3 in the total pop ulation. That i» not altogethe desirable but the urban increas has not been entirely gained at thi expense of the country, since pro vincial population increased ty

17.97 in the 1947 period as agains"

16.96 per cent in 1933. Anothe noticeable trend that can hardi] be considered as being all for th best is the , preponderance o females in the population increase For the period their numbers ex ceeded that of males by 86,897 thus bringing the number of male: and females in Australia mud closer together. The abnormal in crease in male deaths due to ser vice casualties was a big facto] in this aspect of the census.

Whilst there is no cause for grati- fication at the general return Queensland can derive a good deal

of eatisf~"tion from the advance- ment recorded. The populatioi of this State bas grown from 947,534 in 1933, to 1,106,269 ii 1947, represented by 567,539 malt and 538,730 females. Queensland alao shows the largest increase from immigration and there has been a general rise in the propor- tion of the population in rural areas throughout the State. Bris- bane has made the greatest gain of any capital city.

The main lesson to be derived from the census is the urgency of Australia gaining more population. Seven-and-a-half million people are totally inadequate either to hold or develop this continent. AVhilst it is perfectly true that the native born baby is the best immigrant the requisite numbers will not be achieved by natural increase. The governments are fully seized with the necessity of bringing in immigrants, but there it is not so certain that the tra- ditional opposition of the unions has undergone a radical change, though open antagonism has died down. Moreover, we are badly situated for the reception of mi- grants in the matter of housing."

Even if everything were fav- ourable for their reception it ii questionable whether the migranta of the type desired by Australia will be available. We are inclined to be trifle choosy over the people we will admit. Only the cream of the British population and ex American servicemen with plenty of money to spend here can really count oh a welcome. But Britain wants the cream of her population to help, her out of her own eco- nomic difficulties, and there are indications that American GX's will find conditions better in their own land than on the "new fron- tier." As a consequence we shall have to be content with, and may Oe indeed be glad to get, a suffi- cient number of displaced persons in Europe, which appears to be the only reservoir to draw upon by those countries in need of more population.

The census returns bring home more than anything else could do the really serious problems which confront Australia, and Which have nothing to do with the na- tionalisation and social questions I that are rending the country at

the present moment.

articleText:
(E$e ¿floraina JBttlIetín

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY, DECEMBER ll, 1847.

STOLEN POWER

- In his "Sphere and Duties of Government " Humboldt states that the " grand, the leading principle "

towards which man must ever strive is the absolute and essential importance of "human develop- ment in its richest diversity." He was in fact expressing the ele- ments of Christian belief, which asserts the equal importance ot every individual before God. fie postulated the belief that man is a free and responsible creature pat- terned after, and responsible to God through being possessed of a soul, that he is shaper of his own destiny and architect of his own character. In his progress through the centuries man wrested power from corrupt kings and vested it In Parliaments, making ample safe- guards against the possibility .of the. men he sent there to, represent him assuming the power that hë had stripped from dissolute monarchs.

A form' of government which made possible that human develop- ment in " its richest diversity/' and was proof against the cupidity of opportunists and the greed of materialism, was man's highest achievement ; but at no time in her political history was Aus- tralia farther from that ideal than she is now. Never before were

/politicians so greedy, never before have the tentacles of bureaucracy clutched so avidly at the very foundations of our liberties. The truth of Herbert Spencer's prophecy of upwards of SO years ago is arresting : 1

"The fonction Of Liberalism (In Eng

land) In the past «as that of patting a limit to the sower of kings. The function of true Liberalism In the fu- ture will be that ot potting a limit to the power. or Parliaments."

One elementary principle of. the English form of government is that expenditure must be budgeted, item for item, and carrying forward of unexpended votes or balances was -and still is-strictly prohibited. Hardly a State Labour>Government in Australia but has its nest egg of reserve funds, however, to be spilled in election year, and one of the first steps of the Federal Labour Government was to help itself 'to a Commonwealth Bank to "create" millions of new credit

as required. Little use citizens displaying their lack of confidence in the Curtin and Chifley Govern- ments by not filling war loans, when the politicians turned to the Commonwealth Bank,and got all

tíralian Labour politicians have

shaken themselves clear of the economics of government, and so are no longer the servants of the people. Increased pay for poli- ticians, prospective pensions, ultra' extravagant use of luxurious travel facilities are all outward signs of how Australian, politicians have thrown off this salutary check upon their excesses. f

the chard long^aince in Queensland where, in 1Ô17, 61 per cent of electors voted against abolition of the Legislative Council, whereupon the Labour Government went ahead and abolished it. Even to- day, government in Queensland is hy a minority which holds office through the outrageous manipula- tion of electorates rather than by virtue of the Voice of the people.

But most pronounced of all is the arrogant limitation, by govern- mental decree, of redress against injustice because the ultimate ap- peal to the Crown in person is denied every citizen in eases in- numerable. Queensland Labour politicians started to make laws against which there was no appeal, nor was there an appeal against miscarriage of justice even under these, measures. That is to say, not only might the law itself be unconstitutional, but its adminis- tration might ne faulty, inept or even corrupt, yet the hapless vic- tim had-and has-no appeal. In every Labour-dominated. Govern- ment itt Australia puny, tinny dic- tators innumerable have acclaimed

themselves as above all or any law other than that which they create to clutter up the statute bookB of otherwise free lands, lawg which if challenged would be found to abrogate the elementary fight, arising out of British citizenship, pf even the humblest to carry his plea of justice to the highest tri- bunal* of all.

^ The very existence of that tri Tmnal provides a safeguard against the haste, heedlessness and arbi- trariness of local Courts in small communities "where the restraints of professional opinion are not very strong" and where the Co'irt might fall under the domination "of a judge or judges whose quali- fications are political father than professional, abd whose vagaries might otherwise go unchecked" The ink is barely dry on a Com

znonmealth statute that created Industrial Courts in which the judges make their own ruleB of evidence, and are subject to no uniform rules of procedure. Nor does any "appeal lie against '¿heir judgements t

SoT the vast social and mechani- cal progress of the last century notwithstanding, together with man's greatly increased leisure, man enjoys now leBB actual free- dom «than did his great grand- parents. Slaves who lived in volup- tuous ease were none the less slaves, for freedom i's of the mind and spirit rather than of the Bensep, The elementary principles which are the basis of Christianity, which, in turn, has lifted countless millions of men over 2000 years to a higher moral and spiritual dig- nity, do not spring from lessened

muscular . exertion or increased

money tokens, nor had those fac- tors any part in creating our priceless heritage of literature. Man worked for the salvation of his BOul;.and fought for the right

to call that soul his own. in countless ways today that right is being pilfered, and it makes little difference that t}f¡ pilfering is not being done by. kings Who knew ot no greater freedom, but by Lat »our apostles of a higher liberty .which they preach even as they practice an impudent intolerance based

upon stolen pfawer.

articleText:
Cte morning PuUttin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY JANUARY 28,

THE CYCLONE

The cradle of last week's cyclone which brought enormous relief to portions of parched Queensland was probably quite near to the tomb of America's great aircraft carrier Lexington,

sunk in the battle of the Coral! Sea on May 4-8, 1942. Sprawled

on the ocean floor around her are the shattered frames of seven probably nine - major Japanese warships, and their going also' brought enormous relief to quite a considerable area of Australia. Although the Coral Sea fight be- tween great fleets was the first ocean battle in which surface ships did not exchange a shot, this great man-made storm had its origin in a conflict of national wills and aspirations which is as old as human history; just as there is nothing new in the origin of a cyclone.

After days of sweltering calm with no» friendly winds to carry off the vast amount of heat which ig poured down upon the surface of the ocean, great volumes of heated air expanded and rose to find equilibrium in the ra rifled air above, whereupon the barometric pressure fell within the area and air unexpanded flowed in from outside. The process once started could not stop until something happened tp restore these new 'unstable top-heavy conditions, and as none came along to break np the party some wind-gnomes started a mild flurry on the oily surface of the sullen ocean. Like the detonator which explodes the major charge, this tiny bantling started a wildly-whirling spiral exactly like the whirlwinds that have started up erratically in Rockhampton's streets during the past few- weeks. In essence the two vera alike, and the pattern they wove on ocean or road sur-

face would . bs identical. Viewed I from the outside the wind

I spiralled from left to right like

nie hands of a watch or racing j horses at Callaghan Park and motor hikes at the show grounds. Then are exceptions to this sporting rule of course, bnt none in the case of the cyclone. No man ever saw a cyclone in the southern hemisphere, be it on sea or land, which did not spiral from left to right-or clockwise-just ag nobody in the northern hemi- sphere ever saw one that did not spiral in the opposite direction, from right to lett.

When our friend of last week started on its travels it was any- body's cyclone-anybody, that is to say, in sunbaked Queensland.

terns its normal course, due to the earth's notation and move* ment, would be ' south-west to cross the Queensland coast be-

tween Cairns and Mackay, after which it recurves to south and then south-east, moving off to end its days as it began them: on the bosom of Father Ocean. In this case, however, a southern "high" had its centre south-east ¡from Sydney, and was pushing np fresh to strong south-east winch) along the Queensland coast, and thia "cushioned" off the cyclone so that its course was about south, and it seemed for a time as if it would spend the whole of its life-and waste its .precious ufe-giving water-over the ocean. The best explanation of this "cushioning off" is to take for example a swarm of bees. The rate of flight of each individual insect is very high, but the movement of the whole swarm is

erratic and. wmparatively, slow. The only difference is that while none could foretell the course of * -f?*1?1 of bees» a k Possible, with knowledge of contending pressure systems, to forecast the track of a cyclone.

Keeping in mind the dock-wise au- movement at the «round or

ocean surface it is easy to see that, giving the whole cyclone system a southerly movement, the wind in the forward right-hand quadrant of the system will he south-east. This is the only, oc- casion in Queensland when a south-east wind is experienced on a low or falling barometer, the cyclone being of course a low pressure system, while the ordin- ary south-east wind is the child of the boisterous high pressure systems which surge up from the great Southern Ocean. That is how it came that on Wednesday last Rockhampton opened the day with a strong south-east wind and a high barometer and finished, it with a strong, gusty south-east wind and a falling barometer. Il was a perfect example of conflict between two diametrically oppo- site wind systems, one of the main characteristics of which-the south-east wind-was the same in both in the conditions as the} affected this city.

By notr it had become a ques- tion of the relative strength o conflicting forces, and while tb cyclone was shouldered off an made a southerly instead of i south-west course, we know tha it prevailed and crossed the coas just north of Brisbane. While th benefits it brought would hav been welcomed in every part o the State, it has to be concede that it could not well have falle more propitiously. The are which received so liberal a drencl ing is the main food producto portion of tile State, and tl prospect of being spared furthi dépendance upon Tasmanian pot« toes, that must run the gauntli of several hostile waterfronts, indeed welcome.

Peculiarly enough, the impre sion gained from most broadcas and many Press messages w. that the cyclone brought notbii but devastation. Of the wondc fully improved agricultural a: dairying prospects that sprang i in the wake of the watery visita

little is heard. It came too early for some and too late for others

an ungracious response to prayers that men and women had breathed, and in unrelieved parts of tho State are still breathing, with

deas fervour.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON TUESDAY JANUARY 28, 1947 THE CYCLONE
snippet: The cradle of last week's cyclone which brought enormous relief to portions of parched Queensland was probably quite

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY. JULY 15, 1947. CANBERRA CHRONICLE

Bankrupt in political courag Canberra is a whale on superb tives. Not long ago it told i in startled tones that the pop lation was the highest ever, as

such a development in a hal empty continent was hitherto h yond human imagination. Bi even that did not prevent our i Calwell roaming among the falk birth-rates in devastated Euro] in an effort to obtain a fe

immigrants to come and he] develop undamaged Austral! During the war it was trumpet« that we were to build whole fleej of ships for the transport of gooo from Australia. to a stricke

world,: yet Mr. Calwell is couplii his quest for stray tourists wit that for an odd ship or so to brin them here. Our war factor« were to turn out every conceit able kind of implement for uf in peace, yet the clarion call wei

out «from Canberra to U.fi.A. fe 10,000 tractors, and that at.

time when every" allied war fae tory was working at top pressui to supply invasion troops "i , Europe. It' was about this tim«

too when Sear-Admiral Keyes re vealed that H.M.A.S. Hobart ha been .under repairs in Australia dockyard hands for 18 months a a time of desperate shortage "c

Allied naval units ! '

.Just recently Canberra an nounced, flamboyantly, tba Australia's 1936-7 oversea trad

was "likely to be the best o¡ record." That was for consumí tion in the electorates, where i could be told that if commoditie were short it was because the; were being exported to barasse* Britain. But they said nothinj about the spectacular flights ii export prices which govern 'tb bill that Britain must pay, ant they make no reference ti volume of goods as evidence o the extent to which we are- really putting our shoulder to the wheel But taking into account th< urgency of the times, and om increased population since 1930, thi showing is far :frbm creditable One line of excuse ' for the pool showing is the shortage of anips to which our critics reply that f takes nearly twice as many ship] now to handle the same volume o' cargo as was required in pre-wai days. The slow turn ronnel ol overseas ships in Australian port) ie in fact ,one of the major post- war scandals, but Canberra repliei By turning thc other cheek-th« taxpayers'-and by bribing th« watersiders to be good. The cosí bf 'that,is an all-time unheralded high-all met by. subsidies mel by the taxpayer, which .fact, ie also 'tttiheiraïdeVL ? "

Compared with 1939-far from a good year-i-beef exports for the il months to last May were down

by. 31*400,000 ; Uv " of meat and

87&«rj0lKr tb? of . Wtter. ^Export prices in, 1947 are nearly treble those for 1939, so that the £223, 910,000 worth of exports today would be Worth only £80,610,000 in 1939. On the other hand, import prices, more than doubled-, BO that the £166,510,000 worth -Of-imports, in 1947 would be worth only : : ^T4Ä30,000 in 1939; but nobocry wornd -expect the Canberra braggarts to tell, us that. In re-

lation to the eleven months of last year imports to the end of May were up by 16 per cent'.and import .prfc^ea-'jby 12.5 ..per cent; while, .exports ; were np by 54 < per cent and export prices were up by 47 per cent. . That is to say, for the same volume of goods for which we paid Britain £100 last year we would pay her £112/10/ this year; and for the same volume of goods for which she paid, us £100 last year she has now to pay £1471 Her shipping

investment also earns less because we hold her ships idling in Aus- tralian ports far longer than we

did before the Curt ins and Chif leys started to carve the way to the latter's Golden^Age. In this way are the noisy folk at Can: berra aiding Britain in her des- perate plight. Outside repercus- sions to this Canberra fantasia is to be found in New York, where Brisbane's Lord Mayor (Alderman Chandler) is sheltering pending the clearing of the financial weather in hopes that he may pick np a sinai! loan for his dis- tressed, war-worn «city. He has for company the remnants of the drooping ' £11,000,000 Austra-

lian .conversion issued in New York on June 16 with-much shout- ing and acclamation at '974 per cent, the last report' regarding which was that the underwriters wene beginning to look uneasy, though the most ominous sign is that Canberra boosters are silent.;

Internally, we have to be told fairly consistently'how well off we are but even- that fails when

we try to. buy something. Bank' j clearings this year are up 55 per

cent on last; but that is whittled

'down by soaring prices for most

things other than , bread and butter and potatoes. We are assured that retail prices are up by a bare 3 p?r cent, but that takes no ac- count of clothes, fruit and vege- tables, though nobody has yet devised a means by which to go without any of them and remain healthy-and decent. The gross earnings of all railways are down -on last year, and. this despite the fact that there, have been freight and fares increases, with pros- pects ,of more to follow. What is more, Mr Chifley has taken to croaking of an approaching de- pression, in which the« Commun- ists-always happy to herald woe -support him with enthusiasm.

If^ depression there be. ,it will be in spite of a vast amount of work to be done, oceans of money to pay for it, armies of men to do it and other armies of eager folk waiting to buy and pay for the proceeds. It takes a high order of fumbling inutility to make a loss on robbing a mint, but Can- berra lads appear to be making a brave show of doing it.

articleText:
Et* ¿ttormna PttIIeNn

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, NOVEMBER 26,

1947.

PETROL SCARE

With the approach of Christ- mastide we have grown accus- tomed to official warnings of im-

pending shortages of things likely to be most in demand at that season, warnings that have been most helpful to the black marketer, änd to möre law-abiding citizens who realise that to do the fair thing by their families they had better bestir themselves and see what can be done on the lines of the lay-by system. Whilst these measures may be sufficient to meet, ás far as is possible, any threat- ened famine in'häms and bottled béer, in the casevof petrol the car owner needs no official reminding that if he is to command, sufficient

fuel to 'do the extra running round involvèd in the holiday season, es- pecially if he contemplâtes trans-! porting his family some distance from home, he has to start build- ing up his stocks before the official mind comes to bear on the subject. To all but those responsible for the administration of the liquid fuel regulations this sufficiently explains the extraordinary sales of petrol in September and' October which appears to have caused some alarm, extending even to the Prime Minister.

Whether the high September and October sales are the sole cause of the official petrol panic caw not* bs said, but the position is considered serious enough to call for a public statement from the Prime Minister, who has announced new administrative measures to reduce what he calls "illicit" petrol consumption. As a first measure . towards stamping out breaches of the liquid fuel regula- tions, petrol coupons will in future require to be drawn by consumers from permanent issuing offices, which will include Post Offices, the Pott Office frotó which the con-

sumer draws his December ration ; will be regarded as his permanent \ issuing office. OnIyv for changes of residence, or for* other good rea- sons, will consumers be allowed to transfer their licences 'from one depot to another, but they may surrender their coupons and pur- chase their petrol at any garage they desire. No January tickets

will be issued in December.

Mr Chifley, falling back on the September and October' sales, con- siders they show clearly that''the quantity of petrol being used is in excess of 'licensed gallonage, and warns that excess of petrol used over the coupons available must inevitably endanger the national position for petrol supply and the movement of essential transport become jeopardised: Dollar ex-

change and & general world short-" age of oil are basie reasons for Australia,1» need to conserte liquid faeL but excessive consump- tion ls being put forward as the main ground for the present action.

The point that emerges - most clearly is the determination to clamp down on interstate car travel during -the holiday period. ; Whether this will apply to Fed-

eral Ministers, returning . from1 overseas, who require government j oars to be dispatched hundreds of miles to pick up their luggage,

which could quite as easily be ' transported by rail, it might not do to enquire into too closely. The tightening up of regulations re- garding the issue of tickets will go some distance in discouraging in-, terstate journeyings, although even in the most critical days of the war there was never any diffi- culty about getting petrol, tickets by those who knew the ropes. A more effective measure will be the ; cutting down of quotas to garages.

Already filling station proprietors declare that they have no more

than a sufficient allowance to serve regular customers. Within a month it is predicted that there will be plenty of petrol ticket« but no petrol.

A certain amount of sympathy can be felt for private motoriste who are singled ont for special taxation but are allowed little pleasure or satisfaction from being a car-owner. Seeing that the coun- try is no longer /at war and there is no need to build up reserves for that purpose, it should not be too rquch to expect that the manipula- tion of Australia's petrol stocks might have been well enough man- aged for the car owner desiring to make use of his vehicle during the holiday season, to be allowed a little more generous treatment. Of course, if he himself has prevented that by the purchases in September and October which have inspired the present official action, then he has helped fashion a rod for his

own shoulders. ' Some hint -of the ; extent of these purchases was ]

conveyed in the Federal -Parliament recently, whop it was stated that so much petrol was stored in pri- vate garages and onthouses that

it constituted a menace to towns j

and cities in.case of fire.

It is, perhaps, not beyond the bounds of possibility that this sud den alarm at the petrol position on the eve of ' the holiday season has behind it a wish tö divert to the railways and languishing gov- ernment airlines the very remun- erative passenger traffic that will be on the move for the next month or six weeks. By the time the Jan- uary tickets are issued on the 6th of that month, it will be no sur- prise to discover that the. petrol position has improved just as sud- denly as it deteriorated, and that Mr Chifley's worst fears of the movement of essential transport being jeopardised will not materai

ise. One thing certain is that people ' who travel far from home during the holidays in the expectation that they will somehow be able to get hold of sufficient petrol to bring them home will be taking a risk, j

articleText:
Ofct jflormng $nUet.n 1

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY," DECEMBER 4, 1947.

CANBERRA CAPERS.

On Sunday evening, 23rd ultimo, Australians- were inspired in the A.B.C. Guest of Honour session by hearing a strange voice-none other than that of their wandering Attorney-General, Dr H. V. Evatt.

It described - with becoming modesty - how Australia stood the

rest of the nations to attention, and then told them where they both got on and off. Three days later- an ecstatic New York message told us of "the World Citizen of ths Month" who, finding nothing more on this planet to tidy np, was leaving for home. That, too, was Dr Evatt, who, said the fervid splurge, left New York unsung by citizens any more discriminating of the. status of "world" citizenship than "a large gathering of Aus- tralian officials," including our own Messrs Forde and Makin.

But'the most astonishing aspect of it all was that it should have been deemed necessary to en- lighten Australian citizens regard- ing what was being contemplated or done abroad in their name. If anything has stood out more clear- ly than the intolerance and bluster of Australia's foreign policy under Labour, it was that the Aus- tralian people were the last to be

consulted on informed thereanent.

Then there came the wild sug- gestion that Dr Evatt might don silk to lead .the bank case for thc Government in the High Court: but that was merejdte flying. Quite apart from its impropriety, even the Chifley Government is likely to shy off its Attorney-General leading its defence before a Bench that has been the long-suffering target i of Labour play-boys. Ap- pearances are, however, that the kite-flying has been to sustain the drooping Chifley Government pres- tige abroad, and to infuse fresh courage in the bewildered Labour lads at Canberra. Both are badly needed, and if Dr Evatt cóuld help to that end and at the same time placate his own well-developed vanity, his aid is assured.

That Dr Evatt needs any such" bolstering on his own account is unlikely, for-even, though he is Deputy Prime Minister, and will probably occupy the throne while Mr Chifley is warming his feet at New Zealand's hot springs, the returning wanderer is reputedly scanning more-distant and brighter-horizons than those offered by a discredited Australian Labour Party. What-

soever else his attributes Dr Evatt is no leader of lost causes. Labour bas already lost two referendums sponsored by him and is faced with the fight of its life over a Banking Act or 60 clauses that the -Canberra Brains Trust is reputed to hav* built up, from the Bill <>f six clausas which he left. He is, therefore, in a position now to say that his six

¿janse Bill was watertight and fool- proof. Nor is he likely to sponsor the referendum on price-fixing that is to be held early next year, there

being te^4t^j^»f^ than Dr

Evatt td Bee, from the temper of the people as revealed in Victoria, that there is an odds-on chance of being lost.

- Finally there is not much in hoing' deputy to a Prime Minister whose Government stands a first class chance of being mangled at Joegrt election, and Dr Evatt aspires to no cross of martyrdom on the Opposition Benches. Hence it is that if .Dr Evatt is being recalled to Australia to fill the role of scapegoat, some of Canberra's brightest intellect« are liable to get a shock. What they are unable to realise is 'that a Government which is discrediting itself, at the rats that the Chifley Government seems intent upon doing, offers, little to a man of Evatt's qualifications, howsoever strenuously the party boneheads may scramble for th**

sweets of office.

A straw in the wind was Evatt'i recent'righteous disclaimer that all to come out of Moscow is not evil, which might be remembered grate- fully by Russia 'when the vote is being cast next year to replace Trygye Lye a* Secretary-General of the United Nations' organisation. Notwithstanding Australia main- taining costly legations and con- sulates in countries which, do not exchange with her a barrow-load of trade his championship of thc small nations did not deter their

voting him out of the presidency of the United Nations' Assembly this year/so that a "smile ifrom Moscow at -the right time may prosper his fondest hopes. On the other hand, Brother Vyshinsky is unlikely to waste a vote on a candidate from the wrong side of

the Iron Curtain. \

Meanwhile, bidding for Cbifiey's shoes warms up as Evatt's stocks in the party room sag under tho stimulus of propaganda based upon his absence from the Throne Boom When the Big Bad Banks started their huffing -and puffing. Opinions

vary as to whether the shoes will

become vacant through their pre- sent wearer going upstairs to thc job of Governor of the Common- wealth Bank, or.because he "pulled I on" a "strong-man" fight with the banks which electors have taken out of his hands and are ready and horribly willing to chase Labour into the Opposition wilderness. Labour does not want single-handed Strong men nor does it want clever men. It wants "yes-men" who do not get too far ahead of the team, and men with no intellect above Caucus level. It reckons that Chif- ley ventured too far on a diminish- ing Labour status, and also that Evatt knows more than is good for Caucus. "To date, the most ardent bidder is Speaker Rosevear, who on several occasions has des- cended from the Chair to tell the banks from the floor Of the House what he thought of them-not that jt mattered^ what the banks thought of his views, but it was important to get them before rank and filers with an influence in Caucus. That can be explained, out not necessarily excused, In a House where the Government has a microscopic majority.

In the background the three "Tory" State Governments are preparing to assail the Chifley Gov- ernment on finance, with special regard 'to the Federal Govern- ment's flair for doing the lion's share' of taxing and holding the purse strings. The Tories have ?probably been looking at Sec 81 of the Constitution of the Com- monwealth, which provides that all revenues or monies raised or re stired by tbs E*eçufive Çounçil of

the Commonwealth are to form one Consolidated Revenue Fund "to be appropriated for the purposes of the Commonwealth." That is to say. it was the clear intention of framers of .the Constitution thar, the Commonwealth should have power to tax only for the purposes of the Commonwealth. That snag could be changed only by refer- endum, and next to an election nothing causes Canberra Labour to shy more violently than the pros- pect of a referendum.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, MAY 24, 1947.

THIS EMPIRE

Homing Royalty received the other day no less tumultuous a welcome in London where in 1048 the English people beheaded a king, than they had received a few days earlier at Portsmouth where in 1757 they shot an admiral. They lopped'off the head of Charles I as a sequel to his losing a fight with the Parliament of the people, and Admiral Byng provided first blood to the law that provided the same punishment to all ranks for shirking battle with the enemy. No king has been beheaded since Charles for flouting the wishes of the people, but they sent one pack- ing in 1936 on that very account.

These reflections are induced by the fact that today is Empire Day. Conceived just 50 years ago by a Canadian woman in Ontaria, and promulgated with immense labour by an ardent Irishman (Lord Meath) Empire Day is intended to commemorate or emphasise an em- pire held together by invisible threads which baffle the foreigner in time of peace and stagger him in time of war. Not only did

Iiord Meath discover that the black- est ignorance regarding the British Empire prevailed at the heart of that Empire, but Lord Elton has shown that malevolent foreign and ignorant British politicians are

acclaimed nowhere more consist-

ently than in Britain when malign- ing the Empire's greatest achieve-

ments.

Time was, of course, when even well-informed British folk believed

that. Great Britain possessed the British Empire. Many of our American servi cernen cousins who came to our succour believed that, and quite a lot of Australian peo-

ple who should know better still ' believe it. That came about

through Great Britain being the j head of an Empire of subject j States all on the road to self-gov- ' ernment, but in different stages to- wards that desirable end. By im-

perceptible stages ' the leading; strings disappeared and the Domin- ions of Australia, Canada, 'New. Zealand and South Africa became "autonomous communities within

the British Empire, equal in status, though united by a common allegiance to the Crown." It is time now, therefore, to take fresh stock of the Empire of 50 years ago when Great Britain stood at the head of a staggering variety of races, colours and creeds, in the

only League of Nations which has

ever worked-a world-wide Com- j

raonwealth which has banished war

from within its borders, within j which dwells one-third of the human race. It is more correct now to say that Great Britain is one member only of a great associa- tion of free nations and dependen- cies, with special responsibilities to the latter and equality with the

fenner.

During the century, when an un- challengeable British ííavy gave it world predominance, the British Empire gave the people of the world the only century without a war since the age of the Antonine Emperors of Rome. The whole string of would-be world dictators, from Alexander to Hitler, would have swamped the world in blood to obtain a world dominance that the .British Empire had for 100 years, and used only to build up

enramunities of free men.

There can be little doubt that the secret of the Empire's vitality is the very looseness of the ties which hold it together. Had it been mandatory to teach school children the rudiments of Empire history-as other nations would have done-or if it had been drummed into them that the Brit- ish Empire is the most fruitful political 'achievement in history, they may have become self-con- scious and that elusive quality that, for 300 years, has kept the Empire alive and constantly evolv- ing, might have evaporated into thin air. Yet it is worth recal- ling that, as the age of natior^; is counted, the four great British Do- minions were but the other day primitive colonies strictly adminis- tered from London; yet today they are great modern communities, ] each as completely self-governing as is Great Britain. That, in it- self, is one of the greatest politi- cal achievements in history.

When pessimism as to the future of the British Empire sits en

j throned, it is well to remember ! with what glee its enemies saw in

the falling away of the four Do-

minions the dismemberment of the parent body. They are croaking now that Britain's shortage of food, of foreign exchange, of man- power and of life's amenities fore- tell her early end. They should by now know better, but unable as they obviously are to appreciate the amazing phenomenon of an

association between nations be-

coming stronger in proportion as the legal or constitutional ties be- came weaker, they miss the main recuperative ; powers of the British Empire. Its units can and do work together because they have worked together.

His Majesty the King told a London audience that the people of South' AiHca-.the only one of her!

Dominions with which Great Bri- tain went to War-¿"are convinced

that Britain's mission in the world has not ended, but that it is only entering upon a new phase," which brings us back to where we began. The hard-pressed, ill-fed and ill dressed people of Portsmouth where they shot an admiral and those of London where they be- headed a king gare tumultuous welcome to their Majesties and the Princesses because, as a working woman in a Ludgate Hill bus said of the abdicating Edward, "Arter all; a king is king not of land' and water, but of living folk and their

ideals." «*
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON SATURDAY, MAY 24, 1947. THIS EMPIRE

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, APRIL 25, 1947.

ANZAC DAY

Ho stronger "testimony to tîie fact that "time marches on" could be adduced thau that today we commemorate ; the thirty-second anniversary o'f the Gallipoli Land- ing. ? It* is true the ranks of the Aflzacs .have thinned perceptibly, but there still remain a majority of Australians ' who have personal recollection of. the ' events which brought pride and. sadness to so many' homes and gaye birth to Australia's .manhoods ïhere is no putting back either, clpck or calen- dar... ; -

From-the beginning Anzac Day oratory has exhorted each succeed- ing generation, ;t» prove worthy of

the. sacrifices.:made for them on this day. Whether or not they have proved their worthiness, on one point there can .be no ques- tioning-pride in the. valour of their fighting men has always been strong with the Australian people and hits grown with the years. That is "something on the credit side in an age when reverence and dignity have been removed from most things, and all thought ap- pears to be for sport, pleasure and material advantages.

In the early years many stiff battles, were fought over the form of observing . Anzac Day, but today there are few, if any, who would change the form of solemn observ- ance which it has assumed. Anzac Day more than any other is one to invite reflection upon individual re- sponsibilities towards the nation, and indeed such reflection may be indulged in to a greater degree than is apparent on the surface. Heaven knows there is room for

it. Superficially there may appear i to be litle change in the life and habits of Australia compared with the time when -pur men -marched off to the first World War; but if the spirits of Gallipoli heroes could revisit the land for which they gave their lives they would be amazed, and possibly appalled, at the changes that have taken place in many things.

? Thirty-two years is a goodly slice out of the lifetime of a man almost half of the allotted span. The veterans of the first World War still comprise a numerous company and carry themselves well, even if the step is less springy, and Masefield would not find it so easy to recognise those in whose stature and bearing on the beaches at Gallipoli he saw the likeness of the Greek gods of old. All with whom time has dealt kindly, to permit taking part in today's memorial parade have de- rived one legacy from the wai which becomes enriched with ead passing year-that is the friend- ship and association with former comrades-in-arms, an association that, as nothing else could do must give warmth to^ these latei years. Hence it is that the pre serration of Anzac Day is heit most dearly by the older genera-

tion. " ' ?

There is much , to be pondered ot this Anzac Day, not so much ii the glories of the past as the dan gers of the future. In paying homage to the magnificent physiqw of the fighting men of Anzac it ii fitting to inquire whether thc same standards prevail. It mus be admitted that there is no littli evidence to the contrary, much o it derived from the medical record of the recent war when Ute pei centage of sub-standard recruit was alarmingly high. The "six-foo Australian" waB shown to be 91 per cent myth, since only " 10 pe cent of those paraded measured

ft and over, whilst the genera state of health was far from satis factory. The drift to the citie and the growth of factory employ ment have developed a new type c Australian who, in some respect! is smarter than his country cous i but has not the physical resource of the rangy bushman. The cit; type is a watcher .of games rathe than a player, and his develepmei is one of the main reasons for tl attention which 'the government and health authorities feel in polled to give to dietary and ph; sical fitness training.

The uppermost thought of tl patriotic Australian citizen toda is not so much required to be coi centra ted upon our potential f< repelling possible dangers fro without, as to our capacity i meet the challenge to the nation security fram the insidious worl inge of elements within. The would be more assurance of the dangers being countered if

stronger trend could be noted t wards the assertion of citizen rights and less acquiescence in b ing "pushed around'' in so mai ways. A little more of the Anz spirit in the every-day affairs < life is wHat Australia needs mc at this juncture, and its asserti would be the best means of ho ouring the men whose memory preserved on this National day.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON FRIDAY, APRIL 25, 1947. ANZAC DAY

articleText:
Cfee morning ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY. MARCH 5, 1947.

WELL SATISFIED

The delegates to the State ] our-in-Politics Convention who 1 just returned to Brisbane-ha travelled comfortably both way special trains provided by an ol ing Ballway Department-expre great satisfaction at the succès the Convention. The business, 1 said, was completed most ss . factorily and had "given ac cause for confidence in the outc of the election"-soon to be i Delegates added that the "free« of discussions" was largely resp sible for the big achievements. What are these big achievemt that give ALP delegates such i isfaction and assurance as rega the coming election ? From limited allowance of the free

cussion that has been made av( able to the public the first

j most important appears to h

I been the back-down of the Pren

and his Cabinet on the recen passed Industrial Arbitration 1 in that instead of leaving to properly constituted tribunal

matters relating to hours, wa and conditions of Queensland

dustry, the Premier has promi to include the 40-hour week in policy speech, as one of the lej lative enactments to be effected the Government if returned.

Another "achievement" of

Convention was to secure a prom

I from the Government to amend i

law governing Local Author elections, in order to revert to 1 ward system in City Councils. 1 present system, liereby the wh of the enfranchised voters in a loi authority area are privileged

vote for candidates on their mer and without consideration of poli j cal ties, has apparently not work j out satisfactorily from the point

view of the Labour machine, ho ever beneficial it may have prov to the city or town in question, a however satisfactory to the co: munity as a whole. Hence, in ord to give Labour a better chance th want the wards back, wherei "safe seats" can be carved out ; in the wider sphere of State ai

Federal electorates.

Never was a more retrogra« step proposed in respect of Queen land Looa! Authority matters, ai there has been no more shamelei acknowledgement of the means I which the Labour machine achiev* and maintains power in this oom try. It has been shown more tha once that, in the political sph«r Labour Governments have been r turned on a minority vote of tl whole electorate, and invariabl they secure a Parliamentary rep« sentation out of all proportion 1 the aggregate vote cast. They wai now to apply the same methods i the local authority sphere, and th

Government has surrendered.

On the same day which pro claimed the delegates' eatisfactio with the doings at the Labour Coi vention there appeared in the now several items calculated to leav anything but a feeling of satisfac tion with the people who did no happen to be delegates to the con vention, and even amongst thos weighty fortunate ones, preoccupiei with more weighty matters, i might have caused some distur bance of thought.

One waB a declaration from thi dairymen of North Queensland-th« same region where Queenslan« Ministers and Labour delegates re- solved the 40-hour week and th« return to the ward system-thal unless they secured a subsidy thej must cease producing milk withii a matter of weeks. Simultaneously the bakers of Rockhampton pub- lished audited balance sheets tc prove losses under the present price of delivered bread, and nam- ing a date when all bread must be collected at the bakehouse as an alternative to getting no bread at

all.

An even more disturbing item was a report of the Australian Rural Industries' Commission pointing out the alarming prospect before Australia's primary indus- tries in view of the imminent breakdown of British preference for Empire products. Wool, wheat, dairy products, dried fruits, wines, meat, sugar-in fact practically everything upon which Austrlia's present and future prosperity de- pends-is affected.

To no part of Australia is this development of greater concern than Queensland. Yet, whilst the danger grows, and warning voices point to the urgency of Australia seeking other markets and ensuring by every possible means that noth- ing shall be allowed to step in and prevent them being supplied, the Queensland Labour Convention, which virtually is the Government, devotes itself to the 40-hour week, tinkering with the municial fran- chise and other matters designed to make them secure at the polls.
