articleText:
Ctje fHomíng bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1&47.

BEDTIME STORY

Australia's Ambassador at Wash- ington (Mr Makin) has been telling the people of the United States some bedtime stories about Aus- tralia, stories which are not cal- culated to make them any better informed as to the true character of tiiis country. Indeed, if the re- mainder, of his speeches are in keeping with the one under review he must be providing Americans with a more misleading picture than many of them had when they imagined the inhabitants of "Down Under" consisted mainly of kan- garoos, savages and poor whites of the convict class groaning under the heel of the British monarchy.

Mr Makin makes out the strong- est possible case against the ap- pointment of politicians as spokes- men for Australia in other lands. If the half dozen or so defeated Labour candidates recently ap- pointed overseas are doing the same class of work as our Ambassador in the United States, the sooner they are recalled the better, in view of Australia's quest for overseas mi- grants, and the need for migration to be based on a true knowledge of conditions in this country.

But to return to Mr Makin»8 bedtime story. In a speech at Rich- mond, Virginia, on March 19, he

declared that there was no indus- trial dislocation in Australia; that the operation of the Arbitration Court substantially contributed to the "splendid results" of Aus- tralia's wartime and post-war econ- omy. In no part of the -world, he said, was the trades union move- ment so completely part of the national structure aa in Australia . . . Australia's industrial position was due to a system pf arbitration

and conciliation which was more satisfactory than in any other part of the world. It had brought added respect for the law and smooth working in the adjustment of wages and conditions, and it had mini- mised friction by way of strikes and lock-outs. Admitting teat there were "occasional industrial dislo- cations" he claimed that they were the aftermath of the terrible war years. Arbitration, he concluded, had brought about harmonious re- lations between master and man in Australia.

Whatever effect this remarkable utterance had on his auditors at Richmond-the Virginians are by tradition a courteous people-its effect in the speaker's own country has been one of staggered amaze- ment at what must be interpreted ag either sheer effrontery or ap- palling ignorance. Ou the very day that Mr Makin made his extraordin- ary statements upwards of 100 ships were idle and the shipping trade of Sydney held up, all in defiance of the Arbitration Court and the Stevedoring Commission; the Amalgamated Engineering Union had launched a strike that must tie up the transport system of a State and inflict hardship and suffering on a. large community: whilst the Australian Council of Trades Unions had issued orders for a nation-wide stoppage of work on May 1 to force govern- ments to introduce the 40-hour week regardless of whether or not the Arbitration Court found it

practicable. In the light of these more recent happenings, of scores of like nature, the most charit- able view of Mr Makin's Bpeech is to say it was ludicrous.

But ludicrous-or audacious-as was the Ambassador's speech, made for overseas consumption, it was dwarfed by the Prime Minister's attempt to justify it. In the House of Representatives on Friday Mr Chifley declared that he supported Mr Makin's statement "that the arbitration laws of Australia were

held in respect by both employers and employees. Eighty-five to 90 per cent respected the arbitration laws, and only a small section did not pay proper regard to them."

This is one of those half truths that are worse than outright mis- statement. That a majority of Aus- tralian employers and employees are prepared to obey the arbitration laws is true undoubtedly. But they are not permitted to do so-as both Mr Makin and Mr Chifley well know-because of the licence given to disruptive elements which are avowedly out to destroy the arbi- tration system, root and branch. The Sydney waterside strike, the engineers' strike, and the May Day ultimatum are fomented by this element because the Government of the day has given way to them time after time, and has not the courage to enforce the arbitration laws or any other law which they care to defy.

In the light of their, actions to- wards upholding the arbitration system both Mr Makin and Mr Chifley ought to hide their heads in shame, when advancing the startl- ing claims contained in their speeches. It has won for both of them nothing but cynical laughter in their own country, and is not likely to win any added respect from outside, where people know better, notwithstanding the efforts of our Department of Information.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, MARCH 24, 1947. BEDTIME STORY
snippet: Australia's Ambassador at Washington (Mr Makin) has been telling the people of the United States some bedtime stories about

Cfc ü^ntíns 9nIIef.n

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 2 1947.

BLAIR ATHOL

The report by the Coordinator General of Public Works on the large-scale development of Blair

Athol coal measures is a cautious document, which fact must claim for it considerable public respect.

In a restrained manner it shows

(and truly, too), how vaBt would be the value to the State of Queensland-and even to Australia -were such development success- ful; it has collated considerable dáta and lifted them from the realm of conjecture to that ot established fact; it ha« produced much new material that will be of great value to whomsoever exploits the measures; and it. reveals that, notwithstanding all that hag been said and claimed regarding this field, many unknown data require collecting; but it did hot enter the battle of the ports, and left to the Commonwealth Government the knotty problem of finding export

markets.

The lastnamed is important, in view of the cold, calculating state-

ment that:

"Ii the undertaking bad to bear the full interest and redemption charges on the capital Invested in the whole project, including the railway, coal could not be produced (at Blair Athol)

at a price that would be compétitive. In Victoria and South Australia with NSW coals."

Giving the f.o.b'. cost of Blair Athol coal-on an output of 1,000,000 tons per annum on a 24 hour day operation for 300 days ia the year with a 75 per cent effee tive time on both coal and over- burden, hauled to port in train loads of 800 tons-as 23/7 per ton, -the report sets this against 21/0 f.o.b. for Newcastle and 24/4 for

Maitland coals, with sea freight j from. Central ! Queensland port to New South Wales still to be added to Blair Athol coal. Adjusted for British thermal units-11,600 Blair Athol and 13,000 New 8outh Wales-T-£100 worth of B.tl units in Blair .Athol coal would ba con- tained in £90 worth of Maitland coal and £80 worth of Newcastle

coal, all f.o.b, port of shipment. These are stubborn facts, and it is well to know them before thc heat of the next election distort» them again.

It witt be recalled that, early in the piece, th» -statement of the Prime Minister as to the disinte- gration of Blair Athol casi on exposure to air and. subsequent tendency to spontaneous combua

tion trefe hotly repudiated by Queensland*« Premier. It appears now that neither of them knew for

I certain, as samples of the- coal I have since been sent to Bonython I Laboratory, South' Australia, to ¡ test tile former and Queensland Railways are to* "create stockpiles of varyings sizes and thickness, of mixed sizeg of eoal_ with arrange- ments for testing any heat' gener- ated by means of maximum record- ing thermometers periodically" to clear np the latter.

The report shows that were Aus- tralia ' mechanised to-the -same ex- tent as Great Britain we would nee double our present consumption pf coal, and also that we would treble it did our mechanisation approach that of U.SJL. Were Great Britain I situated in the midst of Australia's ; main industrial areas or sear the

centre of gravity of her population, it might become a factor m right- ing this disparity; or did Aus- tralia's main centres of population sud industrial activity lie far from her main coat measures, the value of Blair Athol to our present set- up would be vastly different. But 70 per cent of Australia's total population lies within the States of New- South Wales, Tasmania and Victoria, which aggregate only 14 «per cent of the total area of; Australia, and among them they hare -88 per cent of Australia's anthracite and bituminous coals; and 98 per «¿nt of all sub-! bituminous and Ugnitic. coals ! In view of these, facto the report in ; . recent usus- pf "The Common- wealth Engineer" that Australian output of coal is 2,000,000 tens Short of the total annual require- ments suggests that , her trouble ilies less in a coal shortage than in] her inability either ta win-or use j the abundance of coal she has. They also emphasise the truth of the statement in the report that Blair Athol development is dependent

upon export trade, as mos* s least of the industrial and politic« factors -which have produced tba result in the south would appl; abo in the case of Blair Athol.

One point worthy of note in th report is .the fact that, althone five ports have been made in th 200 or so miles; of coast line be tween Gladstone and Mackay, son of them seems capable of beihj expanded to handle this major pto ject. Neither is there a mile o: railway- line nor a rake of rollin; stock worthy of a second glaset so there ie projected a complet outfit. A railway oves an undia plosed- route is estimated td cos' £7,400,000 and facilities' in SJ undetermined port are set down «1 £881,765. Interest and redemptioi on this lot ia estimated at 9/Í per ton of coal, while operating both the railway and port' ie esti- mated at only 5/7 per ton, whicT apparently will have to be paid whoever takes on the job, and whether the coal goes to southe»

States or overseas.

The job ahead of the "big Eng lish company" that is flirting wita Blair Athol is to find markets foi coal of 11,600 B.T.TJ. costing 23/Î per ton f.o.b. Central Queensland port, against India's 79,000,000,000 -tons and' South Africa's 55,200y

000,000 tons with abundance tif native labour. That job is likely to run against the same irreducible fact that struck many thousands of Australians when the Japanese were marching south: Australia js some thousands of miles from the nearest large concentrations of white folk, and even they have proved better able than are wa to do their own coal digging. To talk of digging coal in Australia for anybody in Asia or Africa is of course the sheerest moonshine, but that is a matter for the "big English company" to chew over.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON TUESDAY, DECEMBER 2 1947. BLAIR ATHOL
snippet: The report by the Coordinator-General of Public Works on the large-scale development of Blair Athol coal measures is a cautious

articleText:
Obe jHorntng bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, APRIL 19, 1947.

PRINCESS ELIZABETH

On Monday Princess Elizabeth Alexandra Mary Windsor-' Lilibet" to more people than maybe even she imagines-will have reached the intriguing age of 21, and although she will then merge into wider responsibilities *nd assume more direct control of her own affairs, she will not beeome "of age" in the sense that she will

henceforward be her own mistress. For one thing, where on coming of age her female subjects need no longer whisper coyly to ardent swains "Ask papa," Elizabeth is confronted until she is 25 with a grim guardian-the Royal Mar- riages Act of 1772-against un- desirable marriages that might affect the succession to the throne.

Until she is. Elizabeth must still refer suitors to *he King for his consent, after which ehe may dispense with that consent on giving one year's notice to the

Privy Council, but during that year; of waiting Parliament may rise in its wrath and forbid the marriage. She may, of course, ignore both

Parliament and its wrath, but by

doing that she would renounce all

right to becoming Queen of j England. Lest there be a slight ten- dency to feminine warmth at this

treatment of a Princess Heir Pre-i

sumptive, it should be noted that, j with but slight reservations, the; law applies also to Princes.

As is natural in the case of a girl that has grown into the hearts of the British people, speculation is growing as to the possibility of her marriage and particularly as to her choice of a partner. For it seems .to be accepted that, while she may not marry other than as approved by her subjects, neither will she marry at all other than as she wishes. She will be no party to smoothing out diplomatic tangles by a marriage bf. con- venience. It ia important to realise that where a King of England marries Ms spouse becomes Queen of England, but where a Queen of England marries her spouse be- comes- only Prince Consort and occupies no official position of authority. That, of course, is go that the line of succession will remain within the Royal Family.

One of the two buildings associated with Elizabeth's child- hood to be razed by Nazi bombs the other was the private chapel

at Windsor in which she was

christened-No. 145, Picadilly was

the London home of the Duke and Duchess of. York, and it was here that Princess Elizabeth spent much of her girlhood long before there seemed any likelihood of her be- coming Queen of the British Empire. During much of that time the disciplining hand of Queen Mary played an important part in influencing the trend of life of the future queen. Dress . was a sore, point with Grandma, for Eliza- beth's inherent tendency towards

an outdoor life led her to uncon- ventional cuts and colours; but all that ig of the past. The strikingly beautiful Duchess of Kent, one of the most delightfully dressed of women, has developed in her niece by marriage an excellent dress

sense.

It is natural, in a granddaughter of King Edward VII, that Eliza- beth should have not only a deep love for animals, but that this should particularly be the case of dogs and horses; she is a fir-t-elass horsewoman. À product of t'ic age, Elizabeth is not of the d-onping type, and while she can- .md did durina the war-darn her own stockings she ig also an accom- plished car driver. The latter she learned during her service with the ATS, but State advisers boggled over the future Queen undertaking the final road te6t through London traffic. The argument was still raging when she arrived at Buck- ingham Palace, per service truck, which she had driven through the thickest vehicular traffic in all of London'» busy thoroughfares. It required pore than State advisers to stand in the way of that young lady getting her driver's licence.

In a changed and changing world this young woman; so like very many English-Scottish young women of her age and time, that her appearance on the solitary path of queenship comes as something of a shock; moves from the security of childhood towards becoming the central figure in a mighty human drama. Problems of vast complex- ity and of deep importance to civilisation confront world rulers today as they did when Elizr. beth's great namesake faced unflinchingly the might and aggression of Philip of Spain, and are being met with no less courage and resolution.

A great Queen Elizabeth who raised high the social, the intellec- tual and political status of England journeyed to Tilbury, there to move among the soldiers camped in waiting for the approaching Armada of Philip of Spain. To an expostulation that she should expose herself to danger shé re- plied:

"A tyrant may fear his subjects. My chief strength ls in their good will."

With no other armour the pre-

sent Queen Elizabeth came and went among the flaming ruins nt' battered London to carry womanly comfort to the suffering people. It was the Elizabethan touch of 350 years earlier, and the Heir Pre- sumptive who is algo Elizabeth

gives every promise of carrying high that proud tradition during her reign.^ They evidently think so

in Britain, where an officer of State said, ' She will be a good Queen. She may even be a great Queen; but good Queen or bad she will be an attractive one."
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON SATURDAY, APRIL 19, 1947. PRINCESS ELIZABETH

articleText:
Cljt ffonifng PnUetitt

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 10,

1947.

COMMERCIAL SUICIDE

Whatever trends may develo] otherwise, in respect of oversea trade Australia has always iel

that a substantial connexion wii ultimately be built up with Asiai countries that will more thai compensate for. former market due to Europe's impoverishmem from war, and from political shifts That expectation should be fulh justified, for in point of prosimi'rj competitive prices and capacity t< export quality goods no othei country should be able to bea Australia for this market eithei in primary products or manufac- tured goods.

Yet in spite of many natura advantages we seem to be deter I mined to destroy our prospects bj I wilful act. The watersider^ bar

on Dutch shipping to the N.E.I

has cost Australia in trade mil

lions of pounds already, and hat built up a legacy of ill-will on thc part of the Dutch that will endure and affect, trade relations long after peace has come to Indonesia, By the deportation of Malayan seamen the Immigration Depart- ment is inviting from Malaya and neighbouring countries a boycott of everything Australian. Now, as if to complete the work of com- mercial self destruction, come fur- ther reports of. the shipment of in ; ferior goods from Australia tc

threaten the IOSB of a lucrative

I market that is expanding by leaps

and bounds.

[ According to à recent despatch I from AAP-Reuter's . correspondent at Hong Kong, poor quality goods ! and unethical business practices ar« damaging Australia's chances Of expanding, or even holding her strong post-war trading position in Hong Kong and South China. Gooda hearing the "Made in Aus- tralia" tag are .being more and more avoided and almost everyone one meets has something critical to say about the Australian trade. The most critical of all are Aus- tralians themselves, who are well aware that their country could and should do better. The grounds of criticism are that the quality of the goods, whether foodstuffs, textiles or machines, is poor and not "up to sample, packing is not i up to the standard of the market

! and deliveries take place well be-

hind schedule.

Specifically, it is complained that tinned fruit« are below the quality of similar lines from elsewhere, that cloth lengths are short and contain 'many flaws, that machine parts are of inferior workmanship, that packs fail to meet local stand- ards and are " carelessly shipped With consequent deterioration and

loss in transit. Worst feature of all is that certain firms in Sydney and Melbourne have allegedly

failed to forward orders after ac-

cepting letters of credit against the goods. Subsequent attempts to contact them failed, for they have been firms- of the "fly-by-, night" type. In other cases: where the orders have been ful-i filled complaint is* made that, in- stead of beuur meticulous when

manufacturing goods, it appears Australia ls becoming slipshod and disposed to say that "near enough ie good enough." Perhaps one ha« not to go to Hong Kong to make that discovery. During the war, on the plea of shortage of essential materials, many low grade articles were permitted to be placed on the market and the manufacturer who took advantage of that licence is reluctant to mend bis ways. Of course, it is not fair to suggest that this stigma at- tachée to all Australian goods chipped to the East. Old estab- lished firms that had pre-war trad- ing connexions with the East are «till carrying on satisfactorily, but the reputation of all" Australian goode is being besmirched by an ail-too large post-war type of business that is simply inviting

commercial suicide, '

The extent of the logs to which Australia is thu« exposed is of considerable magnitude. Host of the foodstuffs of Hong Kong, in- cluding meat, butter and flour, comes from Australian supply by international allocation and, in addition, Australia exports a con- siderable proportion of canned foodstuffs. The value of food- stuffs and provisions rose from 4,500,000 dollars in 1939 to nearly 12,000,000 dollars last year, and the 1947 figures are expected to

show a further substantial in- crease. The value of Australian piece goods and textiles have gone up from 2,500,00'doliars in 1939 to 11,000,000 dollars this year. Surely thia is a trade worth protecting at

all costs, yet this ominous com-j

ment is being encountered from the executives of big importing firms: "Things are sorting them-j selves out now and goods are be- coming available elsewhere. One thing, our experience with Austra- lian imports since the war has \ taught us, i.e., where not to do our j I business in future."

It is incredible that some system' I of inspection of export goods can-

not be devised to meet this situa 1 tion. With one out of every five

adult persons in Government or semi-Government employment, ap- parently none can be spared to en- sure that the main lifeline of the

country's commerce is protected,

for once our overseas markets are lost a mortal blow will have been dealt the economic structure of the Commonwealth. The Customs De- partment and Department of Com er«e appear to be too busy pre- venting gooda coming into Austra- lia to give proper attention to the equally, if not more, important task of seeing that some of our own shoddy products do not leave the country.

articleText:
Qfc jHornîng bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY. DECEMBER 24,

1947.

THE YEAR

Much has happened on the lc scene since Rockhampton citiz last wished each other a me Christmas and a prosperous 3 Year. The Christmas was me enough, in spite of certain sh< ages, and remarkably free fr the haliday tragedy that so of mars the festive season. The w for a prosperous 1947 would h¡ been fulfilled to the fullest ext but for one unfortunate and ava able happening. That was the starred meatworkere' strike in middle of the year which led tc loss ol £100,000 in wages, to £ nothing of further losses to p ducers, and all without bringi gain to anyone.

At one stage in the post-v period Rockhampton carried an i due proportion of the State's i employed, but excepting during ' strike tfaps condition did not p: vail this year. There has been

lack of work at the meatwor: on railway and main.roads ma: tenance, and the big constructipi jobs. Shortage of materials 1 been the principal handicap, a this is being gradually oyercoji particularly in the case of housii where much of the lag has be made up and the lack of acco: modation prevailing since the w has been considerably ameliorate

* Substantial progress has be made with the new Fitzroy Brid notwithstanding semi-flood oom lions early in the year, and tei porary shortages in essenti materials. The work has been e tirely free'from industrial dispui The Regional Electricity Board h¡ not been so fortunate in the matt of supplies, which has retard« the main generating station

Rockhampton. Nevertheless go< progress has been made in ¿caril this * instrumentality to supp Central Queensland's needs : power and light.

With the realisation that the: undertakings are to a large extei of an ephemeral character so fi as -employment is concerned, loci public bodies have addressed thea selves to the promotion of seconc ary industries, fdr which the dil

trier is suited. The meatworks hs operated on the fullest scale as any further expansion of the bei cattle industry by the , improvemer of coastal lands-might naturally 1 expected to lead ' to an expansio there, though there is as yet n sign of a'leather industry develo] ing. Mt Morgan continues to prc vide great wealth for the benefi of the tctjwn,. district and Stat* Experiments in producing sulphn from pyrites are understood t have advanced to a point wher there is some hope of a new in dustry arising. The establishmen of a wool .disposals centre wa halted by the cancellation of th original tenders, but. a delegatioi

jvhich went to Sydney has secure)

an assurance from the Prime Min ister that when the supply positioi permits , the buildings will as surely be erëc^ed. Increased intérêt in Queensland as a source of suppl] for a greater percentage of Aus tralia's coal needs has focussed at tention on Central Queensland, de posits, lending themselves to opez cut mining and the exploitatioi projected for Blair Athol and th« Callide, should it materialise, nins! have favourable implications foi Rockhampton, without encouraging the hope of a coal export trad<

¡ through this port.

So far the most important de- velopment in tiie field of secondary industry was the preliminary ex- amination fay Courtaulds to ascer tapn. whether Rockhampton offered promise as a possible site for one of their rayon'.factories. It is en- couraging to know that this region vis definitely in the running, and the. Qtty Council, and other public bodies are .to be complimented on the manner in which they present- ed our claims in this matter.

Municipally this has not been a barren year for Rockhampton. The biggest undertaking has been the move for the niunicipalisation of privately-owned bus routes, the negotiation being as yet in . the initial stage. Beautification has been exemplified most in the laying down of garden plots in East Street, and in a general improve- ment in parka and playing, fields. A municipal bus run to the' sea- side is in the experimental stage. The OSty Council also has taken

over the School of 'Arts and

Library and is proceeding with th» establishment of free reference and children's libraries

' In cultural matters Rockhamp- ton maintained a healthy state in the year now drawing to a close. The Little Theatre moved on to fresh triumphs, the Musical Union enjoyed'ofte* of its most successful seasons, and the Eisteddfod As- sociation consolidated its ? position so that it bids fair to become an annual fixture. Most notable event in the church life of Rockhampton was the enthronement of a new Anglican Bishop. During the year a tourist organisation was formed and the C.Q. Advancement League advanced -the preparation of ah illustrated booklet on the resources and scenic attractions of the dis- trict, to a point where it but re- mains for arrangements for print- ing to be made. Last but not feast the ' Commonwealth census endorsed Rockhampton's claim to be Queensland's second city.

On the whole the year has been one of bright prospects rather than of wide advances, but on the present outlook there is ground for hoping that at least some of the promises will he fulfilled.

articleText:
O&e morning bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, MARCH 29, 1947.

BRITAIN TODAY

Less than a fortnight after the stifling joy and exhiliration of VE day on May 8, the British Broad- casting Corporation opened it6 9 p.m. news session with the intima- tion that the ration of the British people was to be cut by one ounce each of fat and bacon and a fur- ther cut in soap. Throughout the British Isles patient women paused in their sewing to hear the worst, when "Not as bad aB it might have been" they said with slight relief and went on patching the pre-war shirt or mending the utility stocking.

Measured by the flashing colours of continental crowds the British crowd is at best a drab affair. Today it is the shabbiest imagin- able. *Ia their seventh year of food and clothes rationing, five of them under intensive bombing and deso- lating black-out, the people of the British Isles bear none of the

outward signs by which to dis- tinguish the main actors in a drama that will go down as one of the most magnificent chapters in the history of democracy. No

more than a broken heart can the

stiff upper lip be worn on the

sleeve. Where the French flaunted before their puzzled German cap- tors gay colours and fantastic hats, a British crowd is a sombre affair in dun or black or green or utility maroon or khaki, with here and there an astonishing splash of saxe blue or utility red; but over it all is the utilitarian cut reminiscent of factory or fighting front- Cloth-makers and tailors worked for the services; fashion designers, dressmakers and milli- ners worked for export; and the women who during the war super- imposed factory and office work

over their housework must make the most of their service dress, brightened ever so little by stray fragments of pre-war glory.

A Frenchman who, after the liberation of his country crossed the channel to see the fire-eating British in the home which is reputedly his castle, went back more puzzled than ever. He saw no heroics and no castles, but he did see endless queues In which much is to be learned on the qual- ity of existing laws and the need for fresh ones, on White Papers and Cabinet Ministers; in which originate .letters to the Press and questions'¿n : Parliament. But he realised none of thesa things, as

he missed the reason for the seem-

ing submission tb bureaucratic rule of these war-tried people. This

is that their Government treated

its people as sensible beings who were, willing to accept restrictions if given a convincing reason; that they have accepted what has been imposed on them because of the

essential fairness and reasonable-

ness of Britain's rationing system. He missed the conscious feeling of the snugness of island life; what I ever be the trouble or the rewards I all are in together, with no invader

from without and no traitors within.

Peculiarly enough, these be leagured folk saw 'rationing far harder to accept in a land of plenty such as USA. In the case of the British they knew that the food was simply not in the coun- try, where USA folk could see their country bursting with food, in which case wrote a Glasgow woman "it must involve far more

conscious virtue to cut down your own share." But if it was good that the British saw the need for rationing, it was better that their rulers saw to it that there was always enough to honour the food coupons, and also to allow some flexibility and humanity in appor- tioning the share. Soon after Dun- kirk it was established that every expectant mother and every child under five was assured of a pint of milk per day at half the cur- rent price. Then there was extra cheese for agricultural workers: orange juice and cod-liver oil foi children, and priority in orangée for all under 18- With a rare gen- ius for reaching all essential

needs, the Government of Britain treated its people as individuals with special tastes and needs, and not regimented units on a sheet oí statistics.

This result was achieved less bj the submission of the people than through the helpfulness of the Ministry of Food that, instead of trying to "sell" rationing by high pressure salés talk, set out to ex- plain first the fundamental neeù for rationing and then advising how to make the most of the short commons. It kept pace with the moving events in the grim drama, and when flour was short in 1942 the Ministry gave wide j publicity to recipes ijor making 1 potato sconestand pastry; then j when potatoes became scarce it

I told how to make flour dumplings I to fill the bill. Strange foods ! found their way into Britain dur-

ing those times, and here again the Ministry was on the spot to advise people as to their use and preparation. Every housewife throughout the length and breadth of the British Isles was able each week to look over the Ministry's special advertisement and feel that she was a partner in a joint enter- prise, for not only were her diffi- culties being understood, but she was being advised on how best to

surmount them.

On top of these grim reasons for rationing, the war-time food blockade and the post-war need of more food for Europe-the latter superimposed on the implacable need to export manufactured goods in order to pay for imported goods for the people and raw materials for the industries-has come freak- ish weather that first froze up the whole of Britain's moving econ-

omy, and then drowned much ot that which could not move. Trans-

port was first held in an icy grip BO that supplies of every kind of necessity could not be moved, and then growing crops were sub

merged and mines and industries flooded, so that when the waters subside it will be months ere there will be supplies to be moved.

So it is that British crowds

today are drab aggregafcions of unimpressive people, and so it is that for the hundredth or so time in her long existence Britain is down and out. The crowds are drab because even a bishop, whose episcopal cope was disintegrating, was able to have it relined only when ll of his parishioners surrendered a coupon each; and Britain is down and out because critics say she is-just as they said she was down and out after Dunkirk. But because their atti- tude is the living symbol of the i British genius for apt, balancea compromise to meet reality the bishop got his cope relined, and Britain's 'faint-hearted critics will ba confounded. '
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON SATURDAY, MARCH 29, 1947. BRITAIN TODAY
snippet: Less than a fortnight after the stifling joy and exhiliration of VE day on May 8, the British Broadcasting Corporation opened its 9

articleText:
?ljt iHorning bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, AUGÜST 25, 1947.

PREMIERS CONFER

For moat of last week the Aus- tralian Premier^ sat in. confer- ence, to what particular purpose must be a matter of perplexity to

the bulk of their constituents. It

is true that many matters ' were discussed, and at times a note of frankness crept into the delibera- tions that is not- usual at these gatherings; but the most striking feature of the opening sessions ap-' peered to be the fact that all of the Premiers had attended in the spirit of Oliver Twist; to ask for more of the oublie revenue.

One looks in vain for any pro- posal to reduce the burden On the providers Of that revenue, or to de- vise a means of preventing 90 per cent of the country's note issue being planted and used in trans- actions which provide no taxation returh and Utile employment. There was a measure of agreement as to the need for greater produc- tion to ensure the economic security of the Commonwealth, bot no word of rebuke to the Premiers of NSW and Queensland for having prejudiced that objective by their precipitate action over the reduced working week.

One or two entertaining inter- ludes crept into the conference proceedings. In a spirited exchange

with the Prime Minister over the Commonwealth's intrusion into the control of hospitals, evidently con- sidered a good vote catcher, Mr Hanlon shed a considerable ray of light on the manner in which some of the "agreements" between Fed-

eral and State Governments are achieved, when he remarked that they were brought about by one party standing by with an .axe in MB hand and the other having both hahds tied behind his bick.

Mr McGirr, (NSW) released some pungent, if not altogether new, criticism of the Federal Gov- ernment's policy on tâxàtîoh and other mattera. "If,*' he observed, "the workers were given ab incen- tive tb produce more there would not b% such an Outcry for mater- ials. If there was some relaxation Of the tax oh Overtime there would

be a greater incentive to Work with a consequent greater supply of urgently needed materials." Com- ing from the Premier of NSW, whose hasty 40-hour week legisla- tion, r without any consideration as to ita likely effects, hals done more than any single cause to Tetard production"1 in that State, this is, to say the least, rather rich; but the fundamental truth of the con-

tention is by ho means impaired

on that account.

- Judged by the tone of the later sessions there is èxcuëè fbi be-

lieving that the chief Object of the

Premiers' Conference and the meet- ing of the National Works Council which is .associated with it, was to prepare the public mind for the. imminence of another -depression and general slump in Australian industry- On Friday it was pro- claimed that the National Work* Council had approved of a five-year programme to cost' £358,419,000, this programme to be held in re- serve against a possible depression in the future. The Council directed that the works should fae carried out over as wide a field as possible, so as to provide work for the max* imum number of occupations in an emergency. The Coordinator ot

Works stated' that 40 per cent of the total progfammfe has already been planned in readiness for com- mencement should it be found necessary to swjng the programme into operation.

Remembering the weed chipping undertakings that made up so much of the relief work provided by governments during the last dp pression, complaint will hardly be offered at the "Works Council draw ing up plans that will provide em- ployment- for a maximum number of occupations, should the emer- gency arise. But there will be sur- prise, and no little apprehension, that at this juncture it is consid- ered advisable to draw np a huge public works programme involving £^50,600,000 tq meet a slump that

st least someone in authority an ticipates.

Australia today should be look- ing forward to an> expansion of ID dustries and the development of

her resources to an extent that

Will forestall any possibility of a depression requiring relief work for a maximum number of occupations. Is thia attitude of the governments not calculated to bring on such a slump, since private enterprise, if it embarks on a bold policy of ex- pansion, must of necessity hold entirely different views to those Which 'have inspired this £350,000,

000 relief works scheme?

By and large, there was little in the proceedings at the Premiers' Conférence to inspire the average citizen with enthusiasm. From it he has learned that Tie can expect little relief from his present bur- dens and restrictions, but if the worst happeng and there is another depression he will be provided with a pick and shovel job. Diawing his

own conclusions as to what lies -ahead he will, if in a position to do so, pqssibly hasten the eui day by trying to effect a little insur- ance égâinst the future on his own account, by adding what he can to the store in the old tin trunk.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, AUGUST 25, 1947. PREMIERS CONFER
snippet: For most of last week the Australian Premiers sat in conference, to what particular purpose must be a matter of perplexity to

articleText:
Cfc jtöoming Sulleíín

ROCKHAMPTON,

FRIDAY, OCTOBER .il, 1347.

RAILWAY MATTERS.

Latterly Queensland Railway liave engendered quite an amour of back-chat between Transuoi Minister, union heads and adminis trative staff which has had the ef feet of letting the public in on cei tain aspects of the service in

manner that is enlightening if no altogether encouraging. Maybe th frank speaking is a repercussion c recent revelations of a three-quar

j ter million loss on thc service las year, with every prospect of th ; amount being doubled or treble when the 40-hour week comes int operation.

The first indication that the ex cellent war record of the servis would no longer serve to expiai away present deficiencies was whe; the Minister of Transport felt im pel led to go tb Ipswich and tell ; mass meeting of workshops' em ployees that unless locomotive and wagons were repaired and pu in running order-and the onl; way this could be done was to workshops tradesmen to w/irl overtime-the Department wouli have to ration transport and tba would mean unemployment in th service. Mr Duggan also made . speech in the House iu which h made reference to a scheme fc "wipe put inefficiency in the Rail way Department,"' without givinj any clear indication as to - wha

the' scheme was.

Needless to say an occasion sud as this could not be passed over b;

union officials who are: never mor vocal than at times when action and not words from them would b more to the point. Mr Nola1 (branch secretary ARU) declarei that the present plight of the rail way6 -was due to a lack of for* sight during the latter end bf th war. in those days no constructiv suggestion was made as to ho\ the railways should, be organise) to meet the new situation tba would obviously arise when th war ended. He welcomed the Min ister's declaration of trying ti evolve a scheme to wipe out ineifi ciency. One way of . eetablishim a high standard of efficiency wa to take considerably more notice o the unions and considerably lesi of railway administrators. Th unions and their members recog nised the need for improved ~an< efficient service to the public, bu their efforts to supply this ha« been frustrated . by... inefficients The State Secretary of the Aus tral ian Federation of Loco motive Enginemen (Mr Ridgeway] added his quota to the effect thai for many years his union had mad« suggestions to the Commissions regarding alterations in railway administration, ' but could not ob tain any practical reform.

In the light of past experienc:

this should have beeu the end o the matter. The Minister coul< have basked in the praises of hi; colleagues for the "couragel' he ha« shown in calling the attention o the workshops unions to the alarm ing condition of the rolling «stock and in hinting at some secret plat to implant etficiency in a servio in which it has always beet thwarted by political interference The union leaders would hav< shown the rank and file - whai bold fellows they were in telling of the " heads. " The administrativ« staff would a<5 usual have beer

left holding the bag saying nothing. But the worm wil turn, and the railways admin

istrative staff has on this oc- casion turned in a manuel that must have administered a shock to Ministerial circles and has

made the union spokesmen loot rather foolish, if they arc capable of that emotion. Railway Commis- sioner Will*, who is nearing th« end of his term apparently has de- cided that a little straight tala from the administrative side is in order.

Mr Wills brands the references to the administrative staff as at- tempts to cast an unwarranted slur on the reputation of a body of administrators whose work iu

recent years had received the ap- probation of those in Australia most qualified to judge. The great majority of railwaymen had vdouc a wonderful job in the last few years,, but that could not be said of the unions', whose representa- tives were criticising the depart- ment now. In 1942 when the Japa- nese menace was at its height, Mr Nolan's union threatened to de-

clare the railways black, simply because of a dispute regarding the camping locality of some fettles. In 1944 advantage was taken of the serious war position by the same union and an instruction is- sued to all fettling employees to travel both to and from work in

the Commissioner's time. Recently when the department decided to improve efficiency by obtaining a number of the most modern type of locomotives from overseas, the organ of the ARU suggested to members that if they were not satisfied with the engines when they arrived in Queensland they j could refuse to work them. Mr

Nolan wanted greater service to the public at a time when the de- partment has considerably more business than it could handle and was compelled to ration transport, and at the same time his union re- jected proposals to work overtime on engine and wagon repairs to help overtake wartime lag, whilst it also roundly condemned ¿shift

work.

The demand by the union repre- sentative of a share in the opera- tion of the railways had somewhat amusing features, added the Com- missioner. These mea had beeu un- able over many years of railway service to achieve any respon sible position in the department they now sought to dominate.

An illustration of their ad

rr;nistrative Capacity was given when they were invited to «flcross with the Commissioner and his principal officers iu committee methods of reorganisation. The proposals put forward were those which already had received depart- mental consideration. After two meetings the union representatives failed to attend_ "obviously be- cause their supply of ideas had become exhausted."

I This is crisp talk and to the

point. It is a pity it was not of j fered earlier and oftener. It I might have done a lot for the rail

ways at one time.

BOCKHAMPTON

¡ SATURDAY, DECEMBER 20, 1947.

STANLEY BALDWIN

' Wien people read in their i papers pr heard over the

that Earl Baldwin of Bewdley died in his sleep the tidings veyed little ti most of them,

years of the last decade havi sounded with the names of

who were writing in bold chi ters the history of their day, u of them names which came t abhorred, some that came to loved and others-not so man these-that came to be tru Events in the pre-war twi were soon eclipsed by tte te impact of modern war, just as

domestic affairs of Britain had

swallowed up in the penumbra a. Europe driving recklessly wards madness. Yet the event which history must raise high stature of Earl Baldwin of Sew was that which led the na through an impasse that threat to split the people in the faa oncoming, war, an event which

into . exile a popular English 1 and enthroned our present I and Queen. Through Earl Bald of Bewdléy Britain once more limited her famous limited n archy, and made secure again ' principle of . cabinet responsibi and parliamentary democracy ; the people knew him then Stanley Baldwin, the pipe-smol Prime Minister of Great Brita

For the first ten years,of political life-^-1908-1917-it is li ally true that Stanley Baldwin -unknown even to his own . pa Nor when his patron Bonar ] made him President of the Bc of Trade in 1917, with ' a seat the Cabinet, did ^Baldwin rise ah a "comfortable mediocrity.'* T in October, 1922, with *Bonar and on i-he verge of retirement ¡ the Lloyd George Coalition Gove ment fixed so firmly in office t it risked bringing war-weary B iain into a new fight with " Turi over, the Chanak affair, Stat Baldwin" made a speech which lan up the Lloyd George-Bonar I Coalition as Bonar Law had b hoping" for years to break it nj

That was "the secret of Stan Baldwin's power : he could, w] the supreme occasion called for make the kind of speech his hear would not easily forget, cr

the .unexpected /thing that c vinced the common -people- of

bedrock common sense, his uni peacimble sincerity and downrij honesty. It has been said of 1 that he lacked the subtlety of Balfour, that he had none Joseph Chamberlain's Ruthless 1 termination, . that he had none the Incidity of Asquith and v< little of the genius of Lloyd Geo; fot" - evangelism, notwith&tandi all of which his integrity and hi purpose made of him One of i most attractive figures in Brit national life. ?

ït" took ardent party mernot many year's to learn that,

Stanley Baldwin, party mea notíung. He would work with i men bf good intent whatever" w their political creed, and was p< fectly willing at all times to ado and adapt' good ideas from'wiem soever they came. That trait ga his followers* a quick catch of tl breath when/on attaining power 1024, he made Winston Church Chancellor of the Exchequer. The was* no need for bim to say th the appointment , was of his ov making; . for big " die-hard " su porters respected Chnrchill'a -OB sf^duig abSity no less than th« I feared iris igreat debating powei j 1m* ¿vj^anlejr . Baldwin respect* ' boti,: jímd considered it wiser

enlist their cooperation than ' 1 incur their hostility. Where h colleagues would have cast Church! int* the/outer darkness, Stan!* Baldwin invited ' him to share tl inner light.

I Another cause of palpitatio j among his foIlowerB 'was Baldwin

I handling of ; the, trade union lev; As is the practice in Australia ti system^developed in Britain b which, every member of -a toad union contributed to political fundi

j sot that many thousands of poop]

of non-Socialist viewa were .cori

I petted to support political creed to which they were actually . oj posed. With many Conservative this was made a political issue ii tile 1924 election .campaign ; ' bu while opposed no less than, hi followers to the practice Stanle; Baldwin regarded it as but on phase of tixe great trade " unioi

movement Which must ultimated

bè reformed if parliamentary gov

eminent is to endure. When th debate came on, ,he told a packet House that to meddle with thi matter then would be . prema ture, for it would rouse a storm o bitter -indignation, tt would Tendn absolutely ^inpossible that coopera rion* with' moderate - Labour leaden which he considered vital to thi solution of Britain's : industria problems, and so it was not wort! while to provoke such a contest That was one of the few speechei of recent times that can be sait to have changed a vote of th« House of Commons, but it con i vinced men of. every variety ol ! opinion that here was a man who

on occasion, could rise above thc ordinary prejudices of política

life.

Stanley Baldwin was fundament' ; ally loyal to his known loyalties I Lad deep affections and few hat-

reds, and there was written inte ' thc whole fabric of his thougnt and

I mind that almost unconscious favUi

in the historic mission of Great

Britain which was the special prerogative of his party. Funaa. mentally a religious maii without ever emphasising his religious prin- ciples he disliked the poséur and the professional expert, hated bom- bast and rhetoric and had to a marked degree the Englishman's genius for appearing an amateur in a game in : which he was a master. He had many outspoken critics, but immeasurably more sil- ent admirers, his hold upon his fellow countrymen being built upon a mutual trust founded upon that instinctive relationship that lies deeper than those conscious pur- poses that have their roots io -he spoken word rather than ? in the subtleties of the mind.

England, has lost a" great Eng- lishman after profiting tremen- dously from his life and work : but it was a¡ Frenchman who reminded tts on Trafalgar Day that, if there is any Englishman 'more powert m ¿ban a live one it is a dead great j

ffefr-^ ? ? -J

articleText:
íS$e ¿ttoriung bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

i

THURSDAY, OCTOBER 2, 194T.

BANKING DOUBTS

Queer tilings are happening the laboratory of advanced thoi behind the Labour iron euri Four weeks after the brave Cai resolution to nationalise the

vate trading banks Senator

Sienna-who is to wear the Chi shoes when the latter steps i the chair of the governor of

Commonwealth Bank, and is t porarily wearing the down-at-] Evatt shoes while that en gentleman is thumping confer« tablas and otherwise caking 1

tralla look foolish abroad-t an anxious Caucus a fortnight that "the Bank Bill cannot ready for at least three weeks." also told another anxious qi tioner that an appeal to the Pr Council is inevitable. We are i in the seventh week after

Great Disclosure, and the ' ol hands, who sense the politi danger of delay, are getting n TOUS. They wanted the Bill pus! through an assenting Parliami within a fortnight, so as to ¡ the big plunder over in time

people to forget it when the Op] sition opens up its next elect; range-finding artillery.

Meanwhile, Mr Chifley, banisl of private banks, has made Mr Beasley, our High (private lard« Commissioner in London, an inti national banker by appointing h to ' Bretton Woods, to whi "Socialised crtjdit" is ana them and our own Mr Larcombe has c scribed the proposed plunder

private banks as "great reforn as if Chifley I is any more

be trusted with unlimited pow than was Charles II. By connscj mg the savings of the people t latter gentleman planted the se from which sprang the Bank

England, and by a like process t former gentleman wants to aboli the right of the people, throuj their bank servants, to look aft their own money. The only diffe ence in Mr Larcombe's going bat 277 years to a puppet ministry f< his "reforma" is that where a kii then used power to rob his su jects, a Prime Minister now pr poses to plunder them to get thi

power.

Then scoffers are pointing oi that banks aré not the only inst tutions to lend money. Pawnbro] erg do it as do the breweries, ali many large wholesale businesses < all kinds and insurance companies and that does not include Mac marketeers with upwards < £150,000,000 stowed away for jiu such nimble transactions. Whs arrant rubbish it ia to talk c nationalising banking with ths

sea of outlawed black mark«

money ready to flow and set up i opposition to the Chifley cabal Then it is noted that no provisio has been made in the recently delivered 1047-8 Budget for com pensa ting the privat» banks, no does the document contain an; reference to that revolutionär; proposal. Doss .this mean that th Chifley idea is to plunder bani

shareholders as well as their cus tomers? Or is it proposed to bu; them out with some of the man; tons of Government bonds held ty the Commonwealth Bank-or pape store?. Or does Caucus feel that h¡ the time the hanks and their sup porters have finished fighting then will be mighty little of the ambi tions nationalisation plan left tx finance? Or is it that there ii

hesitancy about bringing it to th< budget stage before Caucus finan clera return from hearing whai their electorates have to say aboul

the business?

Secret advice from behind thc Iron Curtain is that the Bill, whicl was to have been inviolable in all

the stark simplicity of four clauseSj ia already creaking at one or more of the joints of each of its 40 clauses, while the legal panel to the Brains Trust has been more than doubled and its diversity of opinion more than trebled. The thing that was as simple as feeding

lamb cutlets to a bear has become studded with startling difficulties, and the humble field pea now con- fronts them as a champion of in- dividual rights that no swashbuck- ling Government may invade. The Commonwealth Government barked its legislative shins against Section 62 of the Constitution in the dried fruits case; the Queensland Gov* eminent was battered by it in the peanuts case; and the bold bank

nationalises, who were so confi-

dent of the water-tight qualities of their case, are waiting anxiously to see what is about to happen to the Tasmanian Government, which is assailing Section 92 through the medium of a field pea case.

There seems to have been some

suggestion in Caucus, that by judi- cious "packing" of the High Court no certificate authorising appeal to the Privy Council need be issued But Senator McKenna dashed that

ray of hope by telling Caucus tEàt an appeal under Section 92 does not necessarily require a certifi- cate from the High Court. He also told his perturbed hearers that no such certificate was obtained in the famous dried fruits case. Even more disconcerting; to Labour chief- tains is the fervent support given by Communists to the Chifley proposals, and the dynamic, pulsat- ing meetings of the bank defenders all over Australia. On the one hand Mr Larcombe's reformers are em- barrassed by their Communist friends, while on the other they are being mercilessly enfiladed by their freedom-loving enemies. No Government or cause could fear more, and many stronger men than Mr Chifley have bitten the political dust through even less direct attacks upon the rights and liber- ties of a free people. '

Ti j Arbitration Courts of Australia ai j being - constantly assailed by thoi J who-" would like to bring aboi j their .destruction; hence it- behovt j all* emrtjoyers to do., eveiythin j within Tbheîr power to ensure tb j maintenance of the system, even : j the union* will not. To have dos j anything to upset the; shoppin j Jboure' .decision would have bee

Some observations on the sub ! jeet" rby the « "Daily Mirror," a I Labour, paper, is of particular in j terest. The British shopkeepers and

Their I fears that they will be over-worked I and underpaid must not be al j lowed to'materialise; but it holds I strongly, to the opinkm >tiiat. articleText:
' =J

.Ste Jitarning JButlttin I

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 3, 1947.

IMPERIAL PREFERENCE

As time brings ns nearer to the inevitable discussion on tariffs and other bars to the free movement of world trade, we may expect to hear a very great deal on the virtues of Imperial preference. And virtues there assuredly are, just as there are many problems of a nature never before experi-

enced.

In the days of the Ottawa agreement, the provision of which Labour denounced1 roundly and de- scribed as "tariff slashing," Bri- tain was a creditor nation and had pretty well the run of world

markets. She had vast overseas investments, her ships were com- mon carriers for all countries de- siring their services, and tourists

from all over the world paid im- mense sums to enjoy the British summer and the British way of life. Today, as a result of selling her overseas investments in order to wage two-fisted war against the Hun, Britain is a debtor nation, and if she is to feed her people and also her hungry secon- dary industries she must export as she has never exported before. There is no other way.

This brings home another fact that hfrs hitherto escaped notice, which is that while much has been made of Imperial preference the British Empire never ? was any- where4 near being a self-contained unit. The general belief has been that of Great Britain as the world's greatest importer, sel against a background of a power- ful, salf-siifticient Empire enjoy- ing exclusive trading advantages

and able to isolate itself as au economic ' unit from the rest ol the world. From this view it wae but a step to the picture of a series of interlocking, exclusive trade agreements that have suc- ceeded in maintaining British and Commonwealth prosperity in a world. of falling values and gen- eral trade depression.

How untrue is that concept is revealed in the simple fact -that during the five years to 1933 the total inter-Empire trade was only 27 per cent of the total Empire trade and the remaining 73 pei cent was between Empire r.nd foreign countries. This figure has improved-t-as a result of. the 1932 Ottawa Conference - in the five years to 1938 and was slightly under a third of the total trade, with foreign countries providing the other two-thirds.- It is clear from this that the trade of the British Commonwealth cannot be kept within, "the family circle." Australia for example did 42 pei cent of her trading with Greal Britain in the last prewar year, and did tho remaining 58 per cen! of it with foreign countries.

Odd as it may seem, the 1935 Ottawa conference and its result- ant agreement did much to bette] Empire trade because it improved Anglo-American trade relations The agreement can well be termec a "defensive'* policy and its origil can be traced to the Harley-Smoo' tariffs introduced in USA in 1930 which compelled Britain to depar for the first time from her his torie trade policy and impose im port duties in 1932. The Ottawi Agreement was part of that "de fensive" programme, and was ü fact clear evidence of the viciou circle of rising tariff barriers tba always follow any. attempt b

deal with international trad

problems on. a narrow, purel;

national basis.

WhUe the Ottawa Agreemen undoubtedly increased inter-trad between Commonwealth countries it did so only at the expense c the British Commonwealth's trad with the rest of the world. Tba elementary truth was seen nc where sooner, or with greate force, than in Britain and USA both of which depend upon forcig markets for the sale of export and within two years of the Otts wa Agreement the Harley-Smoo tariffs were modified in effect b; USA passing the Reciprocal Trad Agreement Act of 1934. This le to modification of the Ottaw Agreement in 1937, and by tl end of the following year-or o the eve of war-Britain and US. were moving away mutually froi their high tariffs. They wei also moving towards the inescaj able conclusion that the prosperit of both countries is linked wit world prosperity.

All of that took place when Bri tain was a creditor nation, wit her overseas interests, apart froi those within the Empire, sprea through most countries of tl world. When she could no long< send forth colonists she sent fort

capital. It will readily be seei therefore, that a most importai reciprocal trade movement bet we« Britain and CSA was in progrei before the war, and much spat work had been done which led 1 the existing understanding. WM war stripped Britain of her ovei seas reserves it in no way dímíi ished her importance to wor] trade. She still is the world's bij gest potential market, and it ws on thia account that the America loan was made. It ensured thi che world's biggest potential mai ket would revive and take ii traditional place. When the tin comes to talk of Empire prefei ence, it will be well to remembi

that 100 per cent inter-Empii trade would not make of the Bi

tish Commonwealth a complei

economic unit, even were such

consummation either desirable « necessary.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1947.

BAN LIFTED

The ban imposed by the Watc Bide Workers' Federation on Dut sh'pf ing in Australian -ports end on Friday, as a result of negoti tion between officials of the Feder tion and the Commonweal Attorney-General. As a rest trade between two neighbouri and friendly countries, whose i spective Governments had nothi to do with the embargo, will

resumed. The ban, which h lasted since September, 1945, w imposed ostensibly to aid nati Indonesians in their struggle f seif-government, though there w stn. suspicion that it was ju anrther intrusion by Australis Communists, who have a keen no for trouble of any description ai are prompt to take a hand in i as evidence recent activities

respect of the rocket range expel men ts in Central Australia.

At for the right or justificatu of an industria] organisation

one country poking its nose int

the domestic affairs of anothi

country, to say nothing of usur] ing the functions of its own Go"\ ernment, sufficient was said aboi that at the time to convint everyone, excepting the Commo ¡wealth Government, of the impr< priety of the whole business. Y< from inherent weakness or froi fear of repercussions at the ba lot box it did nothing, and doub less, would have continued doin nothing had it not been that tl Indonesian Government, in whof interest the ban was being mair tained, had started to move -heave and earth-even going so far as t collaborate with the Dutch them selves-to have it lifted. In th end there was the ludicrous spa tacle of three Governments tryin to remove something that had bee imposed, and was being main tained, bjr an industrial union.

There may have been anothe and less prominent factor that ba' a good deal with the removing o the embargo. Within the pas week or two a large amount o goods required by the Dutch hav been transported from AustralL by freighter planes, with ever; indication that the volume wouh be greatly increased as machine! became available. ' It may not bi too wide a guess that it o cc urra to at least some of the water' Eiders that, if allowed to develop this would lead to a state o:

things when it would not matte to the Dutch or to Australian sup pliers whether Dutch ships wen banned or given the run of th« ports, since none of them woulc be plying for trade in thes< waters. Something like that n occurring in respect of our inter state shipping trade. There have

¡been so many waterfront hold-up! j that merchants are prepared t< I pay the extra rail and air freights

in order to get their goods regu- larly. If they succeed in half killing the shipping trade thc waterfront workers will not bc the first, nor perhaps the last who have cut their own throats.

It would be intensely interesting Ito see a balance sheet showing thc debit and credit of the .Dutch ship- ping ban. On the debit side il has been shown that it has re- sulted in holding up Australian goods purchased for the N.E.L to the value of over £5,000,000. What lt has meant in loss of wages to watersiders, seamen and transport workers, as well as in port dues, fuelling and victualling expenses, and the dozen and one other avenues of commerce associated

with the overseas shipping trade, is beyond computation, but it probably ran into a larger aggre- gate amount than the £5,000,000 worth of goods.

?As to the credit side, it is diffi- cult to see where tho gains come in. That it helped the Indonesians in the slightest degree in gaining the measure of independence they have achieved is most questionable. If anyone can show a gain it is the Communists, who instigated the ban. They can hardly be blamed if they feel they have emerged with a sense of heightened stature. It cannot be escaped that, whilst three Governments were striving for the lifting of the embargo, the final say-so rested with the officials of a union. That leaves the door open for similar occurrences later

on. .

Apart from these considerations it should be gratifying to Aus- tralia, as it is welcome to the Dutch and Indonesians, to. see the ban lifted. Self-interest alone advances every reason why this country should establish and maintain the friendliest relations, commercial and otherwise, with our nearest and biggest neighbour in I the near west. On commercial grounds it is acknowledged that the NEI offers a wide field for the disposal of our primary products [and manufactured goods, and it is

a market that should be retained

I when, through competition, we may

have lost some of our more distant {footholds. We are fortunate that

this market has not already been I irretrievably lost, but that does not appear to be the case. All

will be glad that the agreement . reached on Friday closes an inci- ! dent from which this country can

take little credit.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, JUNE 9, 1947. BAN LIFTED

. THURSDAY, JUNE 12, 194T.

METEOROLOGICAL MISCEL-

LANY

Taking over the . coila tion and public presentation of the weather pf >» continent, v\f rpm six. States which had brought, the service to varying degrees of aévelopment, wa* a job that, dealing with tone of the main environmental-forming factors, called foi- both vision and enterprise. That' it got neither iras due to several causes, not the least of which ws> there being in Australia "nb well-developed en- vironmental sense.' Surrounded as

they are with impressive evidence of its powerful- influence upon all

forms of. life, few people have even

a «oiei^i.ap^éiiêtion of either the^ presence " ör^" potency '6T en-

vironment. Three Australian ge»

erati^na'rhao^ bë^Éij so intimately assoeiated1 ^th mining, where the state ol thé weather mattered only incidentally, that meteorology was regarded popularly as more of a fad than, as,a seripuststuUy, :a. job for ; &m*ighted> «eera and - mouldy prophets. Beyond-'derision at the failure ^.meteorologists to gratify everyone'jj taste for weather, the Méíwrologícal" Department ; cut a small figure '- in 'the :i public , mind, nor has -it »enhanced that position greatly-if «t- all.

The. policy-.of ¿the Meteorological Départaient fa JhnV out from the vulgar gazer the -workings of those mighty ekijnents. that give to people their weather, "being what it ia, the result is-not surprising. But it is very unfortunate. Politicians, too^Jiad- and ^at%i»ve :;a Jaw esti- mate; oaths' ivalwi' of .jifeteo&iögy,

pM^eiiÍ^ó^^^^¿»st 4ö years

with an Average Expenditure that was=sufficient to give fl worth of weather information tq every 222 of population, or to every £6500 worth of primary production, or to everyv< 48,290 acres of occupied »nd or. to every 621 acres of land under, crop. It-would appear from this grudging dowry that the poli- ticians were either indifferent to the Australian environment as it

is influenced hy weather, or else . they knew nothing whatever about it «Seither the Meteorological De-

partment' -nor^«b».vpoÜt«»ñ-; ^«-^^^ proving1 ^reaîïy.î. on .ij^^vbi^^l ; performances: _. V

. Soon ,after its creation, the Meteorological Department. "di- vided Australia for climatological and meteorological purposes' iní» five divisions" with capital : in each. These divisions. <Ud; n°t fjpl low; State .boundaries^ v^d did not appear to find favour even in the

eyes of their ci^tof^érthey Boom faded .from 'ofl^UtlV^ren^ds. Tlfe; department then proceeded to cut! up Australia ., into ; just on .100" meteorologic^. .divisions as they appear today, and in the describing of these divisions called to its aid names that had the effect pf set- ting up an .entirely new .-Australia.

Of the wealth "<ä well-known Wp

name» to which is. attached either à -^community interest, ian 'historical association or a traditional affec- tion ' thé ' department used spar- ingly. Instead, it went to the com- pass for its main inspiration ».as if that instrument, its func- tions and _ readings^ ure', common- place to most Australians. '.Of the. 89 distrrctB^shown on the. monthly rainfall sheets, only 25 per cent are named geographically - only 17 per cent are so named on the monthly rainfall charts, which do not agree with either number M.names ¿f districts-the rest be- ing a confused jumble of direc- tional and relative designations that; interwoven into a polysyllabic mess, mean, little to the lay mind.

How many Queensland people would/expect, for instance, to find inland Charters Towers in the Central Coast (West) district on the, monthly rainfall sheet, or in the "West-Central Coast district .pi the monthly rainfall map? Or'ho*, many Western Australians would imagine that Geraldton is in . the South -West Division (North Coastal, sub-division) ? The latter is surely a directional medley that,' for poverty of imagination,

out-stars the classical "Second Division of the Sixth Division" of intellectual giants of Brisbane racing: circles.

Nor is títere uniformity in the districts on the sheets .-with those shown in the consolidation of data, in rainfall books, the^e being. 103. rainfall districts and '6859 rai¿' reV cording stations in rainfall books of the six. States, but >nTy 89 rain- fall districts and 1660 Tam record- ing stations on the monthly rain-

fall sheets pf those States. Of the latter, no fewer than 8.5 per cent are in metropolitan -areas, where a large part of the country is under either iron or tile--roofs.

In: the Victorian rainfall book the arrangement as to districts is based upon river basins with the rain recording stations in. alpha- betical order; but districts in the monthly sheets follow no such slavish rule either as to boundaries or alphabetical arrangement. On top of this, while the monthly rain-, fall- sheet has but eight divisions: the monthly rainfall chart has 14.

It may be here noted that, with! the sole exception- of those for Queensland, the Stations on the monthly rainfall ? .sheets are jumbled within their/divisions in happy, but unintelligible promis- cuity.

^ Had it been the amiable inten- tion .of parsimonious politicians, seconded by the Meteorological De- partment, so to jumble and confuse the publication of Australian rain- fall data that people might be prevented from learning of the vital part played by meteorological factors in the. mighty forces of Australian environment they have every reason "to be proud of ¡the

result. -Qr if the gentle purpose

was io prevent curious citizen» prying into the records of meteoro ! logical doings that shape the des-

tiny of their, own land, then the «uccesB is an outstanding one.

CDs iRormng ^ttUetin

BOCKHAîdPTQN

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 6, 1947.

I - _,_t

CHANGING MENUS

There has been considerable soul searching in Britain of late over food^ and particularly was this the case ? in regard to how pre-war menus compared with the present .meagre ration- So painful was the result that members of the Royal Economic Society in London turned back 200 years, to the days of frugal George II and the corrupt Walpole, when Englishmen abroad deplored the declension of manners at home and the roast beef of Olde

'England was a solid reality. They found that, averaged over a num- ber of years to 1937, the people of Britain were eating about 35 per cent less meat , than did their an- cestors in the days of the austere George. . .

There had been a recovery from the slump in consumption of about the middle of the 18th cen-! tury when, due no doubt to the industrial revolution which diverted

the energies of Englishmen from growing meat to tending machines,

it was less than half of that of

125 years earlier. Consumption of bread changed * but little in the two centuries, though'there had been an increase which coincided with the drop in meat consump- tion in the 186LVs. Dieticians may be able to tell us how. one off-sets the other. The consumption oi potatoes has remained practically even over . the two centuries, whereas cheese consumption in 1837 was a mere quarter of what it was and beer was down tb little better than one-third. On the other hand, consumption' of both milk and tea increased considerably. It seems, on the surface anyhow, that consumption of most home-grown products vheld its own, but that refrigeration, - vastly improved transport and distribution not-, withstanding imported commodities have not made up the shortage of home'products due to greater in- dustrialisation and the growth of population.

It scfemè easy to speculate thusly on the reasonB for so radical a

change of diet in Britain-until we coiné to examine what has . hap . pened over the past 20 years in our own land. The two points of ?comparison are closer than in the case bf Britain, CQmprising as they do the. five-year average to 1921 and the. five-year average to 1941, this being à clear interval of 20 years. The result bf the comparison -is that, of 14 staple food commodi-

ties si? showed considerable in- crease ¿üi the consumption, per head of/population, end eight showed almost 4» great decreases.

Odd as it ' may seem, beer con- sumption was down by 2 per. cent, and «that'despite the -fact that the average age of the community is much higher-and presumably thirstier-now £ban it was 20 years ago. But ,±he" consumption of make, , oats, rice and wheat was down by

38, 49; 17 and Í0 per cent re- spectively, or by ¡15 percent in the aggregate: These 'aré -''the major food grains, source of carbohy- drates or the element lu diet which supplies energy. Wte ate 12 per cent itewer potatoes, 9 .per cent fewer onions and drank 8 per cent lesa tea and coffee. Only that fewer people use tobacco than imbibe these drinks it might be said that an increase ,of 26 per cent in the consumption of tobacco more than offset, this diminished intake ol these stimulante. Anyway, nature's adjustments are not always quite so simple. Nor is the answer to bc found in the 40 per cent increase in barley consumption, for even with this increase against the de- crease in consumption of the othei four grains, barley forms less that 10 per cent of the total grain in- take. Well may . we ask if ' thii generation is less energetic that -the last, - only that the relevani generation is just arriving.

On the other side of the scab and additional to . barley and to- bacco, consumption of butter anc 'cheese went up by 20 per cent, thai of fresh milk by 21 per cent, thu of all meat by . 19 per cent and tba of sugar by 6 per cent. The strik ing point about this group is tba they form the main protein producing agents and proteins, a everybody knows, are "essentii constituents of the living cell," an must be supplied in the diet t make good tissue wastage and als to allow of growth. In addition t proteins, both butter and mil contain essential minerals that ca be imbibed in no way so satisfac torily as through these foods.

Here we have the remarkabl fact that over the past 20 yeal the Australian people have s changed their diet a« to take i considerably lesa energj-iupplyin food, and on the other hand t take in. considerably more protei or body-forming or repairing foo« Another surprising fact is that thi has come about voluntarily and nc as, in the case of Britain, throug inability to obtain the foods < which we have eaten less. Of tt 14 commodities in the list tl main stimulants are tea, coff« and tobacco and they are mostl imported. The carbohydrate, ar protein-forming foods are ali pr duced abundantly in Australia, s we are confroated with the pro] lem of why a whole commuait of its own volition and free choic has turned in one generation fro: energy-producing food to proteú building food. It can be cia imf with some degree of assurance thi for young, growing people the 1* diet is a marked improvement upc that of 1921, and it is even bett< for grown people where the ma' need is to make good tissue was

age.

So we come to the questioi Will the generation arriving BU sequent to 1941 be in better bodi nick, but with less energy thi the generation that was' growii up in 1921 ? It seems easy '

answer that question if only fCM be taken into account but-îfoth nature does not always work

arithmetical progression, though wiH be worthwhile in view of tï changed menu to wait-and watt
