articleText:
«je jftorning jBnUettn

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, JANUARY 10, 1947.

ROAD. MATTERS

- The comprehensive statement o road projects as affecting Rori hampton made by the Coordinate)] General this week sets out prett well ell that this district ca: expect in Main Roads Commissio works for some time to come Whether we will get all that wa listed-remains to be seen. Wha departmental heads go touring wit] Minister« in an election year it i safe not to build too heavily oi promises until the goods commend

to be delivered.

. Even after making this allow ance it must he admitted tba there is a. lot of road work in ham and contemplated, and" no tangiWi obstacle stands in the way of il being carried through, althougl there are factors which may cauei delay. They were mentioned bi Mr Kemp and they can be appre dated. One of them is a lack ol sufficient technical staff to take ii hand all the work which the Com' mission would, like to. get on with

Another is shortage and high cosí of materials. Bitumen is indispen sable to high class road construc-

tion and bitumen is three timet

the price in 1038, and that mud harder to get, since all countries are competing for it. It is of som« interest to note that the Queen» land Main Roads Commission û

Reeking to substitute concrete sur facing for bitumen to the extent it ¿an without encroaching , on cement supplies for building purposes. U concrete could be used at compar- able coat it would be very encourag- ing for Central Queensland, which has aspirations to ultimately have a cement industry.of its own.

"¡As ' emphasised by the .deputa- tion which waited on the Treasurer and. Ctöordinator-General, Rock hampton's main : concern in the

matter of roads is to have a-first

class nign%^a^ lining tb^ Central wîià- the^Seifl^herB^lbid Norther*

Divisions and to see1 that tie in- land; regions are^ " given similar access to fthe coast. TTntil there is an all bitumen (or. concrete) road between Rockhampton and Bria bane' we cannot hope i» see that volume Of. motor -traffic setting i» for £he North Which we have a right to look forward to, especially in.-the winter tourist season. Until the road is immeasurably improved a motor: trip to Mackay must continue to be a nightmare, under token 'only by those who cannot

avoid it.

On the word of the, Coordinator*

General improvement- is on ' the way in both matters. Work is pro- gressing on southern'flections, par- ticularly in the Gladstone and Calliope areas, which must have a big influence. on road communica- tion with the- South. As to >the northern- highway £80,000 per annum is to be spent for the next six years on the road system be- tween Rockhampton and Sarina. That is an impressive sum and I should hasten the day when th«

terrors of the northern road trip wÜl ^disappear.

Nearer home, the Coordinator General listed works now in hand

or projected which meet many ot the complaints now current about the Mt Mprgan-Dululu and Rockhampton-Westwood connexions

Steps also are to be taken to ra-j

store the Rodchampton-Yeppoon I road, now . stewing, ^feigns of badly wearing. It is to be regretted that Mr Blemp had to ref er to the last lap of the Yeppoon-Emu Park coast road as something still awaiting final plans and arrange- ments with the Livingstone Shire Council for ifs completion. It is doubtful if any .other

section of road in the central division-not excluding the notor- ious Bajool Flats - has even brought upon the head of the Main Roads Commission more wide- spread criticism. This most used and most popular road in the dis-

trict was left in the condition of an ornate residence completed in every, detail excepting the> back steps, for which packing cases had

been substituted. No amount of complaint or representation has been able to get that mile of road finished, yet, it could have been done probably in a matter of weeks if the Main Roads Depart- ment had been serious about it. By the promptness with which it is mow attended to ' will" very largely be measured the sincerity of the assurances given by the Coor- dinator-General and the Treasurer concerning road undertakings gen- erally at this interview.

Certain general remarks made by

the Coordinator-General are worth

noting. The present priorities are to be observed so that there will be little roora for the introduction ef new projects. That would seem to throw into the background tourist roads to the Berserkers and file Blackdown Tableland and per- haps the projected Port Alma road also.. That does not mean they must be discarded altogether. Road building" will not come to an end when ute present connexions arel put through. On the contrary, a

big organisation will havs built j np, oontalafaif adsquata tachnioal'

staff and equipment, and they will find employment on projects no less desirable if at present less urgent for the district's advance- ment. In the meantime it is for I local interests to see that the pro- gramme laid out this week is not I allowed to lapse through prevent 1 able causes.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1947.

LABOUR DEFENCE

In practically the one breath the Chifley Government made two im- portant defence pronouncements. One waa a decision to spend £50. 000,000 per annum for the next five years on one sort of defence or another, and the other was a re- iteration that nobody who had no appetite for the responsibilities of defence-other,; of course, than in picking up good money in a reserve occupation with full liberty to Btrike and sabotage the whole structure, of defence at will-is under no obligation to bother his head about defence one way or another.

One of these statements is the

negative of the other, and" - the Curtin-Chifley combination proved it quite easy to spend a terrific amount of money and get mighty little defence in return. The shameless outpouring of colossal sums of money for negligible re- turn, the impudent boastings of vast achievements when whole Australian armies never left the mainland, the amMiug cost of ship6, of machine-gun carriers, of tanks and of every form of mili- tary equipment make up a classical story of blunder and brag , that has yet to be told. It i« recalled at .this stage to- indicate,- under Labour administration, how very little defence is to be got for even £50,000,000-per annum. On the other side, of the picture is the fact that it is possible to spend many times . that sum per annum and still have in- sufficient manpower to use the war equipment. If everybody stays behind to spend the £50,000,000 and there is nothing to prevent them so doing-spending it at all for howsoever much return is sheer

lunacy. On top of Australia's shockingly poor showing in the war-equipment field, is the fact that she was the only combatant that did not t»nseript-the whole bf

the . man . and woman, power to serve wherever most needed.

Not eyen the grim leesons pf the just-past war were able to expand the dwarfed outlook of the ALP in regard to defence. Nor has the changed set-up in Asia, with not tens but thousands of millions of Asiatics all surging forward to- wards nationhood shaken the ALP out of its benighted isolationism. The whole world conscripted into arms leaves the ALP still bogged down in academic discussion on the rights of man, even though one of the most starkly taught lessons of the last 30 years is that the only rights worth talking about are those which man is prepared to defend. The theory that'' voluntary defence produced the cream of the nation's fighters ig shattered by the invincible conscript armies of Britain and America; by the dauntless, resourceful-conscripts of Germany; and by the indomitable fighters of the Red Army. Hitler's conscripts over-ran practically the whole of Europe; Montgomery's conscript armies' chased , the dour fighting Rommel and his conscripts

out of North Africa: Eisenhower's conscripts drove the Huns out of Baris; while Stalin's conscripts held the cream of Hitler's armies out of Leningrad and Stalingrad. The heaviest fighting was done by conscripts and thrown back by other conscripts. German con- scripts scattered the defences of Belgium and France and turned the Maginot .Line, while Allied conscripta, shattered Germany's Siegfried Line and blasted the way to Berlin. It appears that the ALP has not pieced up these recently written pages of gory history but is snoring like Rip van Winkle, back in the days when no gentle-

man started a war without first giving a full week's notice.

No special pleading or specious argument, no ' passionate ranting of inherent human rights, no ethi- cal brain-storms on the solemn duties of men-including hair-trig- ger aggressors-can upset the ver- dict of history of immediate, bloody history; but it is unlikely that the grim implications of these things have permeated the mental fastnesses of the ALP. If Mr Chif-

ley knows of these happenings he knows better than to pit his know- ledge against the mental black-out of the .ALP.

In the face of these incontrovert- ible facts the Chifley statement, fresh..from the senile groves of the Trades Hall, that Australia's de- fence is to be purely voluntary, is the essence of hypocrisy, the most shameless skulking behind the armour of our allies. Voluntary de- fence has for the past half cen- tury been at the fore-front of ALP gospel, and because of it the Scullin /Government abolished compulsory military training in 1932. The voluntary defence policy of the Curtin-Chifley survived even so devastating a war as that just closed, but it was so justified in 1942 only by the conscripts of

America.

Protesting, blustering Australian delegates at every conference they attend, a system of voluntary de- fence, and Sydney watersiders moulding Australia's policy make up the sorry picture which we pre jsent to the outside world. It is a [depressing picture, but it is the

best that Canberra showmen seem capable of showing.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, JUNE 16, 1947. LABOUR DEFENCE

articleText:
Olje Womina JMferin

HOCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, AUGUST 18, 1847.

CUMULATIVE EFFECTS

Over many years there have been warnings as to the injurious effect, not only on rural industry but on tho general economy of the Com- monwealth, of the "drift to the city," the rising costa to, producers brouht about by each fresh wage increase and hours curtail- ment for city workers, the repres- sive taxation and rural labour dif- ficulties. Almost daily there is a complaint or warning about one Or other of these things; but very »rely has auf one gone to . the length of pointing out what should long ago have been obvions to what is sometimes called "the meanest intelligence" that ail of these things sooner or later most have a cumulative effect of a moat disagreeable character. Now, with th» unexpectedness of a bolt from the blas comes the first authentic indication that the cumu-

lative effects of the ill-usage accorded our primary industries

ara about to be felt.

Last week, without any warning that such . step was contemplated, a pronouncement wa* made by the Commonwealth Minister for Com- merce that all export of beef and dairy cattle from Australia would forthwith be banned, except by permit. He explained that, whilst

thia did not constitute a total embargo, permite to export would be issued only in extreme cases and after a thorough "investigation of the applications. Ag to the reason for such a drastic measure, Mr Pollard said that Australia is faced with an argent need to build np her stocks ox dairy and beet cattle aa quickly aa possible. The Government had a duty to ensure that there was a plentiful supply Of stock in Australia to produce food for Britain and to provide stock for soldier settlers now tak- ing np land. Until this was achieved tho export of cattle needed in Australia could not be

permitted. The Minister, confessed to alarm at the radncedireduction of dairy herds, particularly in Northern New Sooth Wales.

He could easily have extended his alarm to embrace the beef

herds and the sheep flocks. Start- ling as it is in its general effect, the moat striking thing about the Ministerial statement ia the acknowledgement which it con- veys that there has taken place an alarming drop in the numbers of Australian beef and dairy cattle {and likewise of sheep) upon which the economy ahd prosperity of the nation is largely dependent. It is true that for a long "time there has been no lack of warning that tins very thing was occurring, but the warnings went unheeded by the Government and, most of all, by Australia's urban population.

Yet, the disclosure should cause no surprise. It is common know- ledge that, for many years, stock owners have been compelled, by ruinous taxation, to withhold mar- ketable stock until the next finan- cial year, often to see them lose condition ahd value through ad- verse seasons. Bather than repeat the experience they have curtailed their herds. In other words, the grazing industry has been dis- couraged from producing to its maximum capacity. Thia has been going on for years, but no attempt was made to remedy it. Yet some- one in authority must have been assailed by a fear that all was not well with the stock industry. Latterly there has been an inten- sive survey by departmental offi- cers, the first fruits thereof being this embargo. It will be surprising if there is not more to follow,

.ince no sane person can imagine that the retrogression is confined to beef and dairy cattle.

The Minister for Commerce says the embargo is necessary "in order to provide Australia with a suffi, dent number of stock to give Britain an adequate supply of food." He could have gone further and emphasised that it is not only Britain's food supply that is at stake, but that of Australia's town and city population as well. If, for reasons of his own, the Minister has refrained from

pointing to the logical conclusion of the present trend of rural in- dustry, there are others who have not been go reticent. Speaking at the Queensland local Authorities' [Conference last week, a delegate ¡from Rosenthal Shire uttered a pertinent warning as to what i might happen in the future. He

I said, that people were leaving the

i land because of uncongenial condi- tions, and if ihe drift were not ! stopped the time would come, within five years, when there I would be a serious shortage of

butter, milk and cheese. If such ! things happened the conditions I they would create in the cities would accomplish more in three months than all the protests and pleadings of the man on the land had produced in scores of years.

Lest this be regarded as a lone voice croaking in the wilderness, the same sentiment found more

pungent expression about the

same time from the President of the New Sonth - Wale« Farmers and Settlers' Association in his annual address to the organisation. He said that if ever the time came when Australia's rural population: demanded the right to share in the | alleged standard of living enjoyed] by the urban population, thei nation would be brought to dfsas-i

^I

ter and the population of the cities would starve. Immediately the 40-! hour week and other spurious social advantages were applied to the primary industries that would he the end of the chapter-the whole lot of us would starve. The people of the cities would be moon- ing round the place like dumb stupid cattle looking for something

to eat.

A pessimistic flight of fancy, it will be said. Nothing like that could ever be allowed to happen in this country. Maybe not. But there is no getting round that fall- ing off in sheep and cattle numbers which has stung someone in the national Government into action. Yet, these things will not be cured by embargoes on the export ol cattle on the hoof or by meat rationing at home. The only cure is to restore the pastures to full production by encouraging graz ier<3 to increase their flocks and I herds rather than reduce them a; j they are now forced to do. Ipi provement of conditions of living in rural areas must be brought about so that country people wil not seek the first opportunity t< desert the Und. And thu must be done speedily or the thing! predicted will become as real ai the export embargo and mea1 rationing, both of which wen quite as remote a few years back

articleText:
jttormng bulletin ;

ROCKHAMPTOX

S ATI JR DAY, OCTOBER 25, 1947.

THE EISTEDDFOD.

All this week, from Monday to Saturday inclusive, and from 8.3C a.m. till late at night, a majority of Rockhampton's juvenile popula- tion and a (Considerable percentage of its adult*, to the exclusion . of everything else have been pre- occupied with a local eisteddfod. Contrary to any impression that might reside with the uninitiated the interest in the proceedings has mounted rather than flagged, a circumstance suggesting that this form of competitive entertainment possesses something that puts it in a place apart from anything of

similar character. Whatever it is it has nothing to do with material gain. The prizes are merely nom- inal and those who devote them- selves to conducting the sessions see nothing but long hours of arduous labour, -and no rewards beyond that which enrich a labour

of love.

The enthusiasm with which this and other communities have thrown themselves into the eistedd- fod, Little Theatre, orchestral and similar movements affords testi- mony that seven year« of submis- sion to regulation and regimenta- tion-together with some current trends in the same direction-heve not robbed ordinary human beings of their desire for self expression. That impulse in itself, -whether or not it wins a competition, is one of the things of greatest value that an eisteddfod can call forth. Win- ners of contests at eisteddfodau have often gone on to world fame; but the losers, if they have been encouraged to make beauty for themselves, have gained equally. It is too easy today to abandon personal effort, to sit back and watch others excel, to listen whilst others make music per medium of the gramophone disc and the radio.

One of the most disturbing charges against the Australian today is that he is a spectator rather than a player of games, and his physical development is pre- judiced thereby. If that were true and the same malady were to spread to cultural Things ours

would indeed be a lost1 race. The eisteddfod movement in this coun-

try provides encouraging testi-

mony that such is not ' the case. Apart from all else eisteddfodau keep alive the tradition of good music in a world of fluctuating values and brings home to the mind of ordinary citizens a realisa- tion that human beings can ex- press themselves per médium of thia vehicle and are made better citizens by doing so.

It is questionable if a great number of the people who derive benefit and pleasure from an eisteddfod are well acquainted with its history beyond tile fact that it is something that emanated from Wales, though there is no more fascinating and romantic story associated with mankind's climb from barbarism than the

part which music has played and the everlasting debt which is owed

to the Welsh on that account.

The first eisteddfod of which any account has descended was held on the banks of the Conway in the sixth century, under the auspices of a prince of North Wales. On that occasion swimming appears to have got mixed up with the music, but like oil and water at a subse- quent date it was found that the two did not mix. In order to prove the superiority of vocal ^>ng over instrumental music, tue prince

offered a reward to such bards and minstrels as should first swim the Conway. There were several com- petitors, but on their arrival on the opposite shore the harpers found themselves unable to play owing to the injury their harps had sustained from the water, whilst the bards were in as good a tune as ever. It proved the prince's point, though his manner of doing so may not have been quite beyond question. Since then the swimming carnival and the musical festival have been kept separate, which is perhaps as well. It is doubtful if Rockhampton could sustain a six-day eisteddfod if it involved a number of swim- ming events on the Fitzroy to cor- respond with the vocal and instru- mental items.

?During the 56-year reign of Griffith ap Cynan the eisteddfod flourished in Wales. Born in Ire- land the prince brought with him from that country many Irish musicians who are credited with having greatly improved the music

of Wales. It was at this time that there was framed the first code of laws for the better regulation of the contests between bards, harp- ers and minstrels, many of whom came from Scotland and England, On the annexation of Wales to England Edward 1 deemed it poli- tic to sanction the bardic eistedd- fod and during successive reigns eisteddfodau were held from time to time by Royal commission. For 130 years after 1681, during a period when Welsh nationality wa6 at its lowest ebb, no general eisteddfod on a large scale was held in Wales until 1S19. At the

close of the Napoleonic wars there ¡ was a general revival of Welsh nationality. A large eisteddfod was

held under distinguished patronage j at Carmathen and from that time I a national eisteddfod has been reg- ularly held together with numer- ous local gatherings.

Moreover it is something that has spread to other countries and tp none more than Australia, not- withstanding that Welsh commun- ities ar«» not especially numerous herc The popularitv of the eistedd- fod as we know it-in detail it probably has departed widely from the Welsh idea though the general principle is observed-is not due to racial attachments, but rather be- cause it is something that meets the desire for self expression in- herent in huroân beings, regardless of country, creed or se*.

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, NOVEMBER 18, 1947.

CANBERRA JITTERS

Perhaps the most puzzled folk today are those who, follow- ing patiently the debate on the Chifley Banking Bill, are ; trying to discern some m sug-

gestion regarding the purpose to which the Chifley Government will pat the bank monopoly if-or when-it gets it. The sudden dis- location of the banking arrange- ments of over 90 per cent of th* people of Australia, who will have none of the Commonwealth trad-

ing bank, would be by far the big- gest thing that ever hit Australia, and would have been eclipsed only by the npBet had the Japanese hil

us. Yet one Government mern bei

after another rose, spoke and sat down without disclosing any hint of Government banking policy when once the private banks an closed against depositors who sever used any other. Quotations .there were in abundance ranging a« far back aa William of Orange to as recently as trying to atea) the thunder of the Major Douglas show ; bot. as to the banking policy of the proposed monopoly

bank there wa« an iron curtain of

silence tba J" no amount of adroit probing by Opposition questioning could pierce. Not only were the people of Australia asked whether or not they want a politically con trolled monopoly bank, but nobody ? has oven at this late stage been

able to find out the purpose for which.Mr Chifley is trying to foist it upon us.

' On the other hand, no Govern- ment speaker thought ' to touch upon the "monstrous robbery" perpetrated by Charlea H upon the trust funds of London goldsmiths, which led to the, establishment nf the Bank of England upwards of SOO years ago. Since that time no monarch and no Parliament in Britain has had control of the finance» of government even ap- proaching that which wu betrayed by Charles DI, and nowhere ont sida of dictate^ countries has an»

Parliament of free men had tibe power which the Chifley Govern- ment is now proposing to take.

The reason for that is element- ary. The monarch that control« the banka ia independent of both his advisers and his subjects and tba Parliament that controls the banks may snap its fingers at the people who elect it, while the pri- vate banks under single control would be no better than either, ll ell the evil things said by Chifley stooges of private banks were trues they would still not be cured by : giving, the banking -business of : 7,800,000 people into the hands oí

a political coterie that, in this in- stance, is bossed by union pressure gronos that are in torn dominated by Communists. In human history, which ssw vast nations built up under the. impulse of private enter- prise, ito single fact stands out more prominently than that when once, the common' people lose con- trol of thfe national finance they cease to be free, or to enjoy any of the amenities of free men. '.

Well-infpnned men have no hesi- tation in saying ' that the reason

tho Chifley a yea-men w filled Han- sard with quotations, when speak- ing on the Bank Bill, that gave no indication of the policy of the proposed bank monopoly, is that they know no more of it than they disclosed in their speeches-^which was nothing. That is also the reason for their side-stepping awk- ward questions of bank policy. Xt is au open secret that Caucus ia following Chifley blindly, in part because Caucus is largely Commu-

nist and would shed no tears if

the Chifley set-up was discredited, and in part because Mr Ghifley'a confidants are practically all out- side both Caucus and Cabinet. Timid "yes-men " are asking, petulantly, if the Bank Bill ia so impregnable that the présenos in Australia of the. shrewd Dr ?Evatt is not essential either to its enactment or its implemen- tation ; or can he see what is com- ing and. is keeping clear of the bump ! He is too good a " lime lighter" to miss voluntarily the glad hosannas that will signalise the successful slaying of the lust private bank, and the f'yes-men" want to know what it. is that keeps him in foreign lands, when the ALP has on its hands the fight oí its life. Few of them believe that subjugation of the private hanks ie going to be. quite as easy as has been made to appear, but hav- ing trusted Mr Chifley BO far they have no alternative but to go on! trusting hin», even with the know- ledge that if he goes down they will go with him.

Meanwhile, Mr Drakeford is stated to be awaiting advice on his constitutional power^ to deny to Ansett Airways use of Govern- ment -airports because it stubbornly refuses to increase fares at the behest of the Department of Civil Aviation that has already in- creased them on Government air- lines. It appears that Ansett Air ways is eliminating most of its amenities so as to meet increasing costs without raising, fares, and public support ' is surely the best test of whether the service being rendered by Ansett meets publae needs. It is new to- the function of rendering Service to the com- munity that a Federal Minister should launch a punitive - expedi- tion against a miscreant that re- fused to take from the public more than he needed, but it has quite a brisk dictatorial flavour about it.

In a dumb, trusting, kind of way many supporters of the Bank Bu) hope that it will mean the end of slumps end the beginning of less work and more easy money for political, believers. They blind their eyes to the fact that when i Labour in Australia wa« all out

for the 40-hour week Joseph of [ Moscow increased the length of the working week to 48 hours, and he has a "nationalised" bank at his beck and call. Whether Joseph's serfs got their 48-hour week be-

cause of the nationalised bask or

despite it is a' point worthy of consideration by blind followers of the Chifley fantasy -m but just as Joseph's serfs hád no say in the matter, neither does it. appear that I the Chifley dupes will have "uufch

1 to say in the banking monopoly Í either.

articleText:
fcf)£ mtning Bulletin

MONDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1947

CHRISTMAS COMES ...

.'Christmas comes hot once a year, and when it does it brings good cheer." So ran the old nursery

rhyme, but true as it may have j been in the past, today it calls for

radical amendment. This is the third Christmas since VP Day. If in the joyous days that marked the first

war-free Christmas in seven years

anyone had predicted that two years later wartime rationing of many of the common necessities of life would continue, that Christmas goods would be dearer and in shorter supply, and that the com- munity would be facing depriva- tions as severe as any imposed dur- ing the war they would have been looked upon as having taken leave of their senses, especially if they had added that these things would occur in spite of Australia .enjoying an unexampled period of prosperity due to record prices for her com- modities and the highest rate of employment known.

Yet it is the simple fact; No-one expected a return to anything ap- proaching normal conditions at that first Christmas after the war clouds lifted, for the reason that demobilisation had hardly com- menced and no move had as yet been made to switch the industrial machine from á war to a' peace- time economy. "Next year it will be different and we will have every- thing we could want," was the comforting assurance people offered

to. themselves. Nest Christmas came but there was .still a striking ab- sence of all the things which hitherto had been associated with the festive season. Excuses were not wanting-shortage of man- power and materials, war weariness and so on. "Never mind/' . people said, "wait till next year, surely things will have settled down by then and we will see a real old-time Christmas once more." Next year has come round and the things as- sociated not only with Christmas but with daily existence are scarcer than ever; and, what is worse, very much* dearer. Even the Rockhamp- ton Trades and Labour Council has noticed that. At * meeting of dele- gates held- last week the Executive was instructed to call a meeting of all unionists in Rockhampton early in the New Year to protest against the recent increase in the cost of living.

But if tiie shelves in the stores

are comparatively bare of goods and prices are steadily mounting, the' two and a half years that have elapsed since VP Day have been marked by what we are assured are great "improvements" in the lot of the people, so that the war was not fought and won in vain. Thé 40-hour week has been achieved, substantial increases made in the basic wage and marginal rates, conditions in the workshops "improved," so much that produc dnction per unit is down as much as 40 per cent in some cases com- pared with pre-war; pensions have increased, and social services ex- panded until they promise to eat up most of the public revenue 1 within a year or two.

The fly i& the omtmeñt is, that there is an insufficiency of goods required by the community and what there are have price tags "that make it difficult for ordinary people to acquire them. Christmas- tide is nerhaps not the best season to start preaching cause and effect in matters of this kind, but in view of the meeting of unions

which the Executive of the TLC is to convene in the New Year, it might do no harm to mention them so that the delegates may ruminate upon the subject during the holi- days, ? especially when they take note of the things now missing from their Christmas table which were there in abundance before the 40-hour week and go-slow on the job were even visualised:

In New South Wales it is claimed that the 40-hour week has raised the cost of running the State Bailways by £2,500,000 per ¡ annum, whilst output per man has

fallen to 65 per cent of the 44-hour ¡week output Private business executives also say that a drop in output is observable in some in dustries^ far greater than the pro- portion'of hours reduction. This

runs-somewhat counter to the con- tention of union leaders that the shorter working week must lead to greater rather than to lesser pro- duction per unit.

What are the reasons? One is the notion prevalent in certain militant union circles that to go slow and spin out the job makes it last longer and improves the chances of employment, for others. To give them credit this fallacy is exposed by capable labour lead- ers within and outside of Aus- tralia. There is only one way to make employment for all and pro- vide cheaper living and higher standards, and that is to produce more and not less of the goods that constitute real wealth, and so banish shortages, reduce the cost of living and put real money in the family purse. To slacken effort and produce less is the surest method of

increasing prices and keeping the shelves of the stores bare, not only at Christmas, but at all times.

At ' Christmas 1945 practically everyone said it would be better j next year. At Christinas 1946 they said surely we would be back to something like .old times at the end of another year. At Christmas 1947) they are doubting whether things'

will be any better\next year; in fact, some are seriously doubting that they ever again will see a Christmas of the old pre-war, vint

jftge. These are some aspects of the

problem which the unions and the Trades and Labour Council should discuss. A great many people who are not members of unions, but are equally concerned about th« rise in cost of living, will be interested in

their findings and what they pro- pose to do about it. Entering a protest will not do much towards remedying things, unless it is di- rected to. those who are the guiding lights in Australia's industrial affairs today.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, DECEMBER 22, 1947 CHRISTMAS COMES...
snippet: "Christmas comes hot once a year, and when it does it brings good cheer." So ran the old nursery rhyme, but true as it may have

articleText:
Vdt Jitarning Snlletin

ROCKHAMPTON.

TUESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1947.

THIS CHRISTMAS

Christmas is not what it was. That much we know from personal

observation, as well as from the testimony of our parents and grandparents«who also had like authority for believing that, even in their day, Christmas was an infinitely poorer show than it was in some , remote, unspecified period when Christmas waits ventured abroad , in London's unlighted un- sanitary streets to serenade the principal inhabitants " and accept aa reward whatever might come their way, from a share of the * principal inhabitants'' " . good cheer to being waylaid by '* pyckeres and pillers " and plun- dered of their earnings. That era left the not-so "principal inhab- itants" to » wattless Christmas of their own devising, and history is silent regarding how they* fared.

The troth, of course, is that our \ concepts of old-time Christmases are based upon its observances in Great Britain, round which are centred some ill-formed nostalgic yearnings. But since then the Christmas festival' A&s spread all

over the globe,* a« no other festi-¡ val based upon any philosophy,

known to man has ever done or shows signs -of doing. It has im-

pressed itself upon people of many languages . it has impinged upon climatic conditions ranging from " frigid to torrid j if ranges the high;seas «adv hies unto sub*

marines in which it betakes itself beneath their turbulent surfaces in

"def ence "of the faith that gave -ft] birth ; it flourishes on mountain tops and on plains, *» well as up on the mighty highways reserved hitherto to migratory birds.

: But these amazing ramifica-' tiona notwithstanding, the . spirit of its observance is changed not at all for being enjoyed by im- ' mensely more people. Indeed, so firmly is the Occasion fixed in the human mind that nothing bas shifted it from one part of the «alendar to another) io as to fix it in some Elysian climate mid- way between the ravages of frost- bite and sunstroke. Surrendering

no atom of this most-beloved of jail Bible stories man has accom- modated his climate and his cir- cumstances to the calendar,- and if it liked to roast* or freeze him,

or to bedeck his Christmas with holly or with frangipani, or to Present him "with. Nature in hiber Hiation Ot m wild profusion, with

ce-skatíng or surfing and, that troubled hint not at all. Obviously, whether or not he knows it, man attaches spiritual rather than a nnteriftUttio value upon Christ-

inas, and allows neither the best nor the worst that 'all-powerful Mother- Nature can do to cloud his faith.

An unsuspected balancing fac- tor in thia insistence that Christ- ina« is pot what it was is / the fact that, on the average, indivi- duals now" enjoy nearly a third

more of them than they did. In

jtHe H ..'years to 193¿ man's *x pectation.of life increased by" 3i <jper cent from 4t&- years to 63.5: years, while that of woman in- creased by 32 per cent from 505 years to 67.1 years> and it is prob- ably higher; m~~T)otb caséis now. ?Surely enjoyment of an , average Of ; 16 more - Christmas days than the generation of less, than half a century ago enjoyed is 4 pretty substantial get-off against' the : fancied declension of the Christmas festival, for it means in the ag- gregate «o very much more . joy «nd happiness on earth. On the other hand, man may want to know» why it is that he enjoys on an average only 94 per cent of the Christmas-tides that woman does, but beyond recording that inter- esting fact, that matter is outside the scope of these reflections. But he can surely rejoice /with woman

that whereas 13 children out ?of

hvàcx 100 horn -ai' th« beginning of the century died ere reaching their; first birthday, only slightly more , than three so die ww, for, after all^ Christmas ' is essentially

children's season, and while fewer children .are appearing on tba earth, we do manage tb save many 'more of those that come to jive among us. .

But an end to dry-even if re vealing-statistics. That people in Australia, should compare their

Christmas with that of their

kinsmen;in Great Britain, or with their ,own of today with that of their parents in Australia half a century ago, is to embark on- a ^voyage of unreality, on a sea of 'materialism. It , resolves ' itself after ali in varieties of foods and their relative costs and avail- ability, or in the quality of en . tertainment. But it leaves * un

I plumbed the vast depths of human

sentiment that centres round De-

cember 25# it takes no account of the oceans of goodwill that are expressed in messages and gifts and thoughtful acts, nor does it consider that the impressions of self-sacrifice and generous thought which are left on youthful minds are of prime importance in future character forming. At no other time in the span of human life is the mind so receptive of im- pressions, made by noble example at this season, as in that portion of it which is most influenced by the Christmas season. The hap- piness of Christmas is the happi- ness of givihg of pleasure, and he would be a very Scrooge of a man who could not trace back,>. to some event in a. long-gone Christ- mas, a tendency in himself to greater tolerance or of a more self-less generosity.

Being what it is human nature is far from perfect, but it has in addition immense capacity for being far worse than it is. Mail could revert to \ primal savagery, he could permit himself-by not exerting his Will to liberty-to

become enslaved to one form of totalitarianism or another, he could relapse into a state of sen- suous animal promiscuity ; but he does, none of these things..' With full freedom of choice man still observes Christmas, and the roll- ing tide of Christianity , grows in strength as it spread« because-in spirit-Christmas is still all, - and

even more' than it ever was»
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON. TUESDAY, DECEMBER 23, 1947. THIS CHRISTMAS

articleText:
$i* ülorntng J&ullet.n

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY. DECEMBER 27, 1947

AUSTRALIAN ORATIONS

In* a land where words cour as little as they have been

J Australian Institute of Anatom I Research. It would seem, indi

He also donated j the Commonwealth Government t ¡sum of £1000 to endow an a jnual oration, in preventive mei j cine, in order to perpetuate t

articleText:
?bc morning bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, MARCH 17, 1947

IN TROUBLE

lu its rush to get the Stevedoring Bill through Parliament the Fed- eral Government has landed itself in trouble all round, not the least with some members of its own Party. Why it should be in such a hurry to get on with the Bill is not readily discernible in view of the rumours that it will be in no mind to implement it when it does become law, and also in view of a recent recommendation by the chairman of the Stevedor ing Commission that the legislation be dropped at present. The real explanation of the Government's spurt to get the Act made law is probably the cracking of whips from outside, a never failing tonic in matters of th? 3 kind.

The passage of the Bill landed the Government into a lot of trouble arising not so much from the main objects of the measure as from gide issues. Firstly it led to something that looks perilously like an open breach between two leading ministers and their respec- tive adherents-no light matter at a time when the atmosphere is heavily charged with talk of the possibilities of a Government "split." Failing t» secure accept- ance of his wishes regarding a certain provision in the Bill Mr Ward was so wrathful with Dr Evatt that he walked out of the House and immediately left Can- berra, Such conduct by a minister towards the Deputy Leader would more often than not result in disci- plinary action; but it is unlikely to be attempted with Mr Ward, who might indeed welcome it as affording opportunity, on a favour- able battleground, to test his strength against one who is recog- nised as hig chief rival for the Prime Ministership when Mr Chifley lay8 aside the cares of

office.

Another side issue that lent par- ticular interest to the passage of the Stevedoring Bill was the Gov- ernment's rejection of the oppor- tunity offered it to make a definite

stand on Communist dictation In industrial affairs. The Opposition offered the Government an unex- ampled chance to strike a blow at the elements which are ruining Australia's shipping trade by prof- fering an amendment that "ad- mitted members of the Communist Party should be excluded from membership of or employment by the Stevedoring Commission." The words '"admitted Commu- nist" nullified Dr Evatt"g objec- tion as to who was to deter-

mine whether or not a person wag a reputed Communist. The amendment was rejected out of hand. If any further evidence should be required in proof that this Government will never have the courage to stand np against Communist influence in industrial matters, whether on the water- front or elsewhere, it was here revealed, nakedly and unas'fimed.

In the meantime Sydney is again paralysed by strike action Qn the part of the Waterside Workers' Federation. Idle ships are mounting up and terrific losses are beginning to accumulate in fresh damage to Australia's overseas trade, earn- ings, port dues and in a dozen and one ways. Waterfront strikes occur so frequently and on such varied issues that it must be din! cult even for those involved ic them to keep track of what the; are about. In a hazy kind of way the public is aware that the pre- sent hold-up has something to d< with overtime, not the rate oj payment or objection on the pari of shipowners to paying it, bui some other aspect that must strike the common sense person outsidi the Waterside Workers' Federatioi -and perhaps a good many within it-as going to the lengths oi absurdity.

The chairman of the Stevedoring Commission, which really is th< authority of the Government, in si st H that some overtime must bi worked to enable a reasonabli turn round of ships. The Water siders-or rather the troublemaker! who are leading them-say theri must be no overtime, nor shal there be any increase in the quoti of wharf labour. In brief th<

ships must wait until they ean b< loaded and unloaded.

This is where a long course o: appeasement accompanied by de dining output and mounting cost has got the waterfront industry and the end of the long lane hai by no means been reached. Thi only thing certain at this juncturi is that the Stevedoring Bill wil not cure the position on th wharves, but the events of the pas week suggest that it may have ai influence on some other -nd appal ently unrelated happenings in th industrial and political fields.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, APRIL 21, 1947.

' SOUND COUNSEL

Stimulated no doubt by current j

happenings in another connexion, there was a disposition at tne an"

nual meeting of the Chamber of Commerce to depart from the usual laudatory and optimistic tone of the speeches and to indulge in a little more frankness in relation to current problems and procedures. If some of the things said are taken in good spirit and an endeav- our is made to follow them out it would have no bad influence on the public affairs of Rockhampton.

One point of criticism offered pn the report of the work of the year was that the Chamber appeared to be expending much of its time and energies on matters that, strictly speaking, should not be the re- sponsibility of a body elepfced to

look after the interests of the commercial community. It wa« pointed out that whilst many pages of the annual report were devoted to a variety of" subjects of gen- eral interest, only four Unes were given over to what had been done about price fixing and rationing, two of the most vital questions affecting trade and commerce to- day. In singling out matters which

ware more the concern of other bodies than the Chamber of Com. maree it was suggested that the incorporation of tiie seaside re- sorts in Greater Rockhampton was something that should be left to the Local Authorities concerned,

whilst securing telephone stations for the convenience of motorists waa one for the Automobile

Clubs.

The lessons of this reproof might well be absorbed by aft publie and semi-public bodies. Lately there has been complaint of encroachment, due either to excess of «eal on the part of members of other organisa- tions pr tq there being too many as- sociations with not enough to do. There is a tendency, too, to open un new projects whilst others of long standing and of perhaps greater merit sink into abeyance. For example in the cur- rent spate of ideas as to what had beet be done to improve the ship- ping position, ranging from the Pirate Point cut to handing over the affairs of the Harbour Board to the Government, no mention is made of road connexion with and land reclatnation at Port Alma, whieh has often been offered AS tbe solution of the matter.

One thins; that never fails to be well ventilated at these annual

meetings is the apathy pf «he bueï

nMaman who fails to show an in- terest in the affairs of his city by attendanoe at meetings. Specifically % is oited tnat the Chamber itself, with 500 members, rarely raises two score at the regular meetings, and not more than 160 at the an- nual gathering. Perhaps too much strew eau be laid, on this, without excusing the lasy and apathetic and the still less défendable indi- vidual who will not attend meet- ings or take any office, but is a keen enough critic of what ia being done or attempted by others. The Chamber would have greater grounds for complaint if it had only 60 members when it should have SOO, and so long as it has ar activa executive which realises th« power that a commercial organisa tion with a membership of 50( gives them and uses it when neceg sary, the influence of the body wil not be weakened if large attend- ances axe not the regular thing. A1 the same time it would do *, loi of good to men who imagine thei bare not the time to make om night a month available for th< Chamber meeting, even if th« bowling session has to suffer, though it need not necessarily di

so.

From tbe speeches at these an nual gatherings one would ga the that the most ardent desire of th elected is that there should b keen competition for office, am that they should run the gauntle of an election. There may be les than a full measure of sincerity ii this, for if there is one thing tha gets the average person's back ut it is to bo opposed and beaten fo an elective office. He usuall; marches off in high dudgeon neve to return. Rockhampton has ha some little experience of competí tion for office in semi-public bodiei and the results have not been th happiest both as regards persons relationships and the good of th organisation concerned. That, hov ever, does not diminish the' nee for new men to come forward t take their place on public bodiei The best way of accomplishing thi is usually found to be the use of

little persuasion on the part <

older hands.

On the whole, the discussion £

this annual meeting of the Oban ber of Commerce was wholesoir. and contained more than a grai of wise counsel. Let each Iocs body concern itself with thoi things that rightly come within i sphere, and unite in those thing where cohesion is . required

achieve best results. That shoul not be a very difficult line to fo

low.

articleText:
he Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, JUNE 2, 19«.

JUVENILE DELINQUENCY

Juvenile delinquency is a sub- ject of ouch widespread concern that any discussion thereon ie as- sured of the closest attention, even in centres where it has not become a major ill. Frequent reit- eration has more or less fixed in the public mind that lack of par- ental control and slum conditions of living are the sole causes of this grave social ill, and that if parents were to spare the rod less and slum areas were to be abol- ished all would be well.

Those who are more closely as- sociated with the matter know that there are many contributing causes to child waywardness. They know, too, that preventive ^ mea- sures are neither few nor simple, but in/olve much hard work and 6kill and sympathy of others bo-, sides parents. Notwithstanding the serious attention given to the problem in many countries, how- ever, there does not appear to have' been compiled a sample

manual which would serve as a guide to those addressing them- selves to the problem wherever it may exist. That omission seems about to be rectified.

The findings of the first National

Conference for the prevention and Control of Juvenile Delinquency recently held at Washington USA, will be of great interest to other countries, including Australia. One of the first findings of the confer- ence was that ''prevention and control" primarily depend upon local action. This should prove a wholesome corrective to those who whilst acknowledging the presence of the ill and " e need for action, are content to "pasg the buck" on the plea that it is a national .ques- tion. Local action in its true sense means action in s particular locality, then the town or city i^elf, before wider responsibility can be allocated. Once the respons- ibility for local action is ac- knowledged there will be less indif- ference to the various youth wel- fare movements that, in far too many instances, are allowed to drag.

The purpose of the Washington conference was to bring together for the first time representatives of all the various agencies and or- ganisations, national, State, and local, having to do with the prob- lems of juveniles. It succeeded, in that purpose since it drew to- gether the best experience of the country, and out of the deliber- ations came recommendations for greatly accelerated programmes for controlling and alleviating the problem of juvenile waywardness and crime. The recommendations include slum clearance, better housing, broad reforms in the in- stitutional treatment of children, parental education, church partici- pation and enlargement of school

facilities to provide special help ments in the Court handling of juvenile cases and plan« for arous- ing the interest of -the entire com- munity in meeting and solving

the problem in their midst, were I brought for ard.

The reports and recommend- ations were regarded as the most comprehensive blue print ever drawn up on the subject, but it was admitted that the success of

the conference would depend upon the attitude in which communities themselves moved forward to adopt the blue print. One of the outstanding reports was that of the panel on housing, Which re- commended a national policy of low cost housing for low income groups. In this connexion it was conceded that this was not alone the responsibility of the govern- ment, but the cooperation of builders, banks and labour was sought in bringing down the cost of construction, present methods of treatment of children in train

j ing schools was renounced by the

panel on the institutional treat- ment of children. The need for complete overhaul and reform of the system was emphasised. The present training schools were scath- ingly denounced as dumping grounds where not only delinquents but the mentally ill, feeble minded, and physically ' disabled children are all thrown together.

¡ The conference, as a whole, charged itself with the respons- ibility of carrying this broader more active approach to the juve- nile problem into local communi- ties, and publicising the confer- ence reports through the local Press, radio, and motion picture facilities. Most important is that

summaries of all the conference panels are to be made available in pamphlet form and distributed on the widest possible scale.

Whilst the conference was a purely American convention it dealt with a problem that has no geographical boundaries, and mea- sures of prevention and cure could be given an equally wide applica- tion. For that reason the sum- maries and recommendations should be of great help to Aus- tralia, since they are to be got up in handy form. It will be hoped that some agency-perhaps the Commonwealth Department of In- formation which has ramifications in the United StateB-will be suf-

ficiently interested to obtain copies for distribution in this country.

Improve

articleText:
Sty* jtfonmts J^Herín

ROCKHAMPTON. . THURSDAY, AUGUST 21, 19*7

THOSE BALANCES

The last time.. Br$ajn.. "froze" surplus funds lying in London it ?wa« because they belonged to countries with ' 'Which she was either* at war or of countries friendly to. .ibero. Today . such funds as she "freezes" will belong to her friends or near-friends, and so will in the first place, reduce] trade with them to a form of bar-] ter. and will in any case direct it into channels where it will best aid

her desperate need. That «he used j

the calm before the -storm to em-

bark upon socialistic schemes which are, at best, a speculation and at worst amount to enslavement of her people, is -.- regarded - . among friends whose funds she, cannot freeze and who are in a position to render valuable, aid aa .wasting precious Assets chasing a will-o' the-wisp instead of slicking to ¡the job. ' Australia's contribution-or one of them-under, the flabby hand of the Chifley regime, is to 'plunge the country into a similar socialistic venture, to divide the 'people on a costly political issn* rather than uniting them to face

arr economic crisis.

I According to the Prime Minister our sterling balances in London amount to £280,000,000-the Com- monwealth Bank monthly Statis- tical-Bulletin for July gives the total of gold and balances held abroad as £178,000,000 and their freezing will mean that Australian importe from Britain will , be limited to the value of goods 'which I she will take from us. The balance

of her needs she will either have to produce for herself or compel ¡ her people to take up another notch in their belts'. ''Freering" otir ? balances will merely give to Bri-

tain power to prevent herself being flooded with goods which she can- not afford-the Covernment and not merchants - and .distributors

will say what goods snail erfchsJ enter or leave, the ' country. ' To ration dollar goods she must alec ration Dominion Booda.

IThe Chifley complete eontribu

tionx towards Britain's posb-wai plight ha« not been impressive. A high-powered recruiting Hits among the war ruing of millions ol houses, for tradesmen to come tc Australia to build houses et Can berra; another drive, on "a Minis terial level" for young people tc migrate from Britain to Australia; clamorous demands for ships tc fetch and carry to Australia, even though "such as ventured here took twice a« long as hitherto, to gel despatch; shrill insistence on tot prices and all the préférences that are going-for thy- "goods; --©the* demands--al so . on ''ministerial level"-for- caustic soda which wc are unable to'make because of - a strike that is just on a year old; surely opposition-of 'Ministerial /status-to the despatch by private folk of food parcels to Britain; non-payment -, of long overdue debts and a grudging book entry of £26,000,000 termed by courtesy a "gift"} do not make an impos- ing list. South Africa and New Zealand are1 planning to send food on Lend-lease terms, and the world knows the' generosity of Canada. .To date, a cautious pro- mise to "do everything possible to help1" appears to set the limit to a°y projected aid from Chifieyite

Australia.

One thing that we might do with considerable profit to Britain and a measure of benefit to ourselves would be to utilise our ~ London balances towards paying off our London debts. These amounted at the «nd of June,-1948, to £90^370, 000 on account of World War I, £5,780,000 on account of World War II and £53,530,000 on account of- works and services, being an ag- gregate of £149,680,000 on Com- monwealth Government account; and another- £837,590,000 .' on ac- count of the six States. This is an overall total of £487,270,000, . tb?, annual interest bill' on which ia £11,730,000, to which must be added another . £2,930,000 ex- change. The lastnamed charge-25 per cent-is something that we pay on every account from London for the privilege of having an Aus-

tralian pound that is worth only j 15/' sterling, and it is this-plus ;

the 40-hour week-which is .con- fronting most of Australia's rail- ways with ?? bankruptcy. Already I Communist« and High Priests. in

the A.R.T7. are preaching repudia- tion of this^debt, and no Labour politician has yet been bold enough

to rebuke them.

Much of our sterling balances were built up by stored wool managing to escape to _ Bri' tain, and also by fantastic heights to which wool prices soared. When Canberra points to rising prices in America as a reason for the less- ened valúe to Britain of the Ameri- can loan, and urges that USA take this into account when going for her pound of flesh, ft is elementary honesty to remember the part that prices played in swelling our Lon- don balances. Britain's export prices cannot rise in anything like the degree that her import costs have risen, so that «he is in a position of having to pay rising import prices with .competitive ex- port prices and also meet the cost of Empire preference,. Incidentally, there is no talk of Empire prefer- ence when Australian wool is sell- ing on an open market at up to 5/- and 6/- per Ba. Canberra never talked of "food for Britain" on any but top price terms. Canberra brag of the increasing value of food sent to Britain did not deign to tell how much of the increase was food and how much was price.

Having tried unsuccessfully so many dodges to cut a dash among the nations, tho Chifleyites might go back a few boastful at re tenes arid try the homely dodge of being honest. Seldom has opportunity to do the honourable thing been so edged with gold or so pregnant of promise; never' before han it been so profitable to pay our debts; and seldom has the opportunity to be- friend Britain been fraught with Pcb prospect of being good to our

Iveg.

articleText:
Cte morning PuUetin

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, FEBRUARY 14, 1947

FEMALE LABOUR

Desperate calls are being made for girls to undertake the duties of nursing, and many* and varied are the reasons given for the un- deniable falling off in thc number of young women offering for that noble service. As usual, the purely materialistic side is re . ceiving prominence-the wages are

insufficient, work too exacting, hours too long and amenities p°or, . °r> at least, have not kept pace , with those on offer in other call . ings. To maintain that line of

reasoning it would be necessary tc , say that the impulse or inspiration

to embark upon a noble calling is . not so strong as it was, for if the

wages, hours and amenities foi r nurses are unsatisfactory now they J are in fact very much better than

they were in grandma's day, when the cult of Florence Nightingale ( never languished through lack of

recruits.

' But the percentage of young ; women who have either the moral

or mental quality or the inspira- tion to take up nursing is prob- ably as high . now as ever it was. The real trouble is that modern health treatment demands make ' heavier calls upon our young

womanhood than was the case 50 years ago, on top of which the sup I ply of such young women is fall ' ing. The. shortage of female , labour applies not only to nursing

II but to other callings, and while . the passing of war's upsets and

the inevitable post-war swing to* . wards matrimony accentuates the

trouble, a falling birthrate offers little hope for .the customary re 1 covery. . The simple fact is that [ the number of females between the ? ages of 15 and 24, the age-group . which provides the major number ! of female employees, has come to : a standstill even if later figures-' - oars are np to 1941-do not reveal

! that the number is declining.

At the 1921 census the number of " females in the 15-24 age-group ! wag 46*2,104, and this had increased

to ?'90,231 at the next census in 1933, while the ratio of that age group to the total number of I, females actually increased slightly.

This rate of increase was 2.3 per cent per annum. 'By 1941 the

. effects of the decline in the birth-

rate subsequent to 1920 started to make itself felt, so that the in , creased number of females in the i 15-24 age-group Vas only 22,865 \ or only 0.5 per cent per annum. . This important age-group was î short, therefore, by 84,135 females

' on the rate of increase between

1921 and 1933. Little wonder, -therefore, that there is a'shortage of nurses, as indeed there is °f all female labour. What is more, the ' position is unlikely to improve, as

it bas been- calculáted that the

number of females-^ in this age group reached-ats highest point in 1943, and that a decline has now set-in. *;

That this aspect of our popula- tion "rate of ¿¿aerease; should have . coincided with the upset of war

has had the effect of masking the real reason for the female labour shortage. Then upwards of 800,000 ? males have had tb be translated ; from a war to a peace-time econ-

omy, so that there has been a tem- porary glut there; hut the same ; shortage in this age-group is also

showing up. The male rate of in- crease in this age-group between the census .years. 1921 and 1933 was 2-8 per annum, on which rate

there should .have been an increase : of 136,480 males in this -age-group » between 1933 and 1941. There was . in fact an increase of only 22,003 Î so that the shortage amounts to i 114,477, but because most men stay

on a pay-roll during the whole of their working life, and also because the nation has not been geared up to full'production that aspect of . the case has not forced itself on 1 general notice. But it soon wilL

This is but one, albeit a major ' one, of the.factors that influence

the amount of available female , labour. The effects of widows' pen i sions and} child endowment have . resulted in the . number of older . women offering for- employment r ialling steeply in the last few r years, and the glamour of war I prosperity has had a like effect. 3 The tendency in wealthier com . m unities is for more girls to take

secondary education, for them to work only spasmodically and also to marry earlier. Dooming in the distance, too, is the higher school leaving age ''which will not make the prospect - any brighter for would-be " employers of female [ labour in the next decade.

In the employment that she : takes, too, woman is becoming

more discriminating, and while in . 1911, 71 per cent of all1 metropoli-

tan female workers were employed ' in either manufacture, domestic

service, hotels and the like only 44 per cent were so employed in \ 1943. Conversely the professions,

public service and commerce em- ployed only 29 per, cent of the total females employed in the . metropolis in 1911, where they em-

ploy 56 per cent of it now. Indica- tive, too, of how metropolitan con i ditions are draining off the avail , able female labour supply of the ' State, it is shown that where only i 88 per cent of all such females

were employed in the metropolis ' in 1911, 53 per cent of such total , was so employed in 1943. On the

other hand, the demand for female labour is steadily forcing up female i wages, that were 50 per cent °f

the male' wage in 1914 and are 60 per cent of it now.

These fundamental facts reveal that' the apparent disinclination of young women to embark on a i nursing career is due in part to

there being a diminishing supply of such young women. There is also, and for the same reason, a dimin- ishing supply, of young men, and were Australian economy going ! forward as it should that shortage . would be no less obvious than is

that of' their vanishing-or not / arriving-sitters.

articleText:
Cte jttorning SwUttiti

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, OCTOBER 3, 1947.

THE SALEYARD^

The final selection of Gracemei as the site for the new saleyard will énà a dispute of long stanc ingj and will also remove from

residential area an institution tba in return for the amenities it ei joyed and the discomfort it cause« müde no concessions either t aesthetic taste or humanitaria doctrines. Môre slovenly, unkemji premises it would be difficult" ' t find, and the not. 'infrequent in promptu butchering of haples beasts that perished-eithev throug being exposed in shadeless, yards t blistering heat or through the' bar barous method of 'trucking" "Or" ni trucking cattle wa«, neither restf « to age nor enlightening to youtl

It was not the d6îôg' óf lh¿ Shov Society that our -noonday. summe heat drives all free cattle off th pasture to chew thè.lciid' "oî'reflec tion in the sha^dey hut-it-will-eve stand as a reproach-/of tba authority that it provided shade less cattle yards for use- -at al hours of the day and at all sea' sons of the year./Then as if to en- sure that discomfort "for pur eco- nomic beasts be not ameliorated b} the coming of rain, the yard sur- faces have ' either been troddei down. by countless hooves or erodec by ceaseless winds, so as first to be come lakes and then stagnant sloughs of despond; This is stated less as a stricture on an authority that through many years achieved this civic eyesore, than in hope that the new yards will -have ; in- corporated in them some of thc amenities which should be the due of dumb beasts in their last hours ere giving their lives in our ser-

vice. .

Nor is it the "fault of the Show

Society that the railway authori-

ties of Queensland-if not * Aus- tralia-adhere to the. barbarous side-loading of cattle into railway trucks. Nor, on the other hand, does it seem ever to have_ protested against it, appearing rather to have incorporated its arrangements into this archaic system. Few countries truck cattle so often or so far for a living as is the case in Australia, and it has been left to Argentina to show us the way in long corridor trains, open at the end, so that-cattle walk on and off with a minimum of upset and con- sequent bruising. 'Large numbers of cattle are also carried by water on specially constructed craft fitted with shower sprays and strong fans to keep the cattle cool amenities that are . not alway» available on Queensland railways even for human passengers. Twenty years ago a Beef Cattle Industry Commission reported that a test taken over the 1927 Queens- land killing season showed that the loss through bruising amounted to 6/3 per head on all railed cattle. That amount spent on- providing the elements of humanitarian com- fort for our railed beasts would in fact cost nothing as the grazier loses it by simply permitting the railway authorities to maim and! mangle them. This, too, is less in thenaturè of carping criticism of past performances than to indicate how the railway authorities might follow the example of a South American country to try to do bet-

ter in future.

In actual transport, only through the animate being bereft of speech do we remain unaware of their frightful agonies. The interior of an uncovered truck as the vehicle sways and bumps through at least eight of the daylight hours of a summer's day must as nearly ap- proximate the popular concept of the infernal .regions as any breath- ing creature can endure and sur-: vive. Skeletons littering the all too-few resting and watering places bear mute testimony to the

fact that not all of them did-or dp-survive. With that, of course, the Show Society had no concern. It merely practised anew on the surviving poor brutes when they got here.

Delay in vacating the saleyards on Lion Creek Road has been ex- tended through the conflict of sites. No site could have all the requis- ites of a saleyards to serve both meatworks and abattoirs require- ments, and all three bf -those of- fering had at least some of them. We do not presume to question the judgement of the several interests in the final selection, who should know' their requirements if any- body does. But we do feel that re- moval of the saleyards from a residential area is a distinct for- ward move in city beautification, and trust that provision will be made at, the new site, if not by roofing at least by planting shade trees and the generous usé of water spray» to open a new era oi humanitarianism for which pos- terity will have occasion to bless us, rather than blush for us.

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, DECEMBER 13,

1947.

ABOUT FAIRIES

The whole Christian world is jnoving steadily, inexorably to- wards the time when, if fairies there be in this hectic age it muse surely be then, for even though he is in a class apart Santa Claus can claim to be the most significant, the most universal of all fairies. Of the existence of fairies there can be no doubt, Falstaff's warning, "He that looks on them shall die" notwithstand- ing, for like the overtone of a melody ' they, play an important part in life's symphonic effect. Nobody played more subtly the notes on the scale of fairy lore than Shakespeare and no single writer touched so many chords of human emotion and sentiment, so if ' we are not to believe him to.

whom :may we .give oilr trust i

Fairies impress themselves in- delibly . on the works of Mother Nature, from fairy bells to "blue were her eyes as the fairy flax" ; from fairy (fungus) baths to thimbles for fairy sempstresses; from fairy (ragwort) horses to fairy, gloves which they share with that most artless of scamps, the fox. T?hen there are fairy greens' where, everyone knows, they -dance' through the moonlit hours, fairy; hillocks in Scotland far greener! than the surrounding grassland, fairy sparks emanating from de- caying wood which' «hone over j

their revels, and far too many j more to permit the preposterous' belief, propagated1 by folk who cram themselves . with facts, that

fairies do not exist. Such people have simply forgotten-did they j&vßx know . 5t-the . unspeakable .joy of "Once upon a time." His- torians and 'scientists are indeed sceptical, but even they tell us that Plato wrote of children's games, very, Jike those which chil- dren play today, which had a back- ground of fairy lore. Maybe froto essaying too much, poets haye not always done service to the jcult sjof fairies aa, for instance, George Darley -has ""Sylvia"! dwelling fm a kind" of movie' picture^ studio amid a glitter of light - and : a cacophony of sound which prompted, : no doubt, the plaintive "Who is Sylvia ?" How much 'more satisfying was Ben Jonson's treatment of. Queen Mab:

L feggft'ptf #^5. iiiogt'r engsging/íeje*. tor about îairy lore" is ite uncer tainty, "which; characterises' - alike -that in ; most sophisticated and most primitive countries. Chaucer said ; that England in the days "of H^g^ Arther was -filled'with fair ie^ r«n^ hazarded Belief ¿' tlfcài thèj "3feá- been"; driven áWáy. 1>>

monks -and friars, who -.went about blessing, all the' old fairy haunts; -and .Lewis Spence,'has ' just pub- lished a book called '^British Fairy .Origins*'}.i-^^tt- it» weight of

chantrng" study nr%ht have caused tí^. jíholé fairy" tradition, to van- ish into thin air. He. concludes a ^somber* t work ' by , accepting?1- the whole tradition , to rest ohL.aa

ancient ^belief that dead souls, awaiting .reincarnation,', dwell com- munally ' ' inf burial mounds and hollow trees and lakes,; which is little, in'advance of the belief of some: Australian aborigines That theory denotes a . fairyland . in which every transformation can be traced . tb ' a sluggish liver, every, 'flirting sprite ' to jangled nerves;- -where fairies .'"can be yarded like brumbies, brought to th$::ba>,>.pf jeold reason or difiti pfined like soldiers. Were that so it would be =' farewell . to "Ye elves of f standing lakes and groves, ye cloud-capped towers and. gorgeous pateos, to ali those castîes where

énl^tói^ig music plays tor tireless

dancers which'lure 'the bewildered livelier to forget." , . . :'

; The fact is that nobody wants to know, in ' which belief or fact or memory! Hes the origin of the fairjjr ? tradition; Thfe whole . tanta- lising relationship between .^tatry. 4¿d man suggests a more twilit enchantment, \ ''\a "" moire V subtle mystery than will submit-'to* Nbold analysis,'* We would as soon know what is.at -.the end of the rainbow which »io ' Keats, was too prec- ious' to- be stripped by scientists into beáms and disintegrated 1 by prisms. We- want no "depoetised" fairyland, with its crazy outlines and dimensions- and appointments reduced by architects (*nd town, planners to rules of cause and effect Jtl3and> of weights *Hd

measures. Far better -be it th At

the fairies we accept in later life are those which filled our youth with brightness ? and encourage- ment. We feared them only if we offended against fairy.1 lore that, after all, was very sane human lore. We expected no good fairy to lift Us out of the consequences of our past follies or misdeeds, H being a most healthy tradition of their being or attribute of their functions that they came to re- ward past good conduct. Were it otherwise they might be deputed to speed the well-doped steed on which a despairing cashier had invested the office cash, and no- body ever rea_d a fairy story quite like that. The story of Cinderella may not be helpful in gaining Tiigher marks for English Or for the advanced mathematics; but maybe it does give a child its first les- son in the beauty of being gentle and kind, a lesson which, in after life, may bear infinitely better fruit than would a phenominally early knowledge of the intricacies and vagaries of. algebra.

So, let us retain our belief in fairies if by fairies we mean that which children mean, and if adults

see. in them incentives to unselfish- ness - and a wider tolerance. What

they really are matters nothing at alL in fact, it were better for ut not to try and find oat. A 17th century Scottish clergyman named Kirk ii »aid to have writ* ten on "The Secret Commonwealth pi Elves, Fauns and Fairies," whereupon some of the Common- wealth kidnapped him and breathe it. softly-his very grave in the pariah churchyard ia . stud

to be boneless ! "
