articleText:
V* Jftdmfns bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, JANUARY 4, 1947

STREPTOMYCIN

A cynic might Bay that, witt the wealth of soap bubbles being blown over the community, on« would be hard pressed to find a human being other than wai Cleopatra as she emerged from hei legendary bath of asses' milk; or, judging from the torments to which the ether is subjected dur-

ing the merciless hunt by 6uper sleuths of the most diabolical of bad men, the day of the common crook should be past. One has but to be packed in a theatre bus on a humid night, however, or to read of Sydney's lusty slashings and gougings to know that things do not always work out that way. Incentives to cleanliness are far too personal to be " influenced greatly by third-party importuni- ties, and every ambitious young criminal hopes, to defeat-for a time at least-the sombre police warning "Crime does not pay." Then, again, the evils that ex- coriate the flesh of man should be swept away in the imposing stream of new-found remedies which has flowed of late from Nature's Treasure Chest-but that of course is another matter. Any tendency to exaltation is subdued on recalling that there are few things of which science knows

less than it does of the common cold.

Until September last, when it was first released for civilian use, not many folk had heard-other than under the direst '"hush-hush"

precautions - the word streptomy- cin. The more knowledgeable of those that did knew that it was another of the "necklace" anti- biotics, which means that it is a substance, arranged like a string of beads, that is produced by micro-organisma and is capable of declaring war on bacteria. Many of the bacteria which play havoc with man's health and push up the death rate in unexpected places have been brought to heel by one antibiotic or another, hut there remained some "tough guys" that defied all attempts at then subjection. These latter are said to be "Gram negative," i.e., they refuse to be stained by the Gram method of bringing bacteria under observation, and so left science looking down its nose through an unseeing microscope.

It is not claimed, however, that streptomycin has brought under control all of these hard cases, but it has subdued some quite impor- tant ones. Influençai meningitis, ai disease with high death rate, has been shorn by the new drug of its terrors; while urinary tract in- fections-many of them considered

for 20 years to be incurable-have also yielded to it. It has proved efficacious in peritonitis, in blood stream infections and in sinuses. While the tubercle bacillus is sen- sitive to streptomycin, its evalua- tion "in the treatment bf tuber cu-, losis, despite much premature speculation, needs time," but human clinical trials are in pro- gress. On the other hand, against typhoid fever and undulant fever the newi âsàg ¿Jhowed . "no-drama- tic results/' Cautious chaps, these scientists, and rightly too, raising no false hopes that the new ^phar- maceutical baby" will be unable ultimately tö justify.

Streptomycin was discovered little more than tyro yean ago by Dr S. A. Wakeman, of Rutgers University, New Jersey, after some years' antibiotic research, and went'straight into the fighting forces. It comes from origins as prosaic as its success proved to be dramatic, being tracked down to specific strains of a germ-killing soil organism originally isolated from heavily manured soil and-of all places on earth-r-the throat of a chicken- Later, . the types of soil were expanded and some peats were included. But isolating the strain was only one step in the manufac- ture of the new arrival, for only if the strain of the soil organism is grown on a specific medium will it produce or create streptomycin. In its turn, this "medium must possess certain chemical character- istics that, odd as it may seem, are still- unidentified. Chemist*

are still probing, Jbut so, far ac they can gather these characteris- tics appear to be lodged in meat extract, in the liquor in which corn has been steeped, and in some yeast preparations. The in- cubation . or growth period oi streptomycin is about ten days, when a process of deterioration set« in at once as if, finding nc work at hand, this wonder bac- teria destroyer sets about de straying itself.

Notwithstanding this maze ol complications, production in USi of streptomycin-it ig made no- where else-in November last hac

rcacnea uujvuu grammes and new factories, a large one in Virginia to be used exclusively for mass production of the newcomer, are expected soon to meet all home i requirements and have an export-! able surplus. By far the largest consumer of streptomycin ia tuber- culosis, treatment of which is still in the experimental stage. What places streptomycin at the head of the list of known bacteria fighters is that it can be turned loose among most of the worst charac- ters and at least come to no

harm, where penicillin would prob- ably take the count early in the fray. This factor makes of it "a valuable partner- to penicillin." Just how far that character can be sustained, or with what other substances streptomycin can be linked as it were to work in double harness has still to be demonstrated. But science is hard at work, and while it has some very bright hopes the men who puddle among the odds and end« of things that Dame Nature car ríes in her vanity bag are not presenting us with any unfinished curative symphonies. But so fai as they have told us, and so fai as they have limited the publie .use of streptomycin to assailing bacteria, on which it is known U be effective, several very grin: dangers bave been removed fron man's ; progress through life. Th ohf cure-all or panacea for al evflf -ig no more. There are far toi many substances in nature to ad mit; ëjf' anèh crudities, but it ha lakea a long time to sort then out. Kow that man is aasemblin,

his allies he is reaching that happy stage, described by the man who had just heard of , anaesthetics, "Even if a man don't live well he can be sure of dying easily," which .may have been what he meant, j On the other hand-but we do not know all there is to know of streptomycin, either.

articleText:
Ofje jftorníiig Cullerin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, APRIL 2, 1947.

THE NOMINATIONS.

If the number of nominatioi received for the State gener election ig indicative of tl amount of general interest in tl coming contest, it will fulfil cu r~sit prophecies of proving tl most momentous election tbs

Queensland has seen for 20 year As with other things, quantity i political candidates does n< always imply quality, but electoi have little ground for misgivin on that score, so far as the prii cipal -contending parties are coi

cerned.

One hundred and sixty-thrt candidates have nominated for th 62 seats. With 19 entrants fe the five Central seats the averag is slightly higher here than fe the whole State, and if this ca be interpreted as a sign that elei

tors of the Central Division ar

alive to the need for a change i tîieir parliamentary representa tion, and are of a mind to carr; 'on with, tba work inaugurated a the last Federal election in rt sDect of Capricornia, it shoul bring about a few surprises oi polling day.

Not infrequently ' it happen that nomination day is marked b' some whimsical incident connecte* with a nomination paper arrivinj too late for acceptance, but usu ally it is associated with the can djdature of a "no hoper" who, i truth be told, was just as pleasei to have missed the bus. But then is nothing whimsical about th inexcusable bungle in lodging th nomination of the Country Parti

candidate for Normanby, especial^ in view of the fact that this wa" one of the seats the Party counted on winning. It is some month) since Mr Lindsay's selection wai announced, and how it came t< be left to the eleventh hour t< complete the formalities and sei that the nomination reached the Returning Officer in order and fail ed to do so, is something thai the responsible organisation of th« Country Party should be called upon to explain. If this is a sample of "preparedness" for the election, of -which so much is heard at Party conferences and s"-h like gatherings, it is not over impressive.

The small number of Communists entered is not the least note- worthy feature of the election nomination. Including the sit- ting . member for Bowen they number "but half a dosen. Per- haps the Communist organisation considers it can find a better use for its funds than to allow them to seep into the Consolidated Revenue per medium of forfeited election deposits; or it may be that there is a shrewd realisation that it is bad policy to so openly advertise the disproportionate amount of political power wielded by them in comparison with their hold in the industrial sphere. This sbould bave been manifest long ago to even the most weak-kneed Labour member, who has quaked before them in fear of what they might do on election day. It seems not yet to have dawned on many Parliamentarians that a party whose candidates so consistently lose their deposits can have no great power for good or ill at the

ballot box.

An unexpected development in

connexion with the nominations is the intrusion of a cohesive independent Labour Party acknow- ledging Mr Barnes, Member for Bundaberg, as their leader. There is little hope of any of them being returned but their presence may I give a curious turn to the elec-

tion, and ig indeed said to be dis- concerting to the Premier and his I election managers. The "first I past the post" amendment to the Electoral Act, which abolished preferential voting and served the Government well at several by elections, may now prove a boomerang in that the Independent Labour men-they are nearly all standing for Labour-held seats will take away sufficient votes from the endorsed candidate to

permit the Opposition man to lead on the initial count, though he might not win on a preference vote. It is freely canvassed in Brisbane that bad this develop- ment been foreseen before the recent A.L.P. conference at Towns- ville, there would have been a swift manoeuvre on the part of the Government to get back to preferential voting. As it turns I out there is neither time nor op- portunity to do anything, and the Government must take its chance on the law as it stands.

With the poll on May 3 it leaves approximately one month for campaigning. That is quite long enough to enable the Party leaders and individual candidates to state and reiterate - all they wish to say. It is also sufficient- ly long to enable electors to make lip their minds, if they have not already dor» so. Whatever the outcome of the poll the nomina- tions have created unusual inter- est for this stage of the election, which is sufficient indication that we shall have a rigorous and, per- haps, sensational polling.

articleText:
Hie Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY, JULY 31, 1947. DEPRESSION CROAKERS

Depression -- called recess these days-ie in the air again, 4 gloom prophets are in good fo; Our friends the Communists hi

been, croaking it since Septem last at least., but with them wish' is sire of the prophecy,

in no circumstances do the for of. revolution, prosper so well

during times of economic confus and depression misery, and a Co munist without hope of a rev« tion is a weak, colourless thing. ! Chifley, Prime Minister of A tralia (under thé tutelage of Ms House and the Trades Hall) a author of the Golden Era vigil also has his bleak moments - wi the fact of controlling the Co:

m on weal th \Bank loses its rea ssl

ing promise with the' growi stream of departing customers, the not^hdistant past control

euch a bank waa held to be the pa acea for all financial and econon ills, an impregnable basti against the terrors of dépressif He seems to.be less sore now. .

- The days of plenty in Amerl and those of scarcity in Brits have each been cited as unquestio able evidence, that depression round the corner; -, just . as i vast output and distribuía by America of consumer goot and the low. output and stra gnlated distribution'' of t same kind' of - goods in Au tralia are held to fae unfailing sig of stormy weather ahead. To sobe minded folk these dismal foreeae .based jon. contrnd^tpry aa Ca a Bheer humbug, jnst as they a

clear evidence of thé determin tion of scaremongers and troubl makers to have a depression at a costs. They have their own -reasoi for wanting a depression-to pro' a" financial philosophy, to sea: taxpayers into political subjectio or to stage a revolution-and v may expect to hear more of thei .It is one" of the -penalties and pei

Os of a free land:that 'we mm suffer fools gladly, and treat plo!

ters with tolerance.

If the.army of croakers mana* to stage a depression in .Austral] it will be against all the facts fe stability, all the claims of man i be a reasoning animal. A,vast lap but partly developed, a backgroun set up by 4he sturdy population < hut half a century or so ago, a trag ically large unsatisfied oversea .appetite "for the goods whic we can produce, and bans bulging wiöi money belongin to the ;- people who want bc sane "leadership to" 'go shea as fearlessly and as full ' x confidence as did their, forbears. JJ the face of these-cold facts, cres tion of a depression would be a achievement of incredible stupid ity. Yet the croakers are 'hopeful or at least, are persistent. They ar playing upon, the fears ', and sus pjcions, on greed, and'cupidity, am on envy and sense of'inferior ity

a disastrous team that hag led hit manlty into many a quagmire.' Ii on the other hand, the people o Australia want a depression then is little to , prevent their having it They have but to listen to tat

croakers to find themselves well ol the way to that slough of despond For the 'croakers not only fbretel the thing- they want, but specif j the means hy which to attain it Thei. first and most important fac- tor ^ÍB,for everyone io slow dowj

on production, and Aere Mr Chit ley's ínraífeal tax va . productiot

is |l«rt^e^g>\¿igkeíianW .Aft«

that, comes .thaflmsVup of '-? com munleatictos,so í that things whet , produced cannot, be distributed. Al -this moment there are goods of al] kinds to the. value of maybe" mil- lions lying inert and useless, ror Australian wharves,, on railwkv premises and: in factories, whilf people all over the continent are 'in desperate "need of them. Idle goods mean idle money, and idle money means idle services which is a very short remove fjom idl* men. The glib reason given for that is a shortage of shipping, '«ven while -such ships as. we have }ie idle in port now twice as long as they did. In other words, we could double our shipping by halving the time taken by -ships over, individ- ual "voyages. The Communists, noisiest in. their ' predictions of a depression and busiest in the. cause of keeping ships and wharves idle, could be credited at least with sincerity did they drop on* side of their activities.

The' life-blood of a country is th«» free movement of goods and ser- vices. JVO country can for long re- main healthy if its industrias ar<> strangled either at the source or through the channels of distribu- tion. In Australia today there is no sane reason, none but a disloyal excuse and certainly none who dp

sire that Australia shall remain free who would condone such wil- ful .strangling.

There is no mystery about Aus- tralia's position. She has no war devastation, no major problems of post-war human .wreckage that are comparable with those of Britain, no, crippling need for ship-borno goode if ber people are to survive, and no vast overseas debts. She has on the other hand a va6t land cap- able of both doubling her popula- tion and feeding it, huge, resources of raw materials and a population I with abundant funds to oil the

I wheels of industry. Her three ea ! sential needs are: to encourage j private investment; to encourage j public investment, especially in.

low-cost housing; and see ' that j frozen savings - do not aggregate more than 10 or 12 per cent of the national income. In other words. , keep money moving as a factor in the. production of commodities, so that a large supply of goods flow- ing, to the market-will act as- a safeguard against inflation:

Although Australia could not hope to escape altogether reper- cussions of booms and slumps in Jjo&ftofi aad ftp* York* is would,

be only through desperate trying did our economy suffer as may theirs. Those countries are in tie economic firing line, feeling the full force of tile surge of astronomical masses of moving money, of com- plex political upheavals and sub- sidences. That the finger of their

financial barometer should tremble is no need for panic here. Indeed, it is an added reason why we should work harder and longer so that we -may not only improve our

own lot, bnt be able also to play I our not inconsiderable part in the f rssvseitattoB of Eta-ops. 1

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY APRIL 22, 1947

WHITEHALL DUNDERHEADS

Although Britain is sliding to- wards the oblivion of third Power status, there are still some very thick heads in and about White- hall. They were doddering there in 1939, when Britain was employing the year's respite, which Chamber- lain obtained from Hitler at Mun- ich, in tobogganing towards the bottomless pit, for it was they who sent the King and Queen on a visit to Canada and the United States. Never before had a King and Queen of the British Empire vis- ited any of the Dominions, and if it was a mere coincidence that they selected for their tour Canada, 30 per cent of the population of

which is of French descent, then it would be right to say that nobody in Britain expected the French army to crack up as it did. Extension of the tour to the great neutral republic of USA, travers- ing on the way the battle areas of the Wars of the Revolution pre- cipitated by the follies of another King George of England 164 years earlier, may have been due to a mere whim, in which case none of

the dodderers at Whitehall foresaw how poignant would soon be the need for American aid if democ- racy of the English-speaking peoples was to survive. It is too near the event to be precise, but the world knows of the tremen- dous wealth of aid that poured east across the Atlantic to battered Britain from the two countries

lately toured by their Majesties.

The King and Queen, accompan- ied by the Princesses, have just completed a nine weeks' 6942-mile tour of South Africa, finishing bril- liantly at Cape Town on the 21st anniversary of the birth of Prin- cess Elizabeth, heir presumptive to the throne of the British Em- pire. The current popular belief is that this was merely a tour for collecting addresses of loyalty and strings of diamonds, or for the future Queen of England to give five dances to a young Air Force officer who was on the verge of be- ing thrown out by the Master of Ceremonies for daring to appear minus the traditional white gloves. If that be so, then the folly of the nit-wits at Whitehall emulated

Queen Mary of England in 1558. She said, "When I am dead, Calais will be found written on my heart," and shrewd observers reck- oned that an X-ray of the hearts of Whitehall nit-wits would dis- close the word "Mediterranean" written there. That was before the South African Royal tour and an amended suggestion might be that inspection would see that word scored put and "South Africa" in scribed in its place.

The greater part of Britain's troubles in the Near East and India lie in the fact that the Hindus and Jews and Moslems be-

lieve they have her "by the short hair," and may sever her "life-line with the east" if she fails to re- spond to reason. From Gibraltar

to Java that life-line is lined by Moslems who want the Jews

thrown out of Palestine, the Hindus subjugated in India and the Sudanese brought under the mantle of the prophet. The Hindus, who outnumber the Moslems in India by three to one, yearn for the power of many over the few, and the Jews do not care what the Arabs get so long as it is not Palestine. This amiable trio, clutching at each other's throat as they straddle Britain's road to the east-of which they form no incon- siderable part-would be less vo- ciferous but for the belief that a Britain cut off from the east would

soon be in a bad way. On top of this is the fact that both Egypt and India are in process of attain- ing their independence-British have now to register in India-and are not including tolerance in their preparations for celebrating that event. In the circumstances, that Britain during peace would have the use of the Mediterranean is as unquestionable as that she would find herself walking a tight rope there in case of war, with more than a chance of there being a fanatic working on both ends of the rope with a knife.

There is little reason to doubt that, with Britain less dependent upon the wild men who are gesticu- lating along her so called "life-line to the east" they would be much

more amenable to reason. Re-

adjustment of Empire preferences may also difert trade from one- time Empire dependencies that have become independent, so that the value of the 'life-line" would be less than it was. Hence it ap- pears that Whitehall bunglers are turning their attention to building up the Union of South Africa into the greatest of all Empire out- posts. The Dutch founded Cape Town just on 300 years ago (in 1650), to protect their ships on their way to and from their Colon- ial Empire in Java, where Batavia had been founded 31 years earlier. In their turn, the British took Cape Town in 1795 to protect their ships on their way to and from the Indian Empire. That was long be- fore Suez Canal was opened, and it is logical to look to that half- way house now that there appears a likelihood of its being closed when it is most needed, or opened to an enemy when Britain least

needs it.

The Union of South Africa has an area greater than the aggregate of New South Wales, Tasmania, and Victoria and a population of 9,589,898, of which 21 per cent are Europeans. The aggregate farm area in 1939 was 213.180,000 acres against 23,500,000 acres in Aus- tralia. The number of live stock in 1943 were: cattle, 13,070,000 (13,870,000); sheep, 37,890,000 (124,610,000); and pigs 1,170,000 (1,560,000), the figures in paren- thesis being for Australia. The coal

raised in 1940 was 18.93 tons against 16.99 in Australia.

Politically, the Union is far

from tranquil, the pro-Nazi party Í (Herenigde), led by Dr Malan, held

44 per cent of the seats in the Par- liament of the Union when war

broke out, and in September, 1939, Hertzog's motion that diplomatic relations with Germany be con- tinued led to the formation of Coalition Government led by I Smuts. Even at the 1943 elec I tions, during which Malan said,

"We wish to break the Bri- tish connexion and to establish * free and independent republic in our land," the antüwar party won 29 per cent of the 6eats.

Nobody knows these facts better than the dunderheads at White-

hall knew them when they staged the Royal Tour that has JUE* passed, its climax, and nobody knew better than they what to try

to do about it. A Britain en- trenched behind« aj wast develop- ment programme in the Union of South Africa with blue water on three sides of her, will be a vaEtly different proposition from a Bri- tain in the Mediterranean which is surrounded by land. Not *hat Bri- tain is likely to be pushed out of that inland sea just yet, but she will make a better stand there if she is able from South Africa to

keep an eye on both Atlantic and

Indian Oceans. The Hindu, the Jew and the Moslem «ll have mighty little respect for anyone that can- not bite back, which is why they are so noisy, and the rustics at Whitehall are so busy, now.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON TUESDAY APRIL 22, 1947 WHITEHALL DUNDERHEADS

articleText:
Ste morning PnlleNn

BOCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, AUGUST 20, 1W7.

FULL EMPLOYMENT.

Another of the things that looked

most attractive in the distance only to lose 'much of its glamour upon" realisation is that of "full employment." . In the days when unemployment returns soared high, no happier State could be imagined -and this view was shared by worker, employer and government -than one in which there was work for all who were able and willing to perform it, at fair rates of pay «nd under reasonable con- ditions of hours and labour.

To Australia, liée most other countries, full employment ap- peared then as a Utopian dream, yet in process of time it has come about. We really have reached a stage where there is work for all under wages and conditions that some indeed doubt the capacity of industry to bear, though it is not as yet endangered from that cause. How is it working out for the prosperity and stability of the country and the happiness and contentment of the people who should be enjoying it ? ^

The Victorian Institua» pf Public Affairs has been going into the matter and its flndmgs are of general interest. The conclusion reached on investigation and

mature consideration is that Aus- tralia's fuH employment economy ls working badly. Turnover of labour is at record levels, a- con- dition that - presents serious ob. steeles to efficiency. Working days wasted through strikes are at a peak surpassed only on one or two previous occasions. Indus- trial irresponsibility is widespread and it ls not easy for management to enf oroe even - reasonable disci- pline, let alone insist on a high standard of industrial pegjform^ ance. In spite of the passing of

wartime strains and stresses on the individual worker absenteeism continues to operate on a consider- able seale. Another undesirable trend is that timekeeping is poor, so that the nest periods tend to exceed allotted intervals, work takes longer to get under way and tools are downed before the, recog- nised time for ending work.

This ie not a. pretty picture, and certainly ia not what was visual- ised by the old-time champions of the "right to work," or those who visualised a happy, contented com- munity when there should be full employment for all. The bald fact is that labour has taken advantage of a favourable situation and is

eaploiting k. Neither the workers nor their leaders, apparently, realise that a persistence in such behaviour can easily .prove the very inetru. ment to bring about an end to full employment. .The Institute's find- ings bear out a contention raised daring the 40-hour week hearing -r-fchat even under present condi- tions what with smoke-ohs, tea hours, rest periods and other time

eoneessfona far less than the stsjfca torv noars a» given'¿to actual ?week on tibe job.

IB that* * temedj for tb« pre- sent iméatlsfactory working of the (foll ''employment economy T There' ta, but it 1B, not a simple one. The

Institute does not consider .that the solution of these and other problems -arising from full em- ployment is to be found in a re- turn to the pre-war pool "of un- employment. . On the contrary a fetnrn to the -worst conditions of unemployment that we have known wovld be neither politically prac- ticable nor ^morally defensible.

Three requirements are held to be necessary to make the new economy of full, employment work. Th? first and most important is to restore, so far and.- as soon as possible 'the old time rewards for

Sard work, skill, enterprise and ambition" Secondly, workers need to be educated in simple industrial economics' by employers, trades, unions and governments. Thirdly, expansion in the practice of Joint consultation is advocated as the

most promising means yet devised for raising the workers* sense of ¡ responsibility.

The foregoing must be acknow- ledged as one of the most temper- ate and soundly reasoned contribu-

tions to current discussions on the,

prevailing upset in industry, and j a« Saab is entitled to be closely studied , by all parties. There is nothing in the three conditions of* {ered aa a solution that cannot be adopted bj worker, management and government-adequate reward for work, skill, enterprise and ambition, education on simple in, dustrial economics, and joint con- sultation by management and workers. in their particular indus- try. These are the things to euro «trikes, absenteeism and lack pf concern t. over production.; but neither their recognition nor adop- tion will come without education

of the worker on thege matters, j That is the starting point, and the Institute of Public Affairs which has carried out this examination and issued its findings, has made a valuable contribution thereto.

articleText:
Obt jitarning ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON,

WEDNESDAY, OCTOBER 29, 1947

WHITHER BOUND?

Australians are not given to courting headaches from the inten- sive study of statistics and theil implications ou the economic and political life of the Commonwealth The mathematical researches of th«

average citizen rarely extend be yond a fruitless endeavour to un-

derstand how his income tax de duction is arrived at, with maybe a weekly excursion into the mort clearly charted field of starting price odds and the lottery prize list But this week there have been pub lished a few sets of figures that ar« an invitation to reflection by those not given to that kind of thing.

The census returns showing that Australia's population has reached only 7,500,000 at the end of one oí the lowest periods of advancemeni on record must be a subject of con- cern to everyone, and will revive the warnings that with Australia it is more than ever a case of "popu- late or perish." From whence the new population is to be obtained, how can they be speedily brought to this country, what further measures must be taken to speed lip housing and avenues of employ- ment? These are questions that might naturally be expected to seize upon everyone with the slightest responsibility in these things. But there is little evidence of anything of the kind taking place.

On the other hand side by side with the depressing population figures was printed another column revealing that one out of every four persons employed in Aus tralia is in the pay of a govern- ment or semii-government instru- mentality. Thus not only is a dis- proportionate number of our small population taken out of productive industry but they are becoming on the rest of the-community a burden which is beyond their power to support. Nor is there any prospect of a lightening of the burden. In view of the nationalisation policies of the Federal Government it is in- evitable that greater numbers will be absorbed into the public service. Meanwhile legislative action for the shortening of hours and other ' restrictions tend to still further cur-

tail the productive effort upon

which the entire structure must rely for support.

Just in case the student has not

his fill of returns showing a popu ' lotion that is growing too slowly ! and a public service that is expand-

ing all top rapidly, he will read of the proposals to further increase the number of legislators to look after the requirements of both. We have upwards of 700 members of parliament in Australia today, hut apparently the number is insuffic-

ient and a move is afoot to increase them at all costs before the life of the present Federal Parliament expires.

Federal parliamentarians are not the only thing in short supply in Australia today. According to a message _from Brisbane there is an insufficiency of sporting clubs, in- cluding golf and bowling, to accom-

modate the number who wish to join'up. But if there is % shortage of sporting clubs there apparently is no dearth of Golden Casket agencies, since the turnover in this Government controlled enterprise ran into well over £3,000,000 last year, a sum slightly in excess of a third of the total earnings of the State-owned railway service.

And so we contemplate a country with an undersized population

whose rate of increase reached a new low in the last census period, where one out of every four per- sons is in Government or semi-Gov- ernment employment, where an in- crease in the number of politicians is on its way, where Governments are vieing with each other to further restrict production by

shorter hours and heavier burdens on industry, where lottery invest- ment is expanding to become one of the largest State enterprises, and where the craze for sport is so great that the clubs cannot accom- modate the applicants. Just to round off the picture we have ship- ping held up at our ports for vary- ing periods whilst the assistant secretary of the Watersiders' Union harangues the members on political affairs in Indonesia, and the State railway service threatens to strike unless the penalties by which disci- pline is observed in the service are

abolished.

All this is occurring at a period when in all countries it is pro- claimed that the one hope of saving civilisation is greater production, more work and less government. It adds point to a question that is being raised with increasing ur- gency: Whither is Australia head- ing?

articleText:
Ofje iilorning bulletin

ROCKHAAIPION

MONDAY, APRIL 7, 1947. EASTER ATTRACTIONS

With our bandsmen at Mary- borough and the Musical Union at Bundaberg this Easter, Rock- hampton lends support to the cul- tural ambitions of neighbouring

cities. For its own entertain- ment it contents itself with

sporting attractions in the shape of the RJC Easter race meeting and the State regatta. There is j HO reason to quarrel with the arrangement so long as it is not j to be one of permanency. It will j be found to be a wholesome pro-1 ceeding to reverse the order once in a while.

Easter is the appropriate time fpr Queensland's musical festivals, the holiday spread and the cli- matic conditions alike being bet- ter suited than at any other part of the year. ? Rockhampton has well-founded claims as a cultural .centre and as they have proved in open competition, our musical organisations can hold their own with the State's best. Hence it is fitting that we should take our turn in conducting both Band Con- test and Eisteddfod in order that the citizens of Rockhampton may enjoy the pleasures which they brinv to so many.

It iá several years since we had a band contest, and further back still since the last Queensland Eisteddfod was held here. The in- trusion of the war was in part accountable, but it is not the sole reason. Neither band con- test nor eisteddfod is a self

supporting enterprise and both de- mand a measure of public finan- cial aid and a still greater mea- sure of voluntary labour. When sounded out about undertaking a band contest or eisteddfod there has been some hesitancy about shouldering the task. That com- plex should be got rid of. If it put its mind to it Rockhampton would have little difficulty in pro- viding both cash and workers.

It would" be worth the effort. There is no better means of creating goodwill between com- munities and of adding something to the lives of those who partici- pate. To go away with band or choir, or even to compete at home, is something to look forward to with anticipation and oftimes something to look back on with pleasure. Friendships are widened and goodwill grows. This Easter our oandsmen at Maryborough and our choristers at Bundaberg are receiving courtesies and kind- nesses which it behoves us to re-

pay, and this we'can only do by creating a similar occasion in our own' centre to bring along the players and the singers of those

cities.

But if Rockhampton is to go in for these things we shall require better accommodation for them. The need for a public auditorium better than ,*.nythiug we possess outside the privately-owned theatres has long passed the stage of debate. . Now that the School of Arts has been taken over by the municipality the obstacle of finance is removed, and no-one doubts that just as soon as it can get the materials and the labour the City Council will set about providing an auditorium that will meet the requirements. That, however, may take some

years.

Whilst our musicians are away Rockhampton is entertaining the rowing men of Queensland at a State regatta. Now that the war is over it is pleasing to see the youth of the country returning to the manly sports. Rockhampton

is favoured in many ways and in \ none more than the possession of j the great river which flows liv its door, not the least of whose recommendations are the facili- ties it offers for healthy outdoor recreation. Rockhampton always has held its own with the State's leading rowing centres, but the

number of our young men who \ participate in this manly sport is j perhaps below what it should be, ] especially in view of the dis- !

coifxaging reports now current of j the state of physical fitness j

boasted by Australia's young man- hood. Like eisteddfodau and

band contests, rowing is not a j

commercial proposition and here \ again there is a need for public support and encouragement for those enthusiasts who give their time and energies to its promotion.

The value of the RJC Easter j race meeting need not be . dis- j counted on any account. The countryman also must have his break from the daily routine and

he finds it in a visit to the nearest

city where a race meeting is listed. Because of the race meet- ing many will find Rockhampton an attractive place this Easter, whereas without it they would have voted the city a dull spot, though we offered them band con- test and eisteddfod as well as the regatta. Each to his taste is a good rule, but it is a wise thing for cities, as for promoters in other spheres, to see that all

tastes are catered for.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

BOOKHAMPTON

MONDAY, MAY 26, 1947 SHRINKING HOUSES

Of the many unsatisfactory as-

pects of housing in Queensland, none is more disturbing than that revealed in reports of alarming deterioration in the condition of homes erected within the past two years. The "Bulletin's" Brisbane correspondent, writing last week, stated that people -who had had houses erected within the past two or three years are greatly con- cerned about the way the timber is shrinking. The floors in one modest cottage that cost £1100, and were of tongued and grooved tim- ber of apparently good quality, are now letting in the daylight. In others the walls are gaping, win- dows and doors either will not

open or refuse to shut, and cracks are appearing everywhere. Some of the owners are returned servicemen and other have sunk their life's savings in utter rubbish.

It is obvious that big trouble is ia store ipr these unfortunate

people. If such a state of affairs is at all widespread it amounts to a soandal and there can be no ques- tion that the Government should act before more home builders are victimised, to discover where the fault lies. There is a ready sus- picion as to where a lot of it lies --that is the unhappy trend in far too many avenues of getting the

most for the least amount of ser-

vice. T&6 theory that all the good timber and workman ship became exhausted during the war should

not be entertained for a moment,

but ft it apparent that inferior materials and shoddy workman- ship has taken the place of the reliability in both that distin- guished Australian borne, building a few yoan ago. Tais is an unfort- unate legacy of tiie 'war, when swift construction regardless of cost created a condition that should have ended with the passing Of the urgency in defence needs.

But the causes are of less.con- cern than the measures required to stop practices that will give post-war housing a bad name. In years to come home purchasers will demand heavy discount on ac- count of any property being "of im- mediate post-war construction, which will react again to the own- er's disadvantage. Many people who today are laying out their savings in costly homes console themselves with the thought that "the value will always be there." These revelations suggest that so far as timber is concerned the value is not there now and will depreciate still farther as time goes on. Noshing could have a worse effect on the bousing problem gen- erally. If people in need of homes, and in a position to pay for them immediately labour and materials become available, drop the idea for fear of ending up with a building of the type described in tile fore- going message ' quoted from Bris- bane, it will throw house construc-

tion completely out of gear and delay the solution of Australia's most urgent need ipr very many

years.

Thus is further evidence provided of the futility of the Housing Commissions that investigated the problem before the war, and now control its execution. The Commis- sion that went roving' the country in tile mid-war years, seeking to ascertain tile kind of home people would like to live in, should have been addressing itself to ensuring that stocks- of suitable timber were kept up to meet the building demand when it was permissible to make a start. The present housing and building control, instead of wrangling for months with a pros- pective owner as to whether he be allowed a few feet more floor space than is laid down in the regulation, should be conducting the closes* scrutiny into the class of timber end workmanship that is being put into houses that, only too fre- quently, are eating up the savings and mortgaging the future of many of those who will become the

owners.

Clearly it is a matter for the governments. In NSW inspectors are swooping down on partly con- structed homes and examining con- tracts, with the result in some cases of hundreds of pounds being refunded. Unfortunately, there are many ways in which a builder of that type, if he has a mind to, can recoup himself for the loss before the place is finished. The situation calls for Some more dras- tic reforjn, but how it is to com» about is not at all clear. Some- thing of the same nature appar- ently is occurring everywhere and this has led to older countries giv- ing attention to the possibility of bringing about revolutionary changes in home building.

To that end some 1700 British

architects are going to Sweden to study their methods. Becently a world-wide exhibition of home building was held at Brussels. A remarkable display was the result, and it is predicted that its influence will be felt in all countries in the

future. Australia presumably was

not represented, or we have heard nothing of it, but it is of interest to this country nevertheless, and an investigation carried out by Commonwealth Housing authorities might pay dividends. Nothing is more certain than that conditions such as described in the Brisbane message cannot be permitted to continue.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, MAY 26, 1947 SHRINKING HOUSES

1947.

Few -people will be quite at ea i over the explanation, given by t I Director of the Queensland Medic

It is . also claimed that the mastitis Strepto- coccus provides man with an occa- sional sore throat, but that seems to be another border-line case of which we might know more did we have more trained veterinarians operating on auch problems in con- junction with medical research

Since then the Brisbane out- break baa abated-not because of anything we said any more appar- ently than it was on . account of anything done or discovered by the Queensland Medical Research In- stitute-but seemingly because *rfc had run its' obscure course. Mean- while, the dim borderline between animal and human ills remains comparatively unexplored in part because of the dearth of veterinary practitioners to approach it from the animal side, but in the main because of lack of any liaison be- tween the twin sciences of human and animal health.

articleText:
Cbc /Horning ^Bulletin!

ROCKHAMPTON 1

THURSDAY, FEBRUARY 6, 1847. j

SQUATTERS.

Arising out of the same cause a pressing need and an unused public estate-the squatter is with us now much as he was over a century ago. About 1835 men went beyond the limits of official occupation and took unauthorised possession of unoccupied land, whence arose the term "squatter." It is believed that the term was in Use in USA about this time and for much the same reason, hence there is doubt .regarding in which; country ' "squatter" origin- ated. The practice was unlaw- ful then as it is now, and disap- peared as the country w^s de- veloped and land hunger was satisfied, just as it will disappear now when the rule of law is re- stored and the people are freed from the shackles of incompetent Labour Governments, State and Federal, that hare sold out the housing problem to the Com-

munists.

It can be said with certainty that no self-respecting citizen, un- prompted by Communist helots, wants tb squat. He has no de- sire to break any law be it how- soever obscure, nor is he inspired in his action by any Inherent rebellion against constituted authority. But he does want a roof over his head, a place to where he may take a wife and in which he may rear a famliy. That is a burning need of the time, and that he was assured hy every form of propaganda in spoken br written

word would be his inalienable right as soon as the shooting stopped. . So unequivocal was this assurance that people of all sta- tions felt every confidence in making their building plans and undertaking long-range commit- ments. The slogan was a home for all, fitted with every conveni- ence from refrigerator to pastry

mixer.

How shockingly prospective home builders were let down it revealed in the fact that in last year , Hie total amount paid throughout Australia by the Dé- pannent of Works and Housing was £110,000, and only now that prices are soaring as factories ol every description1 close -down and hundreds of ships are - kept idle, has this shot up ' to £1,720,00C if it can be spent. In thc same year the State Labour Gov- ernment, also strong in the fervour of its- promises, paid through itt various housing departments a total - of $590,000. of whicl more than half . was . on behalf oj the Commonwealth. At present day costs this would -not be suf- ficient, to -provide the average num- ber of porkers' TJweHiiigg erected duringj^the. three Immediate pre- war year*.- Such, is the «um total of how two. powerful Labour Gov eramrate»í^:-with: overwhelming majorities and the resources «f a continent at - their disposal, : re- deemed their post-Hrar promises On top of this, through, theil abject surrender to Communist! who have white-anted the Laboui temple, they have made it neil to impossible for i anybody .tb. built a house even if they have monej or >credit^' to bunt-as i many oi them have. There are, of course important exceptions.

Politicians bent upon savin] their political bacon do not hesi- tate to draw. on the slender sup plies of labour, and material t< run up wool appraisement/build- ings, .or. to build, «pair and. pain' schools and railway premises ant otherwise make unreasonable an< even .dishonest use' bf availabl building supplies. . They in fae "squat" on the property of house less and "homeless people, the onlj difference between them an* squatters in buildings being- tha while the latter put the building to proper, nae with the ahelterinj of 'the homeless, politicians seek ii their squatting* to benefit non

but themselves.

>in «s campaign to Justify squatting the Communist paper "Tribune* shows that while ^thousands of N.S.W. workers live in slums, single rooms or tents, and children are debarred from school for lack of class-

rooms, lthè Sydney Turf Club, a señu*Óoverñm"ent body (of which Hr - McKelL , . Governor-General designate, is a leading light) is building magnificent new accom- modation for racehorses at Rose- hill." It also Bhowp that a Bose hiH grandstand has been .com- pletely remodelled on the most modern-which is alscr the most costly and elabórale-scale, that Moorefield racecourse premises have been renovated on. a lavish scale and that plans are in hand for like treatment for Canterbury Park. At the same time the Minister for Education stated that because the department's building programme had been held up through short- ages of labour and material, hun- dí cds of children who should have started : school last month

had to he punted »v»ay. We thus

have racehorses and racegoers squatting on what should be homes for the people and schools for their children. Nothing could have played more conveniently into the bands of the Communiste who aim at discrediting law an« order, than this wanton, disregará of the fundamental needs of th« people.

rn vueensiana there should . be

no squatting in em^ty Defence Department buildings, because there should he none of such buildings left in which to squat. Had the Queensland Labour Gov- ernment taken over from the Fed- eral Labour Government the whole

of such buildings, and disposed of them forthwith to home-builders the position would be so much ; easier with corresponding lees

temptation-or opportunity-to squat. It would also have de- prived the gentle Communist of a most valuable basis of propa- ganda. There are in this district many military buildings standing empty, the material of which Should be helping to accommodate some of our homeless legions, but our. Labour stalwarts are content to ^declare it '.to be a ' Federal matter and leave it at that.

It ? cannot be over-emphasised that the growing state of deep discontent, of confusion and dis- order'; the tecreasing tendency to

discredit law, and order and ~ to dimmish . respect for * constituted akÁority ara all fact of tbaCom 4 . :

I munist technique. Until it has

reduced society to a state of chaos* there is rio hope for Communism to overthrow existing governing in-

stitutions, and nobody is likely to j argue that its disciples have not brought Australia nearer to that unstable state today than she was

a year ago. That is because Com- j munism's most valuable allies«

today are the State and Federal Labour Governments, which have neither the power to inspire ideals nor the courage to face np io a common enemy«

articleText:
?ëe íHorning bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1047. .

WISE PRECEPTS

Speaking at the matriculation cereniouy oí the Queensland Uni- versity on Friday the Chancellor, Air Forgan Smith, offered to the student body some .words of advice that cannot but be acclaimed as timely and containing a full

measure of wisdom and truth.

The Chancellor said that the future of Australia depends on the applied knowledge and industry of its people. All things are of value but the crucial test is the use to which they are put. Whilst material progress has been phenomenal it is doubtful whether it has brought any increase in human happiness. They therefore must use thoir op- portunities, their strength and their intelligence in promoting human happiness based on all the essen- tials of a sound moral order and a higher conception of citizenship. "Independence of mind and strength of character are essential for suc tess in every walk of life," con- cluded the Chancellor, "and I advise

you to take every opportunity! available for the development of those qualities." Admirable senti-

ments, cogently put, and if as-| similated and practised likely to prove of inestimable benefit not only to the young people to whom they were addressed but to the community.

Chancellor Forgan Smith has always been adept in the propaga- tion of the lofty sentiment, as a perusal of the many speeches made during his political life bear ample testimony. Indeed it was often a matter for regret that when he had greater opportunities than any other single individual in the State of inculcating "a sound moral order and a higher conception of citi- zenship," he used his opportunities, his strength and his intelligence in leading the people of Queensland in the pursuit of those material things which he now sadly admits have added not greatly to the sum total of human happiness, though it would be quite incorrect to say that they have added nothing.

Much will have happened before the 1500 students who ássembled to listen to the Chancellor's matric- ulation address emerge to face the battle of life and put to the test the advice he has tendered fori their guidance. By that time the future of Australia, in many way* of life, will have been shaped, possibly in directions far different from what is contemplated by the students at this hopeful stage of their careers. If the wise precepts laid down by Mr Forgan Smith are to be assimilated and practised to a degree that will prove of real ser- vice to the Commonwealth, they will require to be addressed to a wider audience and to be acted on more promptly than will be pos- sible in the case of this student body.

This is the doctrine that should

be inculcated by the political end industrial leaders of today, instead of their present preachings that standards of living can be raised and prosperity and contentment achieved without work, that more leisure is of greater importance than adequate food, clothing and shelter, that the safety of the

nation can be assured. without

imposing any obligation on its citizens for its defence. We db not hear them subscribing to the belief that the future of Australia de- pends on the applied knowledge and industry of its people. They believe that it depends upon less work, or no work at all, upon destroying all incentive to enterprise and indi- vidual initiative, and casting away every opportunity of establishing commercial relations with the rest of the world. In fact, their dop trines are completely alien to those submitted by one who was once their acknowledged leader.

As to whose teachings will command the greatest respect, in the short run' Chancellor Forgan Smith's will be a voice in the wil- derness, but in the final analysis he will be found to have plumbed truths that it would have paid others than those to whom they were offered to learn before they were brought home to them "the hard way."
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, MARCH 10, 1947. WISE PRECEPTS

articleText:
«de üüornmg bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, MARCH ll, 1947.

CANBERRA BENEVOLENCE

j If Canberra ever pleads guilty to

j a wise act or a generous one it will be explained in extenuation I that Labour rule overshadowed by Communist dictatorship has become an unhallowed memory. The other day the Chifley Government con- founded the prophets by belatedly accepting the Bretton Woods agree- ment, and a few days later Mr Chifley announced that the agree- ment had been so ratified only on

condition that "Australia should be admitted to the International Monetary Fund on the same con- ditions as foundation members." Foundation memoers are those 34 nations that, having signed their acceptance of the movement, were invited to attend the inaugural meeting held at Savannah, USA, in March, 1946, there to set in motion the vast intricate machinery hy which those 34 nations hoped to bring stability to international trade and finance. Another year's grace wa6 given to laggards who might be admitted in accordance with specific rules, yet Australia over-stepped by two months even the year of grace and now, a unit representing less than 2i per cent of the total quotae, essays to dic- tate to the 34 nations the terms on which she will accept member- ship! It is the usual face-saving bluster that passes in Australia for sturdy independence, and at the council of nations for what it really is.

For fighting after the war is over the Canberra gentry will go down in history as the world's champions. No other civilised coun- try is maintaining in peace a rate of taxation that per head of popu- lation is higher than in the worst years of war. But it was different during the war when every other country was bending its every energy to play their part in the grim struggle, Canberra playboys quailed before imposing the cost of war upon a home community that was being glutted with money it could not spend. To the end v of June, 1945, Australia had spent only £292.3 per head of population and of^ that only 27-46 per cent came from the people in direct tax- ation. Another 36.71 per cent of it came from loans to which the stal- warts at Canberra could not induce their worker friends to subscribe Having regard to the ends to which those Labour stalwarts had gone over the years to teach their worker friends that to subscribe to loans was the peculiar prerogative of the "boss," the result is not surprising. The purely materialistic teachings of upwards of half a century cannot he wiped out be- cause it pays Labour prophets much better now to preach another doctrine. In the same time Canada

spent £479 per head of population of which 45.38 per cent came from the people in direct taxation and another 44.60 per cent in loans.

It is with this tawdry drop-sheet as background for their war antics that Canberra showmen are now posing as heroes in "the bloodiest war in history," and by BO doing delude none outside of Australia but themselves. It is against this also that Chifleyites announce a "gift" to Britain of £25,000,000, presumably to buy food in countries where ships are not held up by a noisy minority of disloyalists who lose their deposits wheu they face an election, it being no use trying to spend it in Australia where cargo handlings are down about 50 per cent per gang-hour. In terms of food, a fleet of 40 or 50 ships idling in Australian ports can soon eat up £-25,000,000, and repercussions of this interpretation of the Aus- tralian Government's sentiment to- wards starving Europe and hungry Britain are shown in rotting food supplies and a consequent check to production. Having regard to the experience of the ships of our Dutch allies, the man who tries to spend in Australia £23,000,000 on food for Britain might consider himself lucky to reach home safely' with the platter.

As a comparison of generosity Labour at Canberra " shows up dingily against the Oanadian yard- stick. When war broke out Canada paid up in advance of maturity all her London debts amounting to £460,000,000, and also repatrinted all Canadian bonds- £242,400,000 of them-held in Britain. Her ster-

ling balances amounting to £ol7, 100,000 were turned into an inter- est-free loan, and ehe made an out- right gift to Britain of £203,000, 000. Labour-led Australia did none of these things nor, on the other hand, did she pay her debts "n curred to feed the first AIF during the first World War. That debt amounts to £72,720,000 and is still owing. Even worse, neither in- terest nor redemption- £A3,2S0, OOO per annum-has been paid on this since 1932. Hard up a8 Britain is for overseas exchange settlement of that £72,720,000 30-year debt wonïd be the first glimmer of sin- cerity, as against blatant propa-

ganda to emanate from Labour-led Canberra.

With studied disregard for the? claims of companies "of all sorts to

a let-up on the savage taxation to j which they have been chained, the j Chifley Government is to give a I taxation hand-out to wage earners, J about £10,000,000 in tax relief, j

amounting to slightly more than1 12 per cent of the estimated tax for the current year. But the "pift" has been postponed to the bosrin ning of July, and in any eas«* mounting income is such that by then it will have cost the hungry Chifley Government nothing. With four months to go Customs and Ex- cise are £17.020,000 above the es- timate, go that Canberra benefac tors ar. actually first taxing wage earners so as to givp them a present in four months' time! Many tax- payers will not have received thei»

tax assessment on their 1947-8 in- come until March or April, 1949 which means that they will bave to wait two years for relief. The

pay-roll tax -which is to bring in £13,000,000 might have been abol- ished as a gesture of hope to em- ployers who ro millions of pounds'

worth of gratuitous book-keeping ¡ for the Taxation Commtssione*". j

while there can be no excuse otho*

than plain avarice for keeping on j the Federal lani] tax which had 'doubled early in the war and car-

ries also a 20 per cent super tas. ? In the midst of all these grudging promises and shabby evasions, 'holders of War Savings Certificates ¡are being implored to convert them

into the new issue, and that with- out being told that in the doing they will lose more than ll/- per

i-ent.

The Curtin-CMfley Government set-up has been among the war's queerest developments. The taxa- tion it is imposing now should have been imposed in 19-43 when every other country was taxing for war. Instead, the Curtin-Chifley get- up poured money into hot, eager hands and tailed to get it diverted into loans, and in the belief that inflation is being throttled thc missing 1943 taxing technique is being applied now. The ever-ex- panding not issue is nvte but eloquent evidence of how futile it

all is.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, MAY 12, 1947 CABINET SELECTION

Tile tumult and the shouting having almost died down, the agreeable post-election exercise of picking the new Cabinet is under way in Queensland political circles. The business will be officially transacted when the Caucus meets on Wednesday, but there are many outside the Caucus ready and will- ing to lend their aid beforehand.

In the case of a re-elected Govern- ment, the new Cabinet does not af- ford as much scope for speculation as when there has been a turnover j at the polls, since the old team is

practically assured of reappoint- j ment. They see to that themselves, j for whilst there may exist personal antipathies and recognition of mis- fits in the Cabinet room, Ministers invariably vote as a solid bloc on the principle * that a split is oftimes more dangerous to the strong than to the weak.

The new Queensland Cabinet of- fers some room for speculation on account of the retirement of Mr Williams, Minister for Education in the old Government, and the de- feat at the ballot ofv.Mr Walsh, Minister for Transport and Deputy Leader. There was talk of Mr Gled son, Attorney-General, not seeking office again, but if he ever had such intention he has changed his mind and will now be a runner. But if Mr Gleason is lukewarm about

running for office there are many amongst the rank and file more than chilly towards him and they may conspire together in relieving him of the necessity of making a personal choice in the matter, in which ease there will be three vac- ancies to fill.

A good deal of interest naturally centres in the prospective new min- isters. Allowance has to be made

for the customary amount of "kite flying" inseparable from these oc- casions, but as a rule only "pos- sibles" receive mention; hence we do not find amongst them the name of Mr Clark, member for Fitzroy. Fivje members of the party are considered by the experts to be in the running for the two Minister- ial vacancies. They are Mr Devries (Gregory), Mr Duggan (Too- woomba), Mr Farrell (Marybor-. ough), Mr Hilton (Carnarvon) and Mr Power (Booroona). None of them, excepting Mr Devries in the Far West, is known in the Central Division, and their chief claim to elevation lies in their standing in the party. In that connexion it can be taken for granted that they measure up to all requirements, and that none of them entertains

any unorthodox opinions which will bring them in conflict with the powers inside or outside the Par- liamentary party, who dictate Labour thought and action.

The position relating to the Dep- uty Leadership is not without in- terest. No stranger evidence of the extent of the loss sustained by the Government in the defeat of Mr Walsh can be offered than the names of those mentioned as the

panel from which his^ successor must be selected. They comprise a choice quartette in Messrs Foley, Bruce, Gair and Jones. All of them are well enough known to have re-

vealed the full limits of their ca-

pacity for statemanship, and with- out making any individiouB com- parisons it will be hoped by others than Labour supporters that Mr Hanlon will be endowed with health and strength to lead the Government for the full term of this Parliament. It ia the usual thing for a Premier sooner or later to make way for his deputy, and the middle term of a Parliament is considered a favourable moment to make the change. In fact, it was a more or less open secret that something of the kind would have happened during the present Par-

liament if Mr Walsh had continued

as Deputy Leader. If the alterna- tive is Mr Foley, Mr Bruce or Mr Gair the universal wish will be that Mr Hanlon remains at the head of the Government.

Whoever comprises the Govern- ment they will have grave enough problems to grapple with in the ensuing three years. Signs ^accumu- late that the "honeymoon" period of Australian governments is nearing an end. No longer can their most serious problems be solved by the creation of a few thousand jobs on unreproductive works and the handing out of a

free búttle of medicine. Discontent

at the growing shortage of the things that make for a reasonably contented life for the great mass of the people has hoisted a danger signal that cannot be ignored. Har- mony in industry and increased production must be achieved some- how, and that "somehow" involves a stronger hand in government than Queensland has been accus- tomed to this many a year.

There are other clouds looming also. Mr Hanlon's pledge to the Townsville ALP conference to bring in the 40-hour week regardless of the findings of proper constituted industrial tribunals and regardless also of its effect on industry will have to be honoured, and the conse- quences borne, whatever they are. The release of shipping from Fed- eral control, the removal of other controls involving subsidies, the repercussions of the Geneva trade talks, and the continuance or other- wise of British preference all point to problems ahead for the State as well as for the National Govern- ment. All call for strong and in- telligent administration, and prom- ise to impose a test on Labour government in Australia that has no parallel, not even during the years of the depression.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, MAY 12, 1947 CABINET SELECTION

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, JUNE 7, 1947.

THE SCHOOLMASTER

How many folk realise tha unlike doctors and lawyer schoolmasters have plied the calling from the days of tl Middle Ages ? That is to say, th« taught in the Kingdom of tl Mind long before either of tl others were admitted into polii society, so that however carefi man *was of his body, or hows ever jealous he was of his legs rights he leaned to culture lou before* he vested law with r modern dignity, or raised s«rger above the cult of bloodletting^ < which the barber's pole is a cot sistenf, reminder. Come to thin of it, there was a schoolmaster i tlie beginning of every road thj led men of all. callings ; and - prf fessions to their greates triumphs.

With all this in mind it becomt perplexing to realise how little i written of the schoolmaster or, a he is more genitally known, tï teacher. Books in their legion hat been written with 'the lives . t soldiers sailors, of doctoi rand lawyers, of statesmen an civil engineers; but the number t biographies of teachers is eui prkingly small.- But therè ai some which repay well the rea« ing, and a short list may help t fill this unaccountable gap i many libraries.

It is, of course, a matter e opinion, but it seems &s if prïd of place muet go to "The Stor of a Great Schoolmaster1' b H. G. Wells. Its central figure i Sanderson of Oundle, and in th hands of Wells it became a pr< vocative, fascinating story packe with human interest. D'Arc; Thompson's "Day Dreams, of

Schoolmaster" came out in Lon don in 1912 and bears all the evi dence of being the work of a grea classicist and a great gentlema whose courtesy was no less tha; hie scholarship, as D'Arcy Thomp son" of St Andrew's-assuredly wa Christopher Benson was an Etoi Honse-master, and he left behim a diary that was arranged fo publication by Lubbock whid proved-were such necessary-tha' clergymen can write diaries. Lub bock also wrote "Shades of Eton,* a vivid picture,¿from the pupils viewpoint, of Eton and iti

masters.

Unexpected flashes are ofter thrown OH the. life' -of. a mai through ; publication, . after hi: death, of'Bis'letters'and the "Let- ters of Sir Walter Raleigh," edit« by his widow, .are in this class

Thtey*! £feal firsV' - wjtlii \Raleigh'« experj^Ucég: aV a ' teacher at AH garb.; Indian and later with his Hf« I and work as professor of modem

literature at Glasgow, Livenpoo: and ¡Oxford. A: brilliant werk ! rich |ii unpredictable flashes oj humour land ^Tittle «atfee. Anothei . aerie's &t let$ej¿, .cOHijsrises. ethos* of George 'S".' Gordon, " who wai I Vice-Chancellor of Magdelen Col-

lege, Oxford^ and a pupil of Hal- eigh' at Glasgow. "White promis- ing more than it performs, thu j work ? ofieTB 6orae -jflääguing.. com ments on J. Swinnerton Phillî more, one of the most fascinating ¡ teachers of the classics.

[ Most of these books are, written with a deep sense of the aloofness and dignity of the calling of thc i schoolmaster, but there are others. One of them is from the pen ol the then Professor of Orienta] languages in the University of .Budapest, being in fact "The Story of My Struggles," by

1 Arminius Vambery. It appear«

that he set out to become a self educated linguist surrounded by pedantic defenders" of their own

! language, in the jironunciation of which Vamberj J flug vhig grave with his tongue-.aniá avoided' filling jit only by the ready U6e of."an I adroit mind»'G^ G. CÓülton'g auto- biography "Four Score Years,'.' is witty and .¿¿nial, packed with an j amazing AS^rtment of recollée I tions of preteijratory - and grammar

schools ia England and France. Another.'^ suet';. Wok Is Potter's I .*MUS^:'Ä-^^I^?>*v- a brilliantly witty/^ur^^'Ioï" the. rise of : .the teaching. * ,of . "Engilsh literature among v^ÜS^ÍSttglish people; while Phelp's ' ^nj^iography with Let I ter s*" describes with ^enormous ' gusto the 2Ôfh century American

educational and academic scene and should be in the library of every schoolmaster. Then there is, of course. Trollope's "An Autobiography" in which he said, j with mournful relish of Harrow

and Winchester, "I feel convinced in my mind that I have bee" flogged oftener jhan auy human being alive"; and then, of course,

.there was

But why fall into the error of believing . that because he is a teacher every schoolmaster devotes his leisure to reading of others of his calling ? Or why perpetuate the Greek proverb 'Tie is either dead or teaching a school" ? . It is other readers who should draw upon this - rich minc of scholastic experience, in the lives of men on whose-loyalty to lofty ideals and perseverencè with refractory and often thankless youth arc built the noble educational institutions and traditions of. today. For noble they are even if inexplicable, as becomes an inexplicable English speaking people who stand at the head of the only free institutions to survive, for a thousand years, the assailing might of would-be

dictators.

The teacher, no less than other folk, has his own ideas on the value of leisure reading. Churchill said facetiously at the height of the London blitz that newspaper editorials were his light readjnï, and Sir Charles Dilke chose a pile of Blue-books as he beaded for a

long convalescence, a taste which ¡ Se is said to have 6hared with !

Lord Samuel. The choice of "Civ-

ilisation" H. T. Buckle was "any pew dictionary," while an under- graduate in "Verdant Green" paced his room as he re&d Aristo Ehaneg in the original and cracked

is fingers in ecstacy over the, dusty jests. Finally, as if to upset

all that has gone before herein, Matthew Arnold of Rugby, accom- panied by a pile of books on Celtic literature, was encountered on a railway platform en route to a quiU Cornish village. He said that | bu" for a little light reading the j village might be dull ! Stories are \ extant of Edgar Wallace and O. Henry accompanying other schol-

astic or literary giants to Elysium j fields, but that is another tal«.

articleText:
O&t morning 9n!!erm]

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, DECEMBER 17.

LEAVING SCHOOL

With the breaking-up for th Christmas vacation approximatel;

17.000 Queensland children wij

have attended school for the las time so that the problem for then and more particularly for thei parents, in the New Year will b to get them a job. That is on thing over which a radical chang has come in the last ten years Right up to the outbreak of th second World War one of th gravest responsibilities of parent hood was to find any kind of em ployment for the boy and girl wh< had passed school age and whosi earnings, however modest, wouV assist TH running the home. Happi indeed was the mother and fathe who could proclaim that a jo] was waiting fpr their boy.. Mud more often one or both of then had to undertake a heartbreakin« and, invariably, fruitless canvas of business premises in the hopi of semiring a place by favour. TJ what extent this had an influ- ence on ' the disappearance oi large families, so much deplore; nowadays, has not been canvasser to any extent, but a little inves tigation "along those lines mighi bring to light interesting rçvela

tiona.

Happily 'for present-day par- ents^ if nût for prospective em- ployers, "tiie problem of finding £ job for the boy and girl of school leaving age is no longer a ca UBI of worry either to the parent ot the youth. As stated 17,000 wit leave school at the end of thu year, and Queensland industry could absorb twice that number Indeed, the ' danger confrontiiuj young people today is not thal they wül be unable to 'find em- ployment, but that they will find it too readily and win value il aocordingly, to their own detri- ment and to that of industry gen- erally.

This ia the golden age of youth what with Ugh wages, shorten« ing hours, social services and the preachings of industrial leaders that the proper thing is to do as little aa possible for as much as can. be got and no harm can come out of it, excepting perhaps to thai unconsidered individual, * the boat." Youth would be less than human if it realised the fallacy of many of these things, and put them away from them. Educa- tionalists and others participating in Speech Day functions have done what they could for this generation of school-leaving age, by stressing the urgency of con tinning education to the higher grades 1 of learning, and at all costs eschewing the dead-end I occupation with its present temp-

tation of high wages and easy 1 times. That the advice is sound and, if followed, would prove beneficial to those to whom ; it is addressed, is not to be argued; but faced with their own rising household budgets and difficulty in malting ends meet even parents who would like to give their off- spring more _ schooling are not proof against the importunities of the potential wage-earner, who is

[ so eager to take a job.

! Today there is * stronger argu-

ment against -the eagerness of young people to rush into dead- end occupations than either the Speech Day oratory or the obvi- ous lack of "future which these jobs hold. The very labour shortage which is leading to the plenitude of jobs and high wages is hastening tile day when less and less unskilled labour will be employed. We have not to go beyond our own city for concrete examples. The other day photo- graphs were shown abd details given of a mechanical auger intro- duced by the Regional Electricity Board> which, under the manipu- lation* of one man, excavates post holes at the equivalent rate of 25 labourers using crowbar, pick and shovel. Coal production by mechanical means is considered to threaten the employment of coal hewers to such an extent that every means, from pressure on governments to a nation wide strike, are being resorted, to to pre- vent its introduction. The man- ager of the State Cotton Board has just returned from overseas to report the successful operation of machines that will do the labour of 500 field workers. Addi-

tionally, slot machines are every day reaching a perfection that dispense with the services of more and more shop salesmen and

women.

Nor is there a wide open door of escape in higher education leading to the professions. From time to time a note of warning is

j struck "by University authorities

that the profession of the law' '.s already fully manned, that within a few years there will be a sur- plus of young. doctors, and that other professions will- speedily reach saturation point when the large number of students recruit- ed from the Services after the war become qualified.

v With educationalists stressing the dangers of the dead-end job and the warnings of the profes- sions becoming overcrowded, it might be asked where does the future of Australia's youth lie? These two questions propound a third : Are we going the correct way to ensure that the so-called dead-end job need not necessarily reach a dead-end, and that there is room in the professions for those who are anxious to qualify? The answer to that must be a decided No. In a country like Australia there should be no such thing as a really dead-end job for a person of industry and enterprise^ and

we should also be able to absorb

the output of the higher educa tional institutions. But that can be achieved only by an expanding economy capable of sustaining a larger population. Australia's economic structure could be ex- panded today by embracing out- side markets ¿ager for our prim- ary products and manufactures, and .by stepping up production of ponsumer goods- to meet local re- quirements. But the country's entire industrial leadership, and a good part of the~ political .as well, foster policies diretly antagonistic to such aims. The real tragedy of the 17,000 boys and girls leaving school this year is that they will go into occupa- tions where tirey wiH imbibe doc- trines not only leading them in*.o a dead-end, but, unless a miracle .happens, must place their country is s similar predicament.
