articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY. JUNE 4, 1947.

STATE OWNERSHIP

lu the light of recent events there appears to he good grounds for questioning the Commonwealth Government's sincerity concerning its policy of nationalisation of industries. There is a growing conviction that it is all for the nationalisation of easyrto-run

going concerns, but shies off any- thing involving a pioneering risk, and'is ready to leave to the hated Capitalist 'all undertakings that, are liable to be beset by financial j or labour problems. j

Evidence on these points is pro-j vided' by the current activities in respect of commercial aviation and

coal mining, Notwithstanding a ¡ High Court decision which checked J the initial move to take over the j companies that had pioneered commercial aviation in Australia, and without whose capital and en- terprise there would have been

no airlines to take over, the Gov-

ernment ha» applied itself assidu-

ously to achieving its purpose by other means. Lately negotiations for the purchase of the . shares held by Quantas in the overseas

service were reported, and at- the j moment considerable pressure is

being exerted by the Common- I

wealth airline to invade the intra- state field. The ultimate object is manifest-by fair means or otherwise to. force private opera- tors out . of commercial aviation and make it a Government monop

Why this desire to demonstrate the blessings of State ownership in commercial aviation, when there are so many other activities touching. the lives of the people much more closely on which the experiment could be carried out? Is it because airlines are a new and expanding avenue of com- merce with a profitable future ahead? More pertinent still, is it because it is one of the few things unlikely to be beset by labour

troubles ?

These questions arise from the circumstance that, at the very

time when the Government is straining every effort to extend its hold on airlines, it has quietly handed back to the owners Coal- cliff coal mine,* in New South Wales. Coalcliff was to be the shining example of how the Fed- eral Government could conduct coal mining, presumably by grant- ing to the miners every thing they could desire. Strange to say, or rather, needless to state, there was no loud sounding of trumpets when the mine wast handed back to its former owners. Indeed the bare fact that the transfer was made had to be drawn from the Prime Minister, like the extrac- tion of an eye tooth, at question hour in the Federal Parliiftnent.

In reply to Mr Beale, M.P.7 who asked whether the colliery "had been handed back in Maren after losing £85,000 whilst under Gov- ernment control, Mr Chifley ad- mitted that the Government had handed Coalcliff back after run- ning it at a loss during the war, but he was unable to say what was the exact loss. However,. val- uable experiments in the use of water for elimination of dust had been conducted there.

This is a typical Chifley answer. Imagine a Prime Minister Treasurer not ascertaining the

extent of the deficit before the momentous decision was reached to cut the loss and abandon the experiment. If the balance had been the other way he would have had the figures at his fingers' ends, and proclaimed them from the housetops. And what a "foot- ling" justification to put forward about "the valuable experiments in the use of water for the elim- ination of dust in mines." The (.um of £85,000 is a lot to spend j in experiments in one mine, and whatever they revealed it does net seem to have gone very far to eliminating dust in mines in a general way, since that con- tinues to be one of the staple ex- cuses for a hold-up, when there is nothing else in sight.

Before all others the coaL indusr try was one in which the Labour .Government could best have

(proved to the people of Australia

what merit there resided in its nationalisation policy, as well as the capacity of the State to con- duct industrial and commercial enterprises. Australia's entire in- dustrial machine is vitally depend-

ent on coaL With smooth work-

ing and steady production at the collieries Australia's future would be bright indeed-a vista of prosperity stretching away into the future. What an ideal field in which to demonstrate the worth of State control and management. Yet what happens? After running one solitary mine during a period when the industry was at its high- est peak of prosperity, due to war- time demand and prices, it failed so badly that all thought of per- severing with the plan was dropped and the enterprise handed back to its owners without a word, unless it was one of thankfulness at being relieved of further re- sponsibility.

Not even Queensland's ill starred venture into State sta- tions and butcheries made a. worse showing than this example of State intrusion into industry and commerce. Yet in spite of the experience the Government is all out to bring under State control the airlines, the banks and any other undertakings that are likely

to remain free from labour

troubles, are in a fair way to con- tinue making money and offer good openings for family relations and defeated politicians who were lately parliamentary supporters

of the Government. oly.

articleText:
Çfje Attiring ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON,

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 3, 1947.

MELBOURNE CUP

Tomorrow is Melbourne Cop Day. For mort Australiana the first Tues- day in November is an anodyne to

the tribulations of the other 364

days of the year. It serves'as a safety valve of sanity and good humour, which is one of the needs of mankind. The peace of the world may hang by a thread, the air may he thick with warnings and por- tants of dangers ahead, oar civil liberties may lie under threat from the whims of doctrinnsires; but if

the United/States gave away the bomb secret to the entire world, if Bussia ceased propagating her poli- tical creed, if -the bank legislation were dropped end the waterside workers were to renounce their at- tempts to - conduct our. foreign policy and took greater interest in the torn round of ships, it is Tery doubtful if the' announcement of

any of these things wonid **lure readers' away from the sporting columns' of the paper.

Between Cops probably a major: ity of men and women are pre- pared to listen to dissertations on the evils of gambling and admit that today racing is a highly or- ganised, and legalised, manifesta- tion of widespread vice which eats like s canker "deep into the vitals of society. They are also ready to be convinced that 'galloping over a mile or so of velvet turf with a

light boy on its back is unlikely to improve the breed of a horse] for any useful purpose. Between Cops also they will be convinced oí the futility of putting their wita against tile fraternity whose chance of losing is in inverse ' ratio to

their own. Bot when the first week in November approaches the still amaO voice of conscience has no chance against the flood of tempta- tion that surrounds the Oap with its sweeps and'invitations to haye a little flutter on an each way ~ba*is. If racing is the Sport . bf Sings, then tomorrow in Australia everyone will share the Boyal pre- rogative. Equality of opportunity at least offers to all.

? . As to the principal instruments employed in the business, the af. f eetion lavished on the equine family by Australians may not be as pronounced as some of our whip and spur school of poets would have the world believe^ yet there is a special sentiment towards these streamlined models, trained to the ,nünut¿ and burdened with the hopes of thousands, great . and small. Horses luckily are deprived, of the gift of self expression, other- wise it would be. illuminating, if1 not altogether flattering, to hear Cup favourite and outsider express- ing their opinions of those wno wager heavily on their speed, or lack of speed. But if the equine ar- istocrats cannot convey in words

the^^a^Bic^oJLti^bnriness they

d^w attenßon lo their importance mtha-ejibeme of things. It has been \ said ' ti®' one wilfuí jwoman can

cause more* trouble than ten men caa quell. When most is expected ai it a Cop fancy of the Valais breed can show more tempérament and upset more people than -an Italian prima.donna under the influence of a violent attack of artistic tem- perament. , V

The owners of Cap candidates have their worries also. Apart from tile cost of ownifcg a Cup horse and tiie well-known hazard* of getting it to tho port, another one lias been ' added m the necessity that has arisen to' ballot for the. rigal- to ¿tari. For more than & years a I kind; ' of natural law operated te

ensnro that the 300 or so original entrants were whittled down to the 30 odd required to bring the field within the limits of safety.

This year at the hour of final forfeit then remained in the two Cups^many more horses than cotíM be aceommodated' in the races. -The situation has -been met by a rough and ready ^ system of ; balloting, which has imposed what the vic- tims can hardly be blamed for con- sidering gross hardship on many sections of the racing public, in- cluding the owners. The position arose this year without warning. It is bound to occur again, and to evoke measures to meet it effec- tively will be a test of the capacity of those who frame and administer

racing law in Australia.

Tomorrow at Flemington, . and away from the course as well, thousands of pounds will change hands , over ibis national event Some' will face ruin, otters will be ?enriched, but there is little likeli- hood of the event being cancelled because of these happenings. Ons fact persists that because of one of our national vices, and its prin- cipal medium-which is the - Mel- bourne Cup-the name of Australia has become known world wide, where its many virtues have often failed to achieve the Bame result. -

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, JANUARY 25,

HISTORIC ERRORS

With air travel a commonplace, so that the bosom of a continent is exposed to human eyes from a coign of vantage of which birds hitherto held a monopoly, it is becoming increasingly difficult for people to realise why, for many years, the physiography of Aus- tralia was so studded with riddles.

The French believed that the gulfs of Carpentaria and Spencer were linked hy a strait, a belief which held until Flinders pushed north in 1802 until Spencer Gulf ended in mangrove swamps and saltpans. In the following year (October) Lieut. Tuckey, attached to the Collins settlement at Sorrento on

Hobson's Bay, returned from a survey expedition from what is now Geelong and reported the strong

likelihood of there being a passage leading through to Cape Bridge-

water, and it took some years to

clear up that belief.

Much confusion might have been avoided and several ships saved from wreck had it been possible to look down from a plane on the Middleton Reef area, which lies just under 300 miles due east from Clarence Heads. This reef was discovered on November 10, 1788, by the store ship Golden Grove and named by her commander after the then Comptroller of the Navy. Wary mariners at once gave the place a wide berth, only to find their ships either ashore or in danger of being dashed ashore on

a terrifying reef that seemed to drift into their path. No matter what they did the spouting reef bobbed up under their bows, and after clearing it they were again finding themselves in imminent danger, of once more running on

it. It was more than 30 years ere

it was discovered, that there are

two reefs, Middleton and Eliza- beth, separated from all other reefs by at least 1000 miles and from each other by only 28 miles.

A scout plane would soon have cleared up the misunderstanding caused by the error in longitude which caused Hovell and Hume to believe on December 16, 1824, that they were camped on the shores of Westernport, whereas they were in fact camped on the beach near Bird Rock Point, Gee- long. Their glowing accounts of

the pastoral land through which they passed led to a settlement

being established at Westernport in November, 1826, the members of which eked out a wretched exist- ence until the settlement, based on error, was abandoned in January, 1828. But it was not until Henty landed on Hobsons Bay in No- vember, 1834--or ten years after

the historic error--that the reason for the difference between the

Hovell-Hume description of Gee- long country, and that of luckless settlers at Westernport of their surroundings, became apparent. Yet a plane would have cleared up the mystery in half an hour,

Near the western corner of the Northern Territory appear the

names Queen's Channel and Vic-

toria River, which were bestowed by Wickham of HMS Beagle in December, 1839, in honour of a young girl who had just ascended the throne of England. The river and estuary were but newly discovered, and were of such noble proportions as to bring honour to the christening. This was accen- tuated by the fact that the Beagle negotiated the river for 45 miles to a secure berth in Holdfast Reach, where she watered liberally from wells on the western shore. To all appearances the river was boring south-east towards its source in the unexplored heart of the continent. What is more, it added up with a story brought back to Sydney in 1831 by an

escaped convict named Clark--alias

The Barber--who had sojourned for some years among the inland blacks. Among his peregrinations with them was a journey down the Kindur, a great river that ran northwards to the ocean, and Surveyor-General Thomas Living- stone Mitchell set out in 1831 to test the story. His wanderings brought him to a river which he named Kuraula, now the Mac- Intyre, at that part of its course which ran north-west, but he found on following it that it turned and joined a number of other ill-conditioned rivers to run south into the Barwon. It would have saved him much heart- burning had he remembered that lesson 15 years later.

Many things occupied Mitchell's time in the ensuing years, but the " Kindur " river story persisted. His southern explorations took him to Victoria and the southern border of what was to become South Aus- tralia, but by 1845 he was free to solve for all time the riddle of Kindur, to which Wickham's dis- covery of the Victoria River had given such support. Moreover, popular attention was directed strongly to the matter of exploring central and northern Australia. Mitchell left Boree for Bourke on December 15, 1845, two days before Leichhardt arrived at Port Essing- ton, and five days before Sturt reached Cawndilla--and safety-- after his tragically gruelling ex- periences on Cooper's Creek.

On first coming upon the Bely- ando Mitchell imagined that here at last was the elusive Kindur, but its easterly trend led him to de- duce--correctly--that the river discharged into the Pacific. Then on September 15, 1846, he found after passing through a gap in the

hills :

"The realisation of my long- cherished hopes, an interior river falling to the north-west in the heart of an open country extending also in that direction. Balboa's de-

light at the first view of the Pacific could not have surpassed mine on this occasion."

'FoHowihg the tiver steadily f ten days it led him undeviating tb the-north-west, by which til jbig enthusiasm was rising in mu the same ratio as his proviflo

were fallinfr so. " jrftt «f^P*

of devotion, zeal and loyalty I therefore gave to this river the name of my gracious Sovereign Wueen Victoria." A very small scout plane would have corrected his belief that he was naming the head, where Wickham had named the mouth of the same river seven years earlier. But he had no plane, and so Kennedy-hisv second j in command--was sent in thé fol-

lowing year to trace the river to its mouth. And so Mitchell's Vic* toria River became the Barcoo which, in turn,- became Sturt'B Cooper's Creek. So ended the

Kindur River myth. But it took a lot of killing-mum more, in fact, than would have been neces- sary in these days of bird's ey«

views.

articleText:
fpfcc ^Horning ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, FEBRUARY 17, 1947, j

STILL DRIFTING

Stridents of, Australia's; econo- mic and industrial life over the last one and, half decades can scarcely have failed to be im- pressed with a curions analogy between the economic conditio na

of the depression and the indus* trial position today. During the economic slump we had depriva- tion in the midst of plenty, whilst today there exists a growing state of unemployment in the face of an unprecedented shortage of man- power and - an unsatisfied demand for the products of the land and pf eons omer goods that is without parallel. Just to add to the general lunacy pf things there is an insistent demand to curtail hours and reduce production in the few industries that are still functioning; whilst «very second person ..unemployed want« to be a starting-price bookmaker, a Gov-

ernment official or a canvasser.

Nothing could be more illustra- tive of the state of growing un- employment in the face of acute labour shortage than the tailoring trade ia Rockhampton, cited a few days ago- . Under anything

approaching normal conditions

there would most certainly be a shortage of operatives in the tail- oring trade, since tile demand for new clothes by' the male populace is great indeed and they do not lack the means of purchase. But local tailoring establishments are reducing to a minimum their al- ready diminished staffs, and some are faced with closing down alto- gether owing to tiie volume of business being insufficient to meit overhead. The chief cause is a lack of materials. And this is

happening in a country which ia

the main . source of the world's supply of the first essential to men's clothing seeds. The same thing applies to practically every- thing else. Hundreds of ex servicemen are being trained éo become building operatives, yet1 the building trade is hamstrung because wharf labourers will not i move cargoes excepting under a i working hours .schedule that is absolutely incompatible with an efficient shipping service, and are j rewarded for their obduracy with i annual holidays and special pay- ment for doing nothing (it ia

called appearance money). i

Nor are these the only disturb-. ing features of the post-war em- ployment position. Based upon the optimistic assurances of poli- ticians and bureaucrats there is a more or less comfortable feeling that the post-war training schemes for ex-servicemen are go- ing along swuimingly, and will eventually produce a crop of skilled and semi-skilled workers who will bave a big faflnni»^ jn improving the production position in the not-far distant future. This glib, expectation now comes in for a severa jolt The "Bulletin's" Brisbane correspondent makes some observations .on .the position of. ex-servicemen in regard to em jùoyjnent. that afford little cause for enthusiasm, and ought to make .post planners and blue print

architects hide their heads in shame, -.

Few demobilised - servicemen* says the Brisbane correspondent, are leaving the cities to take up work io. the country- and still, fewer are going on the land as primary producéis. The . number of returned servicemen in Brisbane

who- have taken ap such "Jobs as iee parters, canvassers, fruit hawkers abd tile like ig far too great, Furthermoreí* far too many men bave been pushed' into jobs which have no part-in production, but merelv in distribution and

less' useful "way*. As .jobs these might, provide good enoogh retorne to tue men, bnt Australia LAnd particularly Queensland, wants men wno will take part in actual production, no matter of what kind. It becomes painfully ob* viona that since demobilisation be- came a reality fax too many eer vicemen^ ¿ave been sidetracked intip jobs that are .of no real use to the community. They sra in fact parasitical on the general body of citizens. It is not the fault of the returned. men. but

thjeir tragedy. *The majority of them were untrained when the; joined the. forces, and many of them are working heroically . in their deadend 'jobs to lift them- selves to something better.

The foregoing is a pen picture of things as they exist in Bris- bane, but it differs only in degree to the state of affairs in ever; city and town of any size through- out Australia. And this disturb- ing account refers only to ex servicemen. What of those who cannot claim.such advantages ai their war service entitlee them? Meanwhile the ranks of thi bureaucrats are being added t< and .the Prime Minister, in hi latest pronouncement, hints ai further heavy governmental com mitments, which will preclude much prospect of taxation reduc Hon and certainly will do nothin¡ towards improving production o anything- excepting sandshiftinj

jobs. _

If we nave not already reache a point beyond that state whic has been described as a commun

ity living by taking in eac other's washing-there ara ele ments in the community wh think they can live without eve toking in the washing-we ax not far from it- One thing cei tain is that no country can carr On for long when everyone wan to be a government employee c a starting-price bookmaker, or

In view -of these trends lt

not surprising that many peer who" are not given to incurrí i brain fag by speculating On t future, have an uneasy feelii that Australia is heading f retiring that is almost certa

sphere as so more than a, passing j phase would like to feel more as- j

articleText:
Ct)e ÜSoming JiuIIetin

ROCKHAMPTON

TUESDAY, SEPTEMBER 9, 1947.

CANBERRA BANS

The stock remedy dispensed I Canberra for all human ills is

ban. Taking a line from Brita« whose main trouble is that si must import goods if 6he is to liyi the miracle men at Canberra app! to Australia, which must export : exist, the fiame remedies for weat! ering the economic storm as thos used by harassed Britain. .Fi from being troubled at prospect for footing the bill for import Australia had an export balam over imports for the 21 months 1 thc end of June last of £120,370 OOO, and even allowing for import being reckoned in sterling and es ports in Australian currency, thi is a mighty fine credit balan» That is to say, over that perio Australia was a creditor natioi She had commodities that othc countries wanted, and were prc pared to buy, that much in excès of what we were able to get froi them. Yet the remedy devised b the Canberra Brains Trust is t shut down on imports, which i another way of saying that w must ateo shut down on export to any country which has not th gold to pay for such excess goodi But particularly must we refraii from taking goods from USA. I

seems as if Canberra is detei

mined that, at all costs, thi country shall have its depression.

A week ago it was announce« that the faint glimmerings of ¡ live-stock export trade from th Northern Territory to the Philip pines was to be banned. Know ledge of this promised trad came only with the intimatioi that the chances were heavil; in favour of it being banned, & that Mr Chifley might continue ii bis enjoyment of the misery tha; is tbe first-fruit of depression This live cattle trade was initiate! in 1921 by Vestey's-accurst o Labour-and shipments went fron both Darwin and Wyndham unti about 1930, when the Governmen of the Philippine Islands banned i so as to turn to Indo-China, wheri there were prospects of two-wa] trade. Fat cattle were not neede< for this trade, "oe the buyers pre ferred big bullocks in store condi tion,*' and while it operated i total of 55,000 head were shipped In the words of the Payne repor of 1937: "Such a trade, even if nol very remunerative, would enabli local herds to be cleaned up, ant lift the industry in tbe Darwin dis- trict from its present deplorabli state." Another virtue is that to day it would produce dollar ex change that, we are told in and oui of season, is in desperate short supply.

What the people of Australia an entitled to ask is: if the crux Oj the question today is dollar short age, why in the name of all thai hag-a semblance of sanity, cannol we trade with the only countrj which is able to supply them? T< what extent is Britain's case pre- judiced through Australia trading with USA at least on the level ol

[our exports to her? Especially is

this the more perplexing in view oi the inability of Britain to supply all our needs. Shipping Northern Territory live cattle to the Philip- pines will not prejudice 'Britain's food supply, as these cattle are fax removed from a meatworks and in any case are below chiller stand- ard. The surest way to pull down Britain is to pull down her domin- ions, and the surest way to go about that is. to apply the sam« remedy in an exporting, as in an importing, country. The surest way to aid Britain is to ensure that aa many producing countries as pos- sible keep on their feet, and the surest way to that end is to main- tain a high level of production. To put everyone in sight on short rations is not going to help Brit- ain, and to ban every prospect of trade between Australia and other nations is not going to help any- one. Taking just on one-third of our total wool exports over 21 months to the end of March last, USA is second only to Britain a« a consumer of Australian wool, and that despite all the recent hubub over the new import duty. There are many imports from USA that are not important to our Austral- ian economy; but there are on the other hand many types of machin- ery that are practically impera- tive to our further development.

Meanwhile, if aid to Britain is not to degenerate into mere lip service, that is in such prolific supply at Canberra, Australia might aid the dollar position in Britain by paying her long out standing debts, and then by ship- ments of gift food. One of Brit

ain's major difficulties is that if she buys from her Dominions she must also buy in like amount from USA, which means that the more Dominion food she imports the worse-off she becomes. But that does not apply if tho Domin. ions present her with food. It will be a new experience for Canberra -the £25,000,000 gift was merely a book entry, as Britain is not. short of sterling-but an excursion into generosity will not come amis^ up that way. It is not likely to bte forgotten that, with Minister- ial approval, the food parcels to Britain movement met with strong official opposition, and that prob- ably accounts for much of the popular aC^^^teKgrds the plight

articleText:
Oije ütorning ßuUttin

ROCKHAMPTON

.SATURDAY, MARCH 22, 1Ô47.

THE FOURTEENERS.

If we'-would know the enterprise and industry of a people we look for their major industries and their unit costs; if we would seek their culture .we browne taronga their libraries, and if we would look for the result of their scholastic efforts to instruct the young we look-in Australia-among the fourteeners who have just passed through their educational institu- tions that, in 1842, cost the people of the Commonwealth £13,860,000.

It is customary of course to examine the other end bf the process, as nobody seems quite to like being confronted with the effects of an educational system that each year spills into the com- munity hundreds of thousands of fourteeners who are, in the main, ill-taught, ill-disciplined, ill-content with the prospect confronting them,, and who generally have no idea of how to go about earning a living. Meanwhile, conferences of increas- ing magnitude and cost are either being held, are in prospect of being held, or reports of past confer- ences are being stowed away in dusty archives, while we are being warned with increasing insistence from bench and pulpit that the growing attenuation of the family tie is one of the prime reasons for the swelling tide of juvenile delin-

quency.

Let us start at the beginning, when Australia Junior, reached the mature age of five and was bundled off to school. To now he has known only parental control, but that is broken when the State, in the name of free education reaches out for him and, for most of his subsequent waking hours during school days, it dominates his life and feeds to him a queer mixture of brittle facts from fl communal font, as if to train him for quiz sessions. At home he be- comes a "bed and breakfast" pro- position, his tea or supper being strongly impregnated with home work, radio serials and family dis- cussions. The increasing tendency, towards, smaller houses or more people 'in larger houses, whick brings the inmates into closer pro- pinquity, is not helpful to Aus- tralia Junior's concentration, noi does it sweeten his outlook to be "odd man out" in the nightly radio entertainment. He stiffens sub consciously against any tendency at-home to bend him to the way ol his forbears and not all parent realise that, just as man may no< serve two masters, neither shouit two 'masters-domestic and schol astic-be permitted to apply cor rective measures to the same child

From this it appears that a fai from satisfactory system has beei evolved for the edification and im provement of Australia Junior, i system which reckons little _ o the passing years, a systen for which-as it "growed," like Topsy-none seems blamable and the main sufferers be cause of it are A. Junior, and, o course, the State. Within it hav grown up all kinds of political ai caetles, bureaucratic stronghold and traditional slogans, all of then held together by the cement o parental inertia. It takes stronj resolute folk to fight politicians 01 issues representing votes, and i requires a veritable mental, mora and physical giant to cut a wa; through the bureaucratic jungle.

In common fairness, nobod. FbouM blame fourteeners for the il

equipped condition in which the find themselves as they face up t life, as they had no say in th manner of their being fed into th scholastic machine or of the pabi lum with which they were re freshed while in there. Nor, ft vliat matter, may the parents h blamed, for they would incur

penalty did they try to save the: young from the implacable maw c the State scholastic machine, an they have no say , whatsoever other than membership on a ra enue-collecting school committee in designing the "curriculum" t which the mental processes of Aus tralia Junior are nourished. Nor the Government wholly to blam it being composed of individua from party political stock on whic is grafted, by democratic processe power to rank high as public phi anthropists through spending som« one else's money, and as such

unable to rise above the affili tionB of its members who are di¡ posed to think more in terms . brick and mortar than in terms < the trend of juvenile thought. Tl tutorial side, too, has in turn be« trained into the system which

inherited, and so is hedged in by i Theirs in any case is a thankle job, there r-"!-~ r- » r"

« I1 1 --

arduous than teaching one's own children, unless it be in teaching

those of someone else.

Maybe the remedy is to allow parents in on this job of educating

their own children. That would mean breaking away from mass education and its associated regi- mentation, that oddity which, in a supposedly free land, imposes it- self so despotically on the life of youth, lt is useless to hold educa- tion conferences of interstate or international status, if schools of fourteeners are to emerge each year on to a prospect of dead-end or pick and shovel jobs or seeking entertainment in city streets. It is idle to talk of more leisure for the people when fourteeners are kept pressed to fill in that which they already have. Our Saturday streets are eloquent of that, for even bright, crowded streets are deso- lating as media for time killing. No thinking person could look upon that milling crowd-and they are no worse in Rockhampton than elsewhere-without a shock to his complacency.

An undeveloped continent, a fall- ing birthrate, a sub-educated younger section of the community as revealed by army investigation and fourteeners trying to extract entertainment from barren city streets. Surely this is a job of men and women fearless of vision and strong of purpose, but from results most surely not one for compulsory rr-«« State éducation. |

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, JULY 16, 1947.

THE RAINMAKER

At this time when each daily news releases seems to emphasise

more aud more that the entire world's scientific mind ie concenJ

trated on the development oj engines of destruction to. hurtle through the air at unimaginable speeds,, .it is refreshing to not« that in our country, at all events, experiment? are under way. witt the design of creating conditions that» .if successful, will make the wilderness bloom and increase an£ multiply the* fruits of the eartl for the benefit of mankind.

The .experiments in rain-making, at present engaging" the attention of the. Radio Phyâics Division oil the Couricil for Scientific and In* dustrial Research, must possess à world wide'? interest, ¡while theil

value to Australia may almost bis beyond estimate. In February lasi the rainmaking scientists of the CSD3 conducted,à series of .flights over Unland "-areas in New Soutl Wales,- dufing which they dropped on the cloud . tops - dry ice (solid carbon dipxide at minus 80 degrees centigrade).

These experiments showed that man can Influence the weather, but only under favourable condi- tions. It was found that massive cumulative i cloud ^was necessary. Cloud is a mass " of tiny ' water particles and when the dry ice was dropped; it affected the cloud in two ways. First it created, as it fell, a channel of cool air in which the tiny water drops were trans- formed jnto ice crystals. These grew ' at the expense of others in the vicinity until they were heavy enough to fall as rain. Secondly the dry ice had. an explosive effect on the cloud top. It was boosted into an anvil like top in which the water drops froze of their own accord <and the rain processes were repeated. Of eight occasions on which dry ice was dropped radar

observations indicated that rain formed inside the cloud- on six occasions and on four of these rain was seen to reach the ground. One test was doubtful and a single negative result was obtained.

. The most spectacular success was a rainstorm covering more than 20 miles -which reached the ground when aircraft wer* unable

to discern any other /rain:-within

' 100 miles of the -infected - cloud. Whilst the scientists regarded this as a considerable, achievement the chief Value attached to the success was'that the tests indicated, for the first time, just-.how far they had; to go before, it co^ld ;be toid whether or not rainmaking was a practical proposition. They admît that it is' one thing ~ to produce rain -from towering cumnlous cloud, but what if ploud of this type does not appear over drought stricken areas crying out for rain? On their experiments thus far the scientists admit that they cannot create rain out of a cloudless sky. It can be produced over very limi- ted areas, but the occasions on witch it can be done «yen then are jra^-rurriermore, it has yet to be ascertained " whether or not the process, is economic, ¡

The dry ice method was only the first of a eecies of attacks on-the cloud structured In a. fresh series of flights about to be undertaken hundreds of gallons of liquid preparation will be dropped. This liquid has a strong attraction for water. When sprayed into the (cloud top tiny water particles too light to fall as rain are attracted to it, coagulated into big drops and;fall as rajiK At least, that is what happens theoretically. What the CS IR wants to discover is ^whether this method will produce rain- from more types of clpud than .will dry. ice. In these "experi- ments^-Dakota plane will .carry a tanit- Wiâr #00- gallons of liquid aniÇ spéa^.^peî.1 ^ittdar in . .-the

plane' will check results by picking up the rain echoes in. the cloud after it has been sprayed, and a ground radar station will simul -taneously be- at work to check

results.

The experiments of the rain- makers are confronted by many handicapping factors. First, little is known about what goes on inside a cloud in relation to turbulence, temperature and humidity'. Also there are no records to show what type of cloud, if any, can be expected at any .given time over drought threatened areas iii Aus- tralia. All these problems are involved in the .experiments and give some idea of -the magnitude of the task that has been undertaken.

Yet none will'contend that the

experiments .are not worth, while to. make. Indeed, it would not be* difficult to argue that the rain- making experiments of the CS£R are of far greater value tha<i the rocket range tests also to be con- ducted in Australia almost at the identical - time. It is a curious coincidence that this continent lends itself, as does no Other, to experiments potent' for so - much good or ill to mankind.

As to the value of the experi- ments, if successful, this is almost beyond -computation and to no part of the Commonwealth is it of more importance than to this region of -Central Queensland, rich in everything that contributes to

productivity, excepting regular j rainfall. j

articleText:
(Cdt jitarning SnlKHin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, NOVEMBER 17, 1947.1

LARGER ISSUES. '

At a time when there should be every reason., to look for tran- quility in the industrial life of Queensland we enter a period that is qnore pregnant with disturbance than any other of recent date. Within the past few months the basie wage has been increased to meet altered living standards; .conciliation commissioners-who will hardly be counted hostile to union aspirations-have been ap- pointed to deal with matters that j may arise in the future; the long agitated for 40-hour week has been i achieved; social benefits without precedence have been established; and there is abundant employment for al} with the will to work.

It is in full enjoyment of these conditions that Queensland is faced with a stoppage of its railway sé- vices for four-and-twenty hours, and a complete cessation of all coal production in the State, unless the Government agrees to surrender its rights and functions to an outside power. An examination of the

causes of these two threats to the industrial peace and economic security of tile State are revealing in their indication of how far wc have travelled along the path of absurdity in the matter of grounds for industrial dispute. They have little or nothing to do with wages, conditions of labour or any v^tal principle affecting the relations of employer and employee..

I The railway atop work is a ci I bersome, costly and futile prut I against the disciplinary provis! j in the Railway Act which pern I the fining of employees, in lieu j other punishment, for breaches

I the regulations. The ARU demai

j that the right of the Departm I to fine; be abolished. According J the State Secretary the ARU < j fine members for breaches of

I rules, but it does not concede 1

I right of the Department to fine : j breaches of its regulations. B J haps it would like the Departm« J to hand over all. forms of puni: j ment to the ARU. Not long a J the waterside workers sought I extra-legal authority to permit j to deal with its members even

J the "extent of matters of cargo r. I faring. It calls for no imagina ti I to visualise the absurd lengths

J which this thing can be carried. 1 j add to the general incongruity

J the situation, there is a ve j strong probability that the AI I will fine «ny of its members w j do not Abey the union order j strike against the principle

I fining for disciplinary breaches,

j The case of the threatened cc I strike is. if anything, more pi j posterons' than that of the railw; J hold-up. It is the outcome of J I attempt by the NSW Minei I Federation-i-the cause of more i

j dustrial ~ strife and economic k I to the Commonwealth than/ ai I other single agency that can 1 I called to mind in our whole h j tory-to place the Queensland co I joining industry under its thurn J Tho point at issue is ostensib I whether the industry shall be co: I trolled by a Coal, Board with j majority of Commonwealth

I State representatives, but by sk j processes of revealment it h I been made clear that it is nothii I more or less than a deliberate a

J tempt to curb coal production

J Australia by any method otb j than the present alow, costly ou j of «date means of underground mi I lng, Because of a professed fe; J thai: miners will be -faced with OJ

J employment if opencut seams .ai j exploited, coal production by pre j ent methods and at existing mint j must continue for ail time.

I So far the Premier has stood ou j for the ^development of Queeni I land's coal resources to be coi I trolled by a Board comprising

I majority of Queensland memberi I whilst * conceding the ' Common j wealth the oh airmanship.. This wil

not suit Mr Chifley, nor will . i I now suit the Queensland mineff

leaders who, two months ago

I eagerly welcomed the proposition

Most of all it will not suit thi N&W.^ Miners' Federation, ani I they axe sending a delegation ti

Queensland to show Mr Hanlon thi error of his ways.- And it is hi first sign of weakening thai he hai I consented to receive them; It i

j safé to say that no stone will, bi

left- unturned. Queensland minen I are to be asked to stop all produc-

tion Until the point has been won They will be guaranteed sustenance by the Miners' Federation, and, ol j course Queensland will be den iee I coal from other sources. At all

costs the development of open cut mines must be blocked, notwith- standing that their. exploitation ü this manne'' would meet one oi Australia's greatest needs towards indnstrial expansion, and would re- move ntost of the disabilities attaching to coal production, from the workers' point of view.

Because of a probably groundless fear that a few hundred miners mil lose their pit jobs the means of providing wants for hundreds of thousands ° of others must not be allowed to be exploited. No- thing to equal this attitude has been seen «ince the poor,- mis- guided hand weavers of Britain smashed tba mechanical looms wdútih ? they c^nca'^ed would be the means of depriving them of

the means of livelihood. The

amazing, not lo say appalling, thing is that this illogical stand has the backing of a Prime Minis- ter and. a national government. If the Miners' Federation wins the day, this thing may not stop at coal, but can be applied to every form of progress in industry. In consequence mighty principles are at stake, the consequences of which make the bank legislation puny by

comparison.

articleText:
Cfct morning Palletin

ROCEHAMFfON

TUESDAY, JANUARY 14, 194,7. TALES OF BRETTON WOODS

Of the string of lusty problems that are- cavorting about the Federal arena to keep Mr Chifley and his Ministers awake at night, the line-up on Bretton Woods is not only the most insistent but the most intractable. Most other things such as reducing taxation shortening the working week and increasing wages can all be played off against one authority or another so that* Canberra may dodge making any decision but' 'there is no such "passing the

buck" in the ease of Bretton Woods. Nothing that Australia may do will prevent Bretton Woodg agreements being imple- mented, so that Australia has either to be within the scheme or outside of it. The right to be in the scheme as an original member passed1 along with 1046, and the big tussle behind the scenes at Canberra is to try to induce Caucus to rescind at its meeting in February the decision which it passed In December last.

That is the rock on which the Chifley Government may founder, and neither Bight Wing nor Left is taking anything for granted. The Scullin Government went to pièces on the Premiers' Plan to restore Australian finances, «nd the Chifley Government stands hi danger of a like disaster over the Bretton' Woods plan to maka stab» international finance. That the former achieved its purpose seems to have escaped the atten- tion of its detractors, who- had no Alternative more promising than repudiation'and confiscation; just a« the most virulent critics of the latter propound no alternative to it, nor do they try to show how standing out is going to improve Australia's chances of selling her exports among Soviet Russia, New

Zealand and some Central and

South American republics, who are siso standing ont. That ia not to say that the Bretton Woods bloc will not take such of our ex- ports as it requires, bat it will be on terms in the making of which Australia will have no say other than to aeeept or refuse, and that seems to be the main reason offered by objectors to joining the

scheme. The terms and conditions worked out and imposed by the nations joined together by Bretton

Woods are the terms and condi- tions which Australia will or will not accept, whether she is a mem- ber of the scheme, or not.

But if Australia means little to Bretton Woods, Bretton Woods is vital to Australia, on which lat- ter point the Chifley Government is hopelessly split, with Mr Ward leading the Left Wingers. It will be a duel to the death, and the winner will become leader of the Government. Unlike the 1931 split When there waa a mere shadow of » majority, the Chifley Govern- ment commands such a following that a major fight such sm this can he waged within the party without involving " the possibility of Messrs Menzies and Fadden marching through the breach to the Ministerial Benches. Ward is a forceful fighter who will have the powerful support of Mr J. T. Lang, who still believes that it was his theory and not the Prem- iers' Plan which pulled Australis

out of the mud at the last de- pression. What he is not so ready to admit is that it was his theory and not the Premiers' Plan that caused the Government Sav- ings Bank to close its doors. Bot both Lang and Ward are well primed with horror stories of "Wall Street domination" and the fell purpose of the Bank of Eng-

land to "direct a reduction in the Australian standard of living." Laug warns us that Australia will have to "find £150 million as our quota." What he did not state was that only 20 per cent of that quota or £80 million, would be called up for direct loan opera- tions, and of thal only 2 per cent

of £0.6 million would need to be in gold or USA dollars. The re- maining 80 per cent or £120 mil- lion would be retained in Aus- tralia as a reserve against losses,

just as any other kind ol Aus- tralian business would hold its re-

serves here.

Behind Mr Chifley is ranged bia Brains Trust and his long adher- ence to the somewhat shaky fin- ancial principles of the Austral- ian Labour Party. How far one of these supports the other is a moot point, but there seems little doubt but that Mr Chifley would be a much more command- ing figure did he stand alone. As a background to this Professor D. B. Copland, who was appointed Minister to Chins, f ure ed up un- heralded at Washington to but- tress the magnificent ambassador- ial set-up there. . The explanation was that Copland had teen im- ported from Chungking to lead an international conference that, ap- parently. Ambassador Makin with his Assis tai.t Minister, and staffs At Kew York, Sis Francisco and Washington coaTd not lead!

While Australia was still pond- ering over this development Cop-

land moved on to London on what has been described as "a /secret mission." This fact has been seized

upon by Lang, who identifies Cop-

land as "co-author of the Prem- iers' Plan, designer-in-chief of Australia's controlled economy,"

and he sees in it a sinister move at the behest of international ?financiers to tie Australia to the wheel of the Bretton Woods agreement. Whatever the job in hand "Bretton Woods, ' tariff re- duction, international trade agree- ment, the call has gone out for Professor. Copland. Beasley and Makin haws been passed over." Of such stuff as this opposition to Bretton Woods is built, and both Lang and Ward are talented ex- ponent« of "putting- it over." It is open of course for the Prime Minister to take the people into

his confidence hy expoundinaf the. :

?---,-¡-J

facts regarding Bretton Woods, and so counter the lively charges that are being levied against it. But that is not his line. He will face with sealed lips maybe the greatest teat of his experience, a test on which hangs the Prime Ministership and also the future prosperity of Australia, and white I the former is personal to him the

latter is personal to everybody j living in the Commonwealth.

i . If Mr Chifley can induce Caucus

to : change its mind and stand for

I Bretton Woods he will emerge

i from the contest with restored

political stature. If he falk, as it seems at this stage that he might, his political power will have passed to other hands, and his re- gime will be remembered less .for < the problems, that it faced and

solved, than for those that it ac- cumulated and nourished as if they were holy things.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON TUESDAY, NANUARY 14, 1947. TALES OF BRETTON WOODS
snippet: Of the string of lusty problems that are cavorting about the Federal arena to keep Mr Chifley and his Ministers awake at night,

articleText:
?&)e horning ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1946.

FEDERAL TAX REDUCTIONS

After unwarranted delay a] under extreme pressure the Goren ment has at length come forwa with substantial tax reductions, < pecially in the field of income ta The first J thought that arises

that the reductions announced a a complete vindication of the clair made by the Opposition parti before the last election that an a round reduction of 20 to 28 p cent could be brought in at t] beginning of the current year. Th claim Mr Chifley contested hotly < the hustings, and after being r turned to power he maintained th¡ view, even in the face of mountii evidence to the «ratrary5 wii extraordinary obstinancy. It wi only when it was repeatedly c monstrated that revenue mount« after each grudging reducti< wrung from him that Mr Chiflf conceded there might be somethir to the contention that , if tax« were cut sufficiently to encouraj business enterprise and to offer i centive to greater individual effor he would enjoy a more buoyai revenue than ever. The preset scale of reductions are doubtlei the result of overwhelming ev dence that they are possible ar the strong opinion held by tl public and by Labour Party fe lowers. In the end Mr Chifley mut have stood practically alone in hi

hesitancy.

An examination of the ne'

schedule suggests that the Go1 ernment has given slightly moi than the Opposition promised, bu has made us wait much longer fe it. The procrastination has nc been much of a- saving when offse by other considerations. If in- mediately after the election M Chifley had come down with a ta reduction scheme of these propoi tions and had laid emphasis o the fact that it imposed an obliga tion on every section of the com munity to justify it by great« production it would have fonn them in the mood to respond. B; holding off until now a condition o drift has set in, production ha fallen away, and it will be som« thing of a miracle if the tax cut have the stimulating effect tha would have been the ease som months ago. Nevertheless, that doei not lessen the responsibility of th community to make an effort t> ensure that the «nts do have t stimulating result. If the taxpaye is simply going to accept the con cessions as another Governmen hand-out that does not involve anj responsibility on his part woult perhaps be better that things re mained where they were.

The biggest reductions in the ne\< schedules apply, as was to be ex pected, to the lower income brack- ets. The rebates to family men an considerable, ranging from total ex emption from income tax and socia; service levy on an income of £Z(K for a taxpayer with dependan! wife to £500 for a taxpayer with a wife and six children. The re bate for recognised dependant) goes up from £100 to £150 and for each child under 16 from £3C to £50.

Something, but not much, ha« been done for the higher income brackets in that the income tas and social service contribution im- posed on incomes exceeding £500C will be limited to 15/- in the £. That should do away with the com- plaint that some people have been called upon to pay as high as 18/6 in the £ to the destruction noj only of further enterprise but to the curtailment of their present ac- tivities and consequent injury to

the State.

Company tax has remained un- touched, which is hard to under, stand if the other reductions are influenced by a desire to raise pro« duction and provide incentive. In view of the Australian employment position alone there is every reason to encourage commercial and indus- trial development, and company taxation is held to be the biggest obstacle in the way. However, Mr Chifley and his advisers doubtless

will claim to know best.

Included in the financial decisions taken by the Cabinet is an increase in pensiona of 5/- per week. No- one will question that existing economic conditions bear heavily upon the pensioners, who must be hard put to make ends meet, but the fact that the increase adds another £8,000,000 annually to the pensions bill cannot but draw at- tention to the fact that these huge pay-outs with nothing to offset by way of inflowing contributions will eventually become a load too great to carry.

Consequently another proposition just released is of considerable in- terest. It is that consideration is being given to the introduction of a national superannuation scheme to replace the present pensions system and ali public and private schemes. Under the proposals re- tiring allowances free of the means test would be provided for every- one on reaching the prescribed re- tiring age. The idea has not pro- gressed beyond the stage of inves- tigation by departmental officers, but Cabinet is said to be anxious to have it placed before the Party as soon as possible.

More of this will be awaited with interest. Does it mean that the Government has at last come to see, if but dimly, that the time is approaching when pensions and social benefits can no longer be handed out as though the money jrrew on trees? It is possible, for is it not a fact that even Mr Chifley, most obdurate of men, was brought to see both the imperative need and the practicability of the pre- sent taxation reductions? The c»se of a contributory scheme for super- annuation and social services is

even stronger.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON FRIDAY, MARCH 7, 1946. FEDERAL TAX REDUCTIONS

articleText:
, The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, JULY 12, 1947.

THE ROYAL ENGAGEMENT

Amid a shattering of ancient re- gimes and the violent termination" of long hereditary eras outside of

the ' English-speaking world, the' British Crown has gone from. strength to strength. Today, with j the betrothal of a girl princess who will in due course become Queen of the British Commonwealth of Nations, the British Crown is stronger than ever.,before. In ' a Commonwealth in which every member-and the oldest most of

all-is honourably weakened after passing through dark years of heroic labour and devoted sacrifice in the cansé of humanity, that strength finds its most appropriate symbol, as it did 110 years ago in

the. person bf a. young girl. To j many thousands' of ^people \ all. over]

the world /t he simple earnestness j of the sweet voice which came to/ their homes on Áprü21 last:

"I declare before you -all that ray

-whole'fife, whether it be long or short, shall be devoted to your ser- vice and' the service pf oar .great Imperial tajnBy. I shall riot -*ave -the strength to carry out this "dedication alone unless, sou joni in with me, as I now invite you to >áo." ?

is still fresh in their memory. lb WBA Princesa ^Eíitebeth, r-jerp^sing' the threshold' ^

j eating her îtte;;îo a listening ;&n [ piré."-.Thé wizardry of wireless," ! that enables i«Hsí%oj»m"'*tg^ «j>e¿k direct^

I clear tbat^he lords and -\laoUeH of}

the court stand only oh toe steps of tjíe throne, . enabled an '; ac- knowledged: ^heiress to thai'Throne to beg the'help; of her prospective, subjects.C "i->t-?±ii

The, strength;; of -British aovT ereignty lies in the fact ' that it rests upon a strictly domestic foundation,, and is today as inde- pendent of outside influences, as

any seat of^jiower m ,the^worW. j Thanes^ ]h^v^.,h^n jBuppori^i jbyj

force of ' arms and intoleranceby ! ancient prestige and by mystical ' belief in a divine right. But they- ; have all been swept away«- The King of the British Commonwealth of Nations grasped a sceptre which etiler. rulers either -scorned or. hesitated to touch-the sceptre ol, service which makes the ruler the. servant of his subjects".

Princess Elizabeth spoke in brave, if hazardous times when she made that offer of service On her coming of age'in South Africa, but it Was an invitation to. all men of goodwill to. work ? together. Her grandfather,- Sing George V,; »by refusing to Subscribe to an acces- sion oath that was offensive , , to

Roman XMhoïics, hy being rweJyed by ihe Pope! ai; $hé Vatican, "ind? by inviting to:Buckingham Palace tie variousleaders of opinion to discuss "the Irish question, set an example of that goodwill. He set it again in the economic crisis of 1932, when, it seemed that collaps- ing credit would . involve tile United Kingdom in ruin, by jour- neying from Scotland to London,

soon after which Prime Minister MacDonald resigned, but his seals

of office were handed back to him : and a National Government- was formed. In all of these éventa the

King played his part according"'to his conscience, and the people backed the King for he had pre- served their interests from the.wel- ter of conflicting politics. Against this background of service Princess Elizabeth dedicated her life to the service of the British people, ;n dedication surmounted by the nobie motto "I Serve." She might well go hack some three centuries to her royal intmesake who told Par- liament: "Though God hath raised me high, yet'this 1 count the glory of my «rown-that. I have reigned with jour lové.1* ,

Today, the Empire welcomes the news of Princess Elizabeth's be throthal, and sets the seal of ap- proval on her choice. For all that we tnay . know, she followed the

natural course of all free women and was not influenced-as has I been the lot of women of royal ' blood before her-by the urgency : of international politics or the

griping heed, of expediency. The j future of Greece would not be in- j flueneed.by the second in line of!

succession to her troubled throne

becoming allied in marriage with 1 Britain's future queen, as he re- nounced all such rights. when he accepted the duties of British citi- zenship. Lieut. Philip Mountbatten, BN, is a natural choice rather than a political pawn, the free- selection of a high-spirited young woman | rather than the chosen of elderly statesmen. . .

Every' generation makee the British monarchy less political and more social and representative. It is today more than ever before tile mirror in "which the people may see their own ideals of Ufe,'and in it Princess Elizabeth will stand for the aspirations of men and women of her own age. She will stand for all the effort to build np, on the unshakable foundations that her forbears and the British people have laid, a wider freedom and even higher order than this free Commonwealth of Nations has yet achieved.

articleText:
Cte iteming bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

WEDNESDAY, FEBRUARY 5,

1947.

NSW LABOUR ELECTS A

LEADER

Today big things are afoot in Room 32, Macquarie Street, which is the inner temple. of the NSW Labour movement. As Mr McKell

moved on to Canberra to occupy the ehoes lately vacated by HRH the Duke of Gloucester, so must someone move into the place whence Mr McKell departed. For the past few days high priests of Labour have gathered in small groups and ^qehispered guiltily their hopes and fears, only to break away and form up into other groups obsessed with similar hopes and fears. It. is "a time of tense waiting and ? watching for eigne and portents, for none knows who of the existing Cabinet is nursing a secret determination to become a candidate if the omens and portents take a propitious tum. Most of them recall that after sitting on the rail during a hettie party crisis McKell started unex- pectedly in a jostling* field of hot favourites and rode to victory on a oommiasion that went astray-or

so it Vas claimed.

Much «table support will go to Mr H. J. Heffron, Minister for Ed- ucation and Child Welfare, who has represented Botany since 1930. Al- though born at Thames, New Zea-

land, Heffron'-, ancestry goes back, to Londonderry, limerick. He haa dropped much bf the fire and en- thusiasm of youth, and now affects s - diplomatic, suave approach to major problems, of which NSW

Labour baa abundance. One handi-

cap is that stalwarts who have to face up to the hurly-burly of poli- tical strife are not enamoured of Heffron's kid-glove technique, ana another.is that critical campaign director» are unlikely to regard him as a good-draw card for the on- coming election, which promises to be tough. His association with the "Hands off Russia" slogan is not regarded in all quarters as a happy augury. He also promised a balance sheet of party funds, that there was to be no Inner Temple in the Labour movement,' and that all main issues would be decided by Caucus. Opponents-are asking

where he wa» when the reform

policy was side-tracked, and they also want to know whether be could maka a worse mess of admin- istering the .State- than he has achieved wHlF educational facilities which, they claim, are in a chaotic state. '

Mr J. McGirr is alike a stable hope and despair. A pharmaceuti- cal chemist, he has spent much

time of late on the science of ap-

plied chemistry, which has imbued m him a sense of detachment from

the more dynamic Labour lights. They fear that he may have be-

come bitten with Heffron's reform bug, in which case there is not much doubt about the course he would steer-even to the extent of extinguishing politically - some of the dynamic lights. To talk reform in Boom 32 is to invite Left-wing tommy-gun reaction, with the Com- munists .passing up the ammuni- tion, An even more serious hurdle ia the fact that as Minister for Housing since 1941, McGirr is to become tile' scapegoat for all the housing scandals that have flour- ished under the Curtin-Chifley-Mc Kell dynasties, and there are grave doubts about his ability to retain Bankstown, which he has repre- sented since 1&27. A premier who started out with that "swag*' of unpopularity would be the worst possible leader into an election fight that appears at this distance as if Ss will go the full ten rounds.

Mr W. P. Dunn, Minister for Conservation since 1944, is in a different category. He is anex-ADJ men and grandson of k a Waterloo veteran, though neither of these is likely to enhance his prospects among Labeur chieftains. Bather axe they liable to discount them, there being strong views on the propriety t of defending one's, country, and since the Curtin Government - showmen got ««listed USA men ito come along and do the defending those

Views have become settled convic- tions. But Dunn has other claims. He was a teacher with farming af- filiations', and is the spear-head of Bight Wing Labour's attempt to consolidate its position among primary producers under the insinu- ating guise of the "Labour Country Party."-a bright thought which does not appear to have caught on ttl Queensland. The important point is that with the central votes locked up in so compact a bloc there may not be enough of those primaries to go round, so that *the Labour white hope sf the bush" may get enough Bight Wing primaries to give him a standing until the second prefer- ences start to fall his way. It is a slender lead or advantage which he shares with none* other.

The Deputy-Premier, Mr J. M. Baddeley, has been Chief Secretary and Minister for Mines since 1911, and with the probable exception of housing there is no portfolio that has been so charged with trouble over the past five years than that

of mines. To elect as Premier the scapegoat of all coal shortages and their associated blackouts and walking to work and reverting to open-fire cooking would be to in- vite disaster at the election in May next, and the diplomats of Boom

32 are not such novices. The result

is that nobody gives Baddeley a chance to survive the first ballot.

A likely surprise is Mr C. E. Marth), LL.B, who has been At torney-General since 1941. He was called to the bar in - 1936, and served as Captain ADJ* on com- bined operations in New Guinea, both of which are more likely than not to prove a handicap. High-up Labour believes in education only to the extent that it provides an

excuse to splash money on the brick and mortar side of scholastic edifices. More often than not it is suspicious of learning, and there is no place like a secret ballot to work off a grudge against anyone who took the trouble tb acquire the right to have letters follow

his name.

Whichever way it goes the issue will be close, with the likelihood that those who bite the dust in the first ballot will plump for someone

whose Ministerial duties have not antagonised him with the electors who are to be wooed in May. FoT that, of course, is the major long view consideration, though it is un- likely that anybody in Boom 32 will give up his chances of the Premiership to accept it.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY, JUNE 26, 1047.

WHEN-PREMIERS MEET

There will be wigs on the green at the next Premiers' Conference, with not only the two "Tory" States of South and Western Australia driving the Chifley rabble of Government by bureau- crats and Communists {rom ono untenable foxhole to another. The causes have their origin mainly in tho Tarzan-like grip _ the Commonwealth Government is re- taining on ' its dimin6hing war powers-that and the indifferent use it is making pf these and other powers to get the nation geared into a condition of full production.

Seeing that Australia with the rest of the -Allied nations signed peace treaties on February 10 last with Bulgaria, Finland, Hun- gary, Italy and: Rumania there is much reason jf_or believing thaï, were the validity of the Defence Transition Act challenged in tha High Court of Australia they would not be upheld. You cannot be at war and sign peace treaties at one and the same time. An- other reason for challenging the war powers is that they are being used to defeat the verdict of tb9 people given at two referendums one of them taken since the war, and. it is unlikely that tie High Court would refuse to take cog- nisance of that. In any ca6e, the whole Act goes into the discard by effluxion of time on December

31 next.

Mr Chifley's stand on wage pegging is less secure than it was before Parliament raised the pay of its members during the cur- rency of that provision. Tha question of whether or not the j

increases were merited is beside the

point, for just as good reasons for raising the wages or salary of millions of other Australians could have been advanced as the poli- ticians put up in their own behalf. The point is that the economic basis for wage-pegging makes no distinction between wage or salary earning classes other than in the case of those on the lower rungs of thc ladder. Every argument put up by politicians in favour of in- creasing their pay shot holes in the armour plate of the wage pegging regulations, so that it will be a sorry shield which the Chifleyites will take with them to meet six hungry State Premiers.

Another, reason . for disquiet ia the case which the Communists

areví^ JbwiláiBg «j»-- -against rthe Chirléjr'";règîme. "At ""no* time in the history of Australia has the aggregate industry and commerce of the nation been slowed down so progressively and dangerously as now; at no time before have the shortages been of goods and services so fundamental to main- taining- production as now : at no time before have the machines and appliances of the nation been run so nearly to the point of major breakdown as now. It is true that many wheels are still turning, but many of them are obsolete and out of date or are so worn that they should be on the scrap-heap, or are being kept in service by

material taken from there. There is no secret about all. this,. and people in the several States are demanding, as the Chifleyitee are either helpless, hopeless 01 powerless, that their Governments take a hand. After all, it is the people of the States who arc suffering, and they want to know what their Governments intone doing about it.

Then there are the States tBc Government of which anticipated the Arbitration Court by making an election pledge to bring ii the 40-hour week, and in this re- gard Premiers Hanlon and McGin are particularly unhappy. Thc promising was easy, but fulfil- ment without power to raise th« necessary funds is quite anothei matter. Having surrendered theil taxation rights to the Common wealth Government, the only wai left to State Governments am local authorities by which to raisi the wind to pay for their share ol this innovation will be by iiasreas ing freights and fares on train and municipally-owned tram- anc buses ; by increasing rates anc rents on land in both country anc town ; by increasing rates 01 gravel and timber royalties liquor, probate and successiot stamp duties, motor transport betting, liquor and lottery licences and the other minutae of nationa housekeeping. These charges hi everybody alike, and no Laboui Government likes that kind o taxation, so there will be a strong bid to wrest from Comrade Chifley the power to tax incomes, througl which there is greater opportunity to delude people that it is thi other chap that is paying. Tha

both Hanlon and McGirr set ou to show their disciples that, givei another term of office, they coulf achieve the 40-hour week whicl Chifley said could be brought abou the Arbitration Court will not pre dispose the Prime Minister t< shelter them from the blast U which they have exposed them selves. He might have tb dro: wage-pegging, but Comrade Chine; is unlikely to let go his strangle hold on income and compan;

tax.

Invasion by the Commonweals Government of purely State ai traffic is not ' likely to go uncon tested, if only because it will b in keen opposition to one of tb State's good customers. Comrad Hanlon has surrendered the State" rights by approving the T.AJS invasion of intrastate traffic probably because he hopes to ge something handsome from Chifle; that will help him with his 4C hour week snag. A State ma; not tax a Federal instrumentality but it can tax those using it, ii this case passengers and freigh

carried within State boundaries If for his own reasons Comradi Hanlon will not so tax this venturi of his friend Chifley, it is practic ally certain that, both South an<

Western Australia will. Having lost the Benambra by-election Comrade Cain (Victoria) is ajso in trouble, as Labour crashed most heavily in the industrial area of Wodonga, so he will go to the Premiers' conference with nothing to give away and mighty little for which to hope.

One of the major battles-there will be several-will centre round

wage-pegging, which the ACTUl is sworn to have scrapped. If

that goes then the Commonwealth j Prices Branch, one of the major' bastions of bureaucracy, will be swept away-either that or the already opulent black-marketeer will be granted a new lease of life.

Prime Minister Chifley might avoid the breakers by being more conciliatory to the States, but

the Commonwealth invasion of State airways and the dictatorial dragooning of all local authority

accounts into the Commonwealth Bank looki more like a declaration of war on them. Well, if Prime Minister Chifley goes to conference

stripped fol battle he is likely j

to get all he wants without going outside of hit turn party.

articleText:
Cfc jlotning ^alíettn

EOCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY. SEPTEMBER 13.

1947

A CULTURAL MILESTONE

Unheralded, and quite undeserv- edly' unsung, the form of adminis- tration which has for so long guided the. destinies of the Rock- hampton School of Arts faded quietly off-stage and the Rockhamp- ton City Council . moved into pos- session. It was like the impercept- ible merging of one season into another-^only that folk know what to expect from the incoming sea- son. In this case they-or some of them-are left with their hopes.

The Rockhampton School of Arts means more to the culture of this district than is suggestea even by the quality of its library ser- vice and the granitic embrace of its auditorium chairs. Its influ- ence stretches back to the stark

pioneering days of the city, when crinolines floated along the' quag- mires termed streets by usage, and bearded men in corduroys and red bandana neckerchiefs regarded hopelessly the preponderating mas- culinity of the population. It had its genesis at a meeting held over 86 years ago on July 23. 1861, when 14 earnest folk delivered it from the womb of crude material- ism and gave a focal point to which generations unborn might shackle their cultural aspirations and ef

forts. More they could not do with-the -material at their dis- posal, legs they could quite easily have done and spared themselves tlie worries of steering their pro- tege through its teething troubles. These men were-it is meet that they become known to this generation-Bev. S. Kelly, Messrs C. Archer, F. N. Beddek, A. Bertram, H. Boyle, W. J. Brown W. H. Buzacott, J Dougr iaB, R. M. Hunter, J. Jardine, J. A. Larnach, P. D. Mansfield. J. Palmer and A. F. Wood, and they decreed the objective of the insti- tution which they had created to be "the diffusion of literary, scien- tific and other useful knowledge among.its members: to be attained by means of a reading-room, the delivery of lectures, a library, and the establishment of classes." Tf the Rockhampton School of Arts has degenerated through the years into a lending library the blame cannot be laid at the door of any of those 14 pioneers of cultural thought. Looking for inspiration, its new sponsors might well study the inscription on its birth certi-

ficate, i

Important at this stage of it: career is the fact that society hal much more leisure now than it han 80 or so years ago, and it mighi well be claimed that one functioi of the School of Arts should b« directed; towards the profitable em- ployment thereof. That the pari of literature in the future will tx less than, it was in the past ic not to be expected; but where ii ministered to the -cultural needs ol the comparatively few, there will now be a faj greater number ol folk whose recreation is more on the-playing field than in the -writ tea word. A centre with appropri- ate accommodation for amateur sports clubs of all kinds and also & well-eouipped gymnasium, as a means to gathering youth off tho streets and employing its mind and muscles with healthy recrea- tion, should be among the primary ainjB of the new School of Arts regime. It will be easier to direct the trend of healthy young minds along the hallowed paths leading to culture through literature, than it will be to persuade the same youth to forsake its aimless pavement dossing and languid veranda post leaning to make for the nearest library. If it appears that we place sport as the first considera- tion in the employment of youth- ful leisure, it is because we believe it to be the first need. To become the cultural centre of the citv and district the School of Arts ad- ministration should interest itself in nroviding every form of health giving amateur exercise as the first essential to winning the confidence

land interest of youth- Our sports fields each Saturday afternoon aro replete with lessons of singular portent, for they are of but recent

development.

I On the slopes as it were of

Parnassus provision should be made not only for the accommoda- tion of devotees at the shrine of the several Muses, but for their eneourajrement. While the general tendency is to regard "talent firsts" onlv in the light of prob- able stardom it should never be for- gotten that the city's first duty i« to its youth, first to establish arni then to sustain its cultural bal- ance; first to provide facilities by which youth talent may discover itself and tlwn guide it in the direction of a legitimate outlet for euch talent. If in 50 years the City Council discovers no film or radio star, H will have served well

its purpose if it has aided genera tiona of youth through its inher ent talent to entertain itself. Lesi it appear that such role is cast 01 the toilsome plain rather than upoi the Elysian height, it must be re membered that the former is when youth today is thickest, and thal attainment of the latter is suf- ficient reward.

Flanking these functions should be the free reference library, it be- ing a matter of some reproach that, in a city with four private and one State secondary schools with three others at Yeppoon-or seven such establishments in all-there is no such thing as a reference library for the free use of students. Less because facts change within them- selves than because different ap- plications of them are being de- veloped, and also because science has takeu to itself seven-leagued boots a reference library is no longer, the static institution of our forefathers, and many a bright child could lose its opportunity be- cause it browsed in reference pas- tures that had been eaten out.

But superimposed over it all, and embracing it as it were in its vast resources of recorded know- ledge, should be the general libr- ary with a bright corner for the childi en. Here are the recorded

noblest thoughts of man since he learned to write, here are stirring excursions into the lives of men and of people, here are told in countless ways the never-dying story of the love of man for maid, stories of great sacrifice and daunt- less endeavour. It is a vast store I house crammed with treasures of great price for the enrichment of the human ?'iind and the uplift of the human spirit. Somehow,, the new administration has to open new ways of approach to this store, so that, youth will find the road from the playground to the read- ers' chai? is both pleasurable _and profitable,
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 13. 1947 A CULTURAL MILESTONE
snippet: Unheralded, and quite undeservedly unsung, the form of administration which has for so long guided the destinies of the

1947

AS IN INDIA

Many millions of I people eat nothing but rice their goat-mutton or-on the -fish, for which western i eaters have reason to be gre Rice is grown on land which many centuries has produced ing else, by people to whon growing of rice is a tradv duty. It would take many

But the greatest proposed volution- -in India's dietary less in new food than in vas pansion of supplies of food ab in short supply, and nowhere this apply more than in the 1 of milk and milk products,

But anybody could say that a I percentage of the 30,210,000 g in India ' are either, meat or i producers, for goats enjoy no munity, through religion, from prosaic task of feeding humai It is the reverence that hand of millions of Hindus have for cow that has filled India with lowest class of dairy beast in world-and the biggest food pi

lem.

The AH-India Cattle Show

opened at Delhi on February last, when the Minister for I and Agriculture announced 1 "the three-fold problem of n milk, better cattle and suffic fodder for cattle has to be tackli

i He.: Wetat on \o vsajr that one.

so years could have told him al

stock. He also knew as well as th
