dus in their millions "arie préparée to immolate themselves rathe; than that any -harm should corni I to the very sacred but quite use

less cow. He Í6 in ' fact standing oi

mission.

Husbandry, one of the oldest of man's _ avocations is in its most j primitive state in India the land

I earth. There is little, if any. con-

servation of fodder concentrates, and "no more than 60 per cent, of requirements in fodder are avail- able today," which means that to a very large extent India is little past the stage of producing its milk on a rain fodder basis which after all. is the basis on which we produce beef in Queensland. articleText:
Ohe ¿Konung JMIetm

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, APRIL 14, 19â7.

AID FOR BRITAIN

Considering that it is a fortnigh or more since the public meetin was held to launch the Rockhami ton drive to assist the Australia wide Aid to Britain Fund the rt sponse to date is , nothing abou which we have any reason t boast. According to the last pul lished list of acknowledgements, i amounted in cash, contributions fc less than £600, not a creditabl figure for a city and district o the size and importance of ours.

Whatever the reasons, they d not touch the two most importan

aspects of the case-that is th urgency of the need and the capa city of the district to make

generous response. Nor can it ver; well be attributed to a lack o sympathy and absence of generou instincts on tile part of the com' munity generally. Their creditabli

record in these mattera has beei too often and too long attested t* permit the slightest credence it any suggestion that the generosity of this community has suddenly dried up. But whatever th reasons for the slow response t< date it is time a serious move wai made to make up the lag.

As to the need for the appeal none can plead ignorance of 01 doubt the urgency of the case foi relief to Britain. On top of th« privations of six years of war and the subsequent struggle for eco nomie survival, Britain has been overtaken through floods by appal- ling losses m the sources of hei home-grown food supply. Th« agricultural losses include 1,600,000 sheep, 30,000 cattle, 100,000 aerea of wheat and 100,000 tons ol potatoes. This would have been s major catastrophe even in normal times, but coming now it assumée the proportions of a national disas- ter, the relief of which calls foi outside aid a£ all costs.

The natural effect of these in roads into Britain's scanty food store is a still further reduced

! ration. People in Australia, living

in a land of plenty-not to say

wast«-find it difficult to make the

mind grasp how pitifully meagre is the British ration as it stands, with its ls. £d worth of meat weekly and its scraping of butter ! once a day only; but it should not

call for much imagination to grasp the warning that any further re- duction will have a serious effect on Britain's national health, which is something that concerns Aus- tralia, viewed from the most selfish angle. We are looking to Britain to supply a majority of the immi- grants with which we hope to build up our population to safety limits. An. undernourished people, whose standards of health have been , undermined, is no suitable recruiting ground for population for a country in need of strong healthy citizens. That this possi. bility of a Britain broken in health is not one of idle specula- tion is attested by the latest mor- tality figures from the homeland. For the five months ended March of this year, 11,000 more people

died in Britain than in the cor- responding period last year. Deaths ia London for the same term wera 2000 above normal.

It is for Australia to ask whether we are doing all that we can to aid Britain in what has been

describe^ as '-the most severe struggle she has known in her history.'» There is widespread dis- appointment at the lack of a vigorous lead to the people by national leaders in the Government, and very sharp disagreement with [ the Prime Minister's claim that I "Australia cannot send more food

to Britain without intensifying j the severity of our own rationing." I That disappointment should only j serve to strengthen individual de-

termination to do everything pos ! sible tx> render aid. There are few Australians who would not forgo a proportion of their own generous

j food allowance to help the hard ' pressed people of Britain today. But we are not asked to do that. All we are asked is to give the cash equivalent of the food which is Britain's basic seed at the mo- ment. The appieal sponsored by the Ked Cross affords an easy means of translating cash gifts into food parcels, and this is al- ready being done.

From Rock&ton's viewpoint

the present need is for a sharp j stimulus to he given by the local fund, both by individuals and by organisations whose energies ar<» devoted to raising money for de. serving causes. Until we make a satisfactory showing in this matter it might not be too much to ask that other calls for public funds be placed in the background for the time being.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY. JUNE 14. 1947. THE HALLE CONCERTS

The Hallo concerts, , the first of which was held just 90 years ago, had their origin in the belief ot German-born Charles Halle that, like £old, the love of music is where you find it. He found that lore in Lancashire, which is why the Free Trade Hall, Manchester, became the traditional home of ono of the most remarkable de-

velopments in British musical" history.

Born in 1819, Halie began his musical career at the mature age of aeren, and ten years later ne vant to Paris there to mingle with such giants in the world of art as Cherubim, Chopin, .Liszt, de Müsset and George Sand 's but the first breath of the French revolu- tion swept him across the channel to Britain and, ultimately, to Man- chester. Here he found-long be- fore the songful ebullition of

Gracie Fields-^that. while the love of music was ingrained in the people of Lancashire it was prac- tically uncultivated. So he set to work "to wed Lancashire love of miisic with German musical cul- turé, -and astonished even himself at the success of his Lancastrian orchestra, which ^wrfonned before the late Queen Victoria at "the Exhibition of Art Treasures, Man- chester, in May, 1857.

With the thunder of that great success ringing in his ears. Halie

launched the first of a series of orchestral concerts in January, 1858-and came out of it with an enhanced reputation and a profit of half a crown, as à warning of how strangely fate "may mingle bitter with sweet. It was by no means his last of such experiences, but Halle pocketed his losses, capi- talised his enhanced prestige and was rewarded when three Man- chester ia ns came forward and

helped him with the losses. This

led to the formation in 1889 of

the present Halle Concerts Society, membership of which involves an irrevocable guarantee of £100 tu cover_ .losses, with which backing

the concerts', have continued

throughout fortune both good and bad. Sir Charles Halle died ju 1859. but left as monument a name that took fine music into the home of the1 masses, a name that made immortal his "bob a nob" for practically all seats. Great figures -Richter, Balling, Beecham, Harty and Sargent-followed Halle in Ithat order, but even as they raised

to new heights the status of Jjthese

world-famoua* orchestral concerta, so did they enhance the reputation of the man who . gave them hi« genius -and his name.

Then came World War II, and in like measure as , recruitments left deep gaps in the orchestra se did there - spring up all over Britain a phenomenal demand for good orchestral music. The fragile second violin betook herself to thc

cypher office, the aesthetic double bass found himself among the siege artillery, and the plump

flautist blew hails of lead in the mighty aerial orchestra of tho Battle for Britain; Then Goering's

emissaries arrived over Manchester and bombed Free Trade Hall out of existence. At this pass it seemed as if nothing remained to the Halie Society but to play its own requiem,. but instead it flew high and invited John Barbirolli, of the New York Philharmonic Sym- phony orchestra, to come to Man- chester. To their astonishment, he agreed, and in June, 1943, he ar- rived and at once applied himself to re-forming the 3rd oldest .orchestra" in the world.

It is unlikely that anybody ex- pected miracles, but that is what they got. At the end of a month 40 new players had been added to the attenuated orchestra. Thc aged came out of retirement and an. incapacity for war work, the war-broken youthful - came out of hospitals and convalescent homes, all drawn by the same invisible strings-the inherent love of good music. In July. Bradford emerged from its dug-out to hear a new Halle orchestra that, in the first six months of its existence, it gave 126 concerts to a quarter of a mil- lion delighted, war-worn folk in 34 different towns. Manchester got its first concert in August., when 6000 people flocked into King's Hall to welcome the resur- rection. !: Being portion of a circus King's Hall was less ornate than it sounds, but by a wizardry of improvisation the acoustics proved to be as good, if not better than those of most concert halls. So Manchestriáns of brows both high

and low flocked in their thousands

through avenues of grotesque figures and gaudy signs of great allurement to youth to King's Hall that, surrounded by monkey nouses and merry-go-rounds, had a seat- ing capacity of 6000. That capacity was seldom adequate.

By Christmas, 1944, Lancastrians in their thousands were on the Continent assisting to drive the Hun back into Germany, and it was decided that the Halie concerte would shift to Europe for a short season. Crossing the English Channel had been cleared of many of its military perils, but nobody could do anything about the weather, which staged a blanket fog that. immobilised their troop- ship in mid-channel and shut them out of Brussels, where they were billed to play that " night. But Brussels' loss was the gain of many hundreds of war-bound sol- diers, who were given an im- promptu concert of light music from dance tune scripts, scribbled on the backs of old envelopes with soldiers as music stands. Truly is the love of music where you

find it.

During that tour the concert party was machine-gunned, an oboeist fell in a shell bole and hroke her arm, three players went dowr4 with ?flu but the Halie con- cert party, clad in overcoats and Balaclava helmets, pl va ed to 20.000 delighted troops in" Belgium and Holland. On this and subsequent tours through Britain, the 51 men and $3 women who make up the oreliestra travelled far and lived hard, a two-hour performance

after a 12-hour motor coach jour- ney being the rule, and not the

exception. It was then that they !

found there are two Barbirollis one who from his rostrum drove them without mercy ; the other who. at lorry drivers* " pull ins " and emergency roadhouses, was attentive waiter to women and elderly folk.

Meanwhile, Halle's was homeless but hopeful, its prestige having soared to new heights, the spirit

which it inherited from its founder

never more indomitable. Its opti- mism was justified, for Manches ter ians in their pride decided to build thc Halle with a new home, and it is to be built on the site on which stood the old Free Trade Hall, the cradle and nursery of one of the most famous orchestras in the world.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

FRIDAY, JULY 18, 1947 MADE IN AUSTRALIA

For very many years one of our proudest slogans was the "Made in Australia" label attached to. a steadily expanding and improved quality ' range of manufactured goods. Hence it will Come aa a shock to many to learn that we are in some danger of seeing a very different meaning applied to that slogan. With the realisation that Australia's" future prosperity must depend to a large extent .upon oar ability -to' achieve and maintain a footing iú oufanVIeK:markets for manufactured articles as well 'as, for .primary products; ;a state' bor-, dering on. alarm is; assailing ;the Federal í MíSistry. t>f Commercé,]

which controls Commonwealth- ex-

port trade. . ~ / :

.Little more than a "week ago the Minister for Commerce (Mr Pol-: lard) intimated that Australian ex- port",'methods .fell far below stand- ard. Specifically* he -declared that ,we "fell down on packing, quality" and measurements; in some cases rolls of cloth of short length had been reported." Such charges could be multiplied by other sources. A Sydney manufacturing chemist- just returned from Siam, Malaya and Southern China states that half the gooda exported from Australia to those countries " since the war should never' hâve been allowed to . go. Shoddy merchandise, had . done!

irreparable damage' to Australia's prospects for trade in those coun-

tries. "*'.'" ''

Th» is a disturbing, state of af- fairs;, and;, refl«^ r 'tfce ! utmost short-sightedness cai the - part of . those responsible, both for selling

the goods and -for allowing them to leave the country. According to; the Minister the main- offenders are

those- who do not intend to stay in the export trade. JBnt it also is alleged that the Government is

itself largely ia Mamejfor the poor reputación Australia has gained for its . goods since the war. & this re-

spect the .damage has been due largely to the .shipment of the Dis-, posais Commission's goods both by Government and private traders. These shipments often ..comprised goods,, that were not prepared v for export in the first place, and in- cluded articles of inferior quality, bad packing, torn labels and rusty, tins; in some-cases the' consign- ments were a total loss to the~pur chasers. In one shipment to Singa-, pore of condensed milk from sur- plus Government stock, and. for export of. which the .Commerce. 'De- partment' gave a permit, the tins! bore nb labels, the milk was hardj

and discoloured, and. should-never' have- beéá ¿Uowed . to ^bc sold for. human Mhfiiimptibñ.'< The Govern- ment has regulations-strict enough to control .these things effective)^,' but export licences¿ suitable quality goods have been refused by the Commerce and'Supply De- partment, whilst jpe/mits haye hjien, given for rubbish. Fi^^-which^'îi

would appear that the \ Commerce 'Minister, besides Upbraiding un- scrupulous exporters, might wjfjb. profit examine the permit system wperating in his own Department.

No matter where lies the fault for past misdeeds, none'"trill argue against the necessity f or sound ex-: port standards,' to be maintained in the future. The. period ' of. an unchallenged. sellers' market is passing and Australian exporters must be prepared to meet increas- ing competition. They will be under a heavy and needless, handicap if a bad reputation has been estab- lished abroad for the quality of Australian goods' generally. Until recent yean Commonwealth ex- ports consisted mainly of bulk commodities, but in the case of cer- tain products, especially'fruit, we had to learn. painful lessons con- cerning the necessity for better packing and grading. Nov we are seeking to put manufactured goods on the outside market in order to absoaii the surplus of the factories. We have not had a great deal of experience in thÍB field, sud it is of vital, importance at - the outset to build up goodwill and study the needs* of the consumer. That re- sponsibility devolves firstly upon the "manufacturer and., almost equally, upon the Government to en- sure that the Unscrupulous few who.do notintend.to remain in the export insiness are prevented from .entering ît at all.

Unfortunately the*charge of slip- shod ;-methods in the preparation of goods ¿or public consumption is not confined to exporters. The "Bul- letin's^ Brisbane correspondent this

week gave an account of a mau who purchased a couple of bearing blocks for his irrigation plant. They were made in Australia but

I were described aB "a disgrace to

the name." The castings were rough and unfinished, the brass pitted with air holes up to nearly a quar- ter of an inch across, whilst even the bolts were the wrong size. The i correspondent commented: "What

! engineers overseas would think

of such, rubbishy stuff, is not hard to imagine; the first order would be the last and worse still Austra-

lian goods as a whole would gain a

bad name."

Nor does such - workmanship apply only to bearing blocks turned out by machine shops. Judged by the frequency of' complaints it is a

disease-no doubt a war-time legacy-that runs through a wide range of manufactures intended for

the home as well as .the outside market. It will not do, and unless there is an effective moye to check the drift all the good work accom- plished by the several "Made in Australia" campaigns in pre-war years will go for naught, and the patriotic desire to support local industry will be changed to a directly opposite sentiment, with damaging results all round.

What appears to be required is wide powers for the existing Stan- dards Association to prevent the output of manufactures of low quality, and, in the case of export- able goods, for the Commerce De- partment to enforce its regulations

in the strictest sense.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

THURSDAY. SEPTEMBER 4.

1947.

40 HOURS, DROUGHT AND

DINGOES.

While exponents of the 40-hour week are extolling its moral up- lift and material benefit to both the State and the individual, no- body has yet announced what it is proposed will be done with the extra four hours per week that

millions of workers will have on their hands. So far the only sug- gestion has come, somewhat halt- ingly, from one of the innumerable ABC brains trust, that responsi- bility for filling in that time- or teaching folk what to do with their

leisure- is a matter for the State. We are to "be confronted, it seems, with a brand new problem, in that after paying for many more mil- lions of unworked hours, the com- munity is to be asked to foot the bill for supplying entertainment for recipients of this new freedom

from work.

If the Brains Trust would descend from the clouds and look over this fair land of ours it might be possible for it to see many millions of hours of undone work that workers might do on their own account. Many thousands of those hours are to be seen in and about a large percentage of Rockhampton homes, among which the tidy back yard and well trimmed flower and vegetable gar-

den are the exception and not the rule. There is little enough excuse even now for anybody living amid the desolation of untidiness and neglect; but with four extra hours of leisure per week such shiftless- ness becomes simply inexcusable. That is to say, if a man is to sell

less time to an employer to qualify

for his weekly wage, it is always open to him to sell it to himself so as to brighten and improve his surroundings and those of his family.

But that is mere scratching the surface of the business, though if

in improving his surroundings the

worker is also improving his mental outlook the surface will have been

scratched to some purpose. But

so far his leaders end their leading when they ensure for him that he works fewer hours for his em- ployer. They tell him that he will be that much better off, but do not say how; just as they say that

the State will be that much bettei

off, also without saying how. If the employees' condition is im- proved by doing less work, and the State's condition is improved by there being more work-left-undone none, of Australia's industrial lead-ers has explained why people in every other country on earth- in-

cluding Soviet Russia - try to reach the same condition by work-

ing harder and longer. It is, of course, no business of ours what people do in other countries, ex- cepting maybe to note what steps they take to reach a given result; but it is our business to know why

the rest of the world is so con- sistently out of step with Aus-

tralia.

While this dementia is going forward the Queensland Govern- ment statistician tells a sorry tale of shrinking stock numbers. There is no 40-hour week among the fac- tors that eat into flocks and herds, and far too many of these shrink- ages come from working too few

hours out among the live stock. We lost 154,100 dairy cows, in milk and dry, between the year 1943 and that, which closed at the end of March last, and nobody can pre- tend that that was good for the

State. Some of them- but not

nearly as many as politicians de- clare- were drought victims; but even so their end was hastened by the amazing policy of the Curtin Government, which subsidised wheat farmers in Western Aus- tralia to the extent of millions not to grow wheat. Chances of recovery in numbers of dairy cows is not bright, there being a drop in the same period of 128,000 heifers of one year and over and of calves of one year and under. Feed rationing, made imperative by keeping Western Australian wheat farmers out of production, had much to do with this decline; but the bobby calf industry also helped.

It offered a market for an animal that might otherwise die of star- vation, even though it lingered in

the tax return.

Beef cattle dropped off in the aggregate by 365 000, of which 276,000 was in the cow and heifer or breeder class, and another 203,000 was made up of calves of a year or under. Fewer beef cattle die

of starvation than do dairy cattle, but the dingo toll-due to fewer man-hours worked against them is higher and is shown in the calf losses. Another factor is taxa-

tion, as there is little encourage- ment to mate breeding cattle on a basis of 18/6 in every 20/- for Mr Chifley, so that and the dingo have worked amicably together. A sig-

nificant item is an increase of 206,000 bullocks and spayed cows, really due to strikes at meatworks, leaving unkilled that number of bullocks that should have gone to Britain. Not even Australia can

for long stand that kind of foolery, and somebody should explain how

the 40-hour week is going to help turn these surplus beasts info beef: i.e., from a liability into an asset.

Sheep are in a bad way, for in the five years to 1947 we lost 9 570 000 of them in all classes, or 37 per cent of the 1943 flock! That, of course, is in addition to the natural increase for those years, as indeed obtains also in the case of beef and dairy cattle. All ewes of a year or over declined by 3 790 000 and there were 2 440 000 fewer young stock under a year at the end of March last than there was in March, 1943. Unchecked dingoes and drought be- tween them are responsible for the major part of this smash. Pigs, too, are down in the same period by 69,000, or 20 per cent, due wholly to shortage of rationed feid while Westralian wheat grow-

ers got paid not to grow wheat!

The only inescapable factor here was drought, and even its effects might have been mitigated had not the Curtin Government showmen rushed every able-bodied man into the army, and then built up the Curtin Line So that our armies could not go with our Allies. Hun-

dreds of thousands of men who never left Australia could have

been tending our precious flocks and herds, and now that millions of the world's people are on the brink of starvation the only in- crease in the animal kingdom in Queensland is in the ranks of the dingo clan. This is the record of reduced man-hours in the pas- toral industry over the past five years, and much of the unfinished work that contributed to it is still undone. On the basis of the 40- hour week, when it will be im- possible to get men away from the bright lights of the city, it appears as if this calamitous show- ing it but the beginning of even

worse to come.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON THURSDAY, SEPTEMBER 4, 1947. 4[?] HOURS, DROUGHT AND DINGOES.
snippet: While exponents of the 40-hou[?] week are extolling its moral uplift and material benefit to both the State and the individual,

articleText:
ROCKHAMPTON

SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 27,

194T.

THIS AGE OF PORTENTS

As one State after another in- augurates au official lottery through which the many gi\e to the few, as mid-week racing and night trotting, help add up the cost of living the tipster, the seer, the

oracle and the crystal gazer seem

to occupy a greater place in pub- lic thought than ever before, to be more impudent in their claim to the attention of the gullible. This, be it known, despite the fact that we are spending a record high on education; that men and women of talent and enthusiasm devote themselves to-the colossal task of nurturing the logical, and of im- planting the facts on which the mind can build the temple of reason. Even so, there appears to be more people than ever who be- lieve that some evil of savage vin- dictiveness will descend upon them should a black ace follow a red queen; if the tea leaves in their cup lie in some sinister combina- tion, or if, having entered " the world under the zodiacal sign of Scorpio they conclude a business deal on Thursday while wearing a, brown suit between the hours of ll a.m. and 1 p.m.

So long as this manner of ar- ranging our daily lives is general, our hopes for civilisation must re- main small and our sympathy for our teachers large. If notffing

better or loftier than that can evolve in the human brain or be

the product of its use and opera- tion, can it be said with any cer- titude that man is turning to ade- quate account the Divine gift of reason? The philosophy behind the

state of mind that shudders at the

portents of the stars and exults over the promise revealed by spent leaves in a teacup is no more en- lightened-though it mar s^ll be as profitable to its sponsors-as that stage when human affairs were determined by examining the condition of a..fowl's entrails, or when hapless washerwomen were hanged as witches because children at houses where they plied their calling died of' convulsions. Each reflects a state of savagery and popular delusion difficult to as- sociate with ordinary civilisation, and the modern version of these superstitions is ' incredible in this Christian age.

Does . the growth of belief in signs and portents, in the fore- casts of glib prophets, or in the mumbled incantations of mystics mean that there is a corresponding decrease in our faith in God? Has the seance taken the place of the

sermon, or has the sublime faith

in Divine Will been supplanted by a. greedy anticipation of unearned Wealth, on the .sayrSö of a scheming tipster? Does'God determine our tritures and, having done so, does He really betray Bis intentions by the, manipulation of ftTpack of greasy old cards, or by arranging the whereabouts of a .used tea leaf? If 'this be' so, and the faith of centuries based upon the eternal verities is fading against the rising sun of a cult that goes back to the days of sorcery and witch- craft, cannabilism and slavery, then indeed is the universe but a crazy pavement, and we may as

well dance the dance of the witches

on its silly surface as make resolu- tions for the morrow.

* That is an "unfaith'' BO dismal

and damning that we should view with dismay every trend rf thoughtlessness, or of crafty greed, ïliat helps it on. In a world of mass movements, a world in which even educated men will swallow any myth or lejrend and worship any god-hero rather than f àce ' the ' re- sponsibilities of life, the more «table among us should insist upon our power to choose and mould, and to maintain, at all costs, that for good or ill the future is ours. We misrht with profit take counsel from the words of Shakespeare's ?".eiltest viii." ins. Edmund and Iago who were alike in nothing more profoundly than in calling upon reason to save mankind from pre- posterous conclusions:

"This the excellent foppery of the world that, when we are sick in for- tune-often the surfeit of oor own be-

haviour-we make guilty of our disas-

ters the sun. the moon and the stars: as If they were villains hy necessity: fools by heavemy compul- sion; knaves, thieves and teachers by spherical . predominance; drunkards, liars and adulterers br an enforced obedience of plan lary influence; and all that we are evil in hy a divine thrusting on; an admirable evasion of Trhore-mafter man, to lay his goatish disposition to the charge of

a star."

Shakespeare spake great truths through base lips. But great as was the need for his scathing de- nunciation, never was -it more timely than now. when so many nf our supposedly literate people appear to be swayed by the verbal trickery of soothsayers and tips- ters. It will he idle to blame the vindictiveness of the planets or thc

waywardness of a tea leaf should tlîe earth be turned into a hell.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON SATURDAY, SEPTEMBER 27, 1947. THIS AGE OF PORTENTS

Cfee jflonttag ^Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, JANUARY 27, 1947.

AMERICA FACES I94T

Despot« tome overseas croakin and. Communiât gloating* at t prospecta of a .major smash

Unele Sam's land because he c loose from many war-time cc trois, tba ruling sentiment ov there on the threshold of - 19' ia one of confidence. It ia tn

that they ara issuing warnings < their own account, but the genen view and forecast pointed to ne peaks of production in many k< industries, provided they 'hold ti price line and avoid major strike That proviso is elementary ai holds good in Australia no Ie than in U.SA. Full productif and equitable distribution withi the framework of a free sociel are the soundest bulwarks' agaim Old Man depression, and nobod in Australia who ia not either

member of Canberra Brains Trui or an abject apologist will pr tend that we have either i Australia.

Talking «ver the national ne work the Under Secretary < Labour (Keen Johnston) woul have none of "the fatalism < boom and bust," and also declare that the American set-up wa based on the resolve that neithe blind chance nor raw economi power will determine thei national welfare. With othe men who have their finger o the pulse of America's nations life, Johnston expects to see

big expansion in two-way oversea trade. Where the keynote a Canberra is one of stagnant con merce and stalled in dos fay, Und Sam devoted the first part o ?1948 to liquidation of war pro duction, after which expansion o consumer goods took charge an« is^out full-bore after new records America wanta to buy more thing! from overseas, and is gearing nj to ' produce export goods to pa]

for them,

Nobody in U.8~A. pretends U control the weather, so that t proviso that it behaves itself ii added to a forecast that the farm lng outlook is more promising than for many years, and it if expected that there will be mon bushels of corn raised in this yeai than ever before in American history. It is also anticipated that tile volume of dairy products will increase without increase in price; but the same forecast ex- pects fats, sugar and some tinned goods to continue in short supply. The forecast takes account of thr possibility of some "slide off' in the prices for primary products, it ls not anticipated that they will fall far below present high levels. Consumer pressure is a new factor, though the general belief is that it wUl be a stabilis- ing one.

' A realistic view is taken of the possibilities of industrial peace, in which regard the sudden folding up of labour-leader Lewie In the face of a Presidential challenge is held to be most promising. It established for one thing the fact Of community rights and the deter- mination of the Government to preserve them. Unlike in Aus. tralla, where the community is regarded as merely incidental to the behests of industrial and political nabobs, there is in U.S.A. a strong belief in the rights or the common man, and a no lesa strong belief that the Government is the proper repository, for and de- fender of those rights. They have no equivalent there of the A.C.T.U.

A.W.U. - Communist triangular Katti* in whieh tho rights ot the

people and the powers and duties of Governments go by the board.

In support of this view Boris Shiskin, economist for the Ameri-

can Federation -of Labour «aid that because "reliance on direct

negotiation and settlement by con-

ciliation and mediation will be

much greater," there will be fewer

strikes in 1947. He added that if left to their own responsibilities, with Government rule limited to

providing the machinery for that conciliation and mediation, "man- agement and labour will have "a

tremendous incentive to work out

their problems peacefully on their own." After all, problems of in-

dustry and production differ little i fundamentally in U.S.A. from; those confronting Australia-the

vital difference is that Uncle Sam j still governs in the interests of!

the community, whereas class government in Australia ÍB ram- pant, and the seat of government

fluctuates between Mark House and the Trades Hall.

articleText:
The Morning Bulletin

ROCKHAMPTON

MONDAY, MAY S, 194T.

SAW MATERIALS AND

SECONDARY INDUSTRIES

The industrialisation of South Australia coes on apace in spite of many natural handicaps, the chief

of which is an absence of coalfields. The latest development, and one which must have aroused no little envy on the párt of other States, particularly New South wales, is the announcement by Imperial Chemical Industries of its intention to spend £1,000,000 on extensions ¡ of the existing alkali plant at Os- borne, SA to bring the annual out- put up to 100,000 tons.

Imperial Chemical i6 the kind of industrial organisation that any country would welcome, and South Australia is likely to derive per- manent gain from this enterprise. The alkalis to be produced include soda ash, caustic coda, bicarbonate of soda and calcium chloride. All of these are in short supply and they are vital to Australia's economy. As a fact títere is a world -wide shor- tage of alkalis, even America being unable to produce to full require- ments. Australia has trebled con- sumption in the last 10 years, and the establishment of new industries during and since the war has caused, consumption to overtake supply, i Shortages will continue until the new ?plant begins to step up out Iput..

I South Australia is fortunate in having the only existing works in 'operation, and more so in having the . saltSeld deposits which form the baisis. pf .these products. It is an economic truth that secondary in- dustries' should be based on sup- plies of raw materials, and in fact this must be the guiding principle of decentralisation bf industry which is now the stated policy of 'all governments. But whilst it has

the raw material in the salt fields, South Australia suffers a serious

handicap in respect of coal which ig equally essential to industrial production. South Australia's only coal is the Leigh Creek field, which ia totally inadequate and it is frankly admitted by the Fermier of the State that coal for the opera- tion of the new works will have to be brought from NSW

Queensland will not quarrel with the principle of basing secondary industries at the source of raw material because it happens to be in another State, but in conceding the principle it is entitled to insist on its rights in the same regard. If South Australia getg the alkali works on account of its salt fields and NSW steelworks because of the

proximity of coal and iron, Queens- land, and Central Queensland more so, is entitled to wool and hide processing because of its com- manding position in the production of those raw materials. We are in a

particularly favourable situation as regards coal deposits that are as yet scarcely touched, but which still somehow appear to escape the notice .of those behind the present industrial expansioB^in Australia.

Recently a RocS&ton mer-

chant was in Adelaide and, attended an industrial exhibition of manufactures made in that State which really amazed him. It hap- pened that he was called upon to respond at an official luncheon, and in doing so remarked that what amazed him was not so much the variety and excellence of the goods displayed as the fact that they were being manufactured in a State that wag virtually without coal, whilst Central Queensland, with a vast area of untapped coal re- sources, was virtually without in- dustries. This comment resulted after the luncheon in his being asked many questions about this region, particularly the coal deposits to which he had referred. To his surprise he found that his inter- rogators confessed they had little or no knowledge of our wealth in this connexion.

South Australia's advanced posi- tion and Queensland g back seat in industry are not entirely due io the incidence of natural resources. Gov. eminent plays some part in it, and South Australia always has pos- sessed a government which does not frighten away the investor. When Premier Playford announced the big ICI scheme for his State an inquiry was put forward as to whether this enterprise could not have been es- tablished in NSW which has the coaL the inquirer conveniently over- looking-though it is improbable I the company did-the fact that a six months' old strike is on the way to throttling ICI existing works at Botany. . . » -

Í Central Queensland is not envious of South Australia's good fortune j with the alkali works, but we are

entitled to ask with greater insist- ent when something of the kind is likely to come this way.
heading: The Morning Bulletin ROCKHAMPTON MONDAY, MAY 5, 1947. SAW MATERIALS AND SECONDARY INDUSTRIES
snippet: The industrialisation of South Australia goes on apace in spite of many natural handicaps, the chief of which is an absence of coalfields.
